loan.name: Para

texts.en: Para K. lives in a single family with her husband and two children in Koteshwor. Her husband's name is Lalit K. and he works in a private office. They have one son and one daughter. Both of them are studying in secondary school. Para opened her bag shop three years ago to help her husband in fulfilling the household expenses. She sells different types of bags like school and ladies bags in her shop. She buys these bags from the wholesale market. Now she is requesting a $300 loan to expand her shop. She wants to buy different varieties of bags. Para wants to use her income for her childrenâ€™s education and she also wants to upgrade the living standard of her family.

loan.use: To buy bags

loan.name: Puanam

texts.en: Punam M. has two daughters. Her daughters are studying in grade 9 and 6 respectively. Her husband's name is Bharat M. and he works in a shoe shop. Punam M. opened her beauty parlor 3 years ago to earn something for herself. She took 3 month of training for this work from a training institute. She opened her beauty parlor in Koteshwor. Her service is for ladies only. Now she is requesting a loan for $300 to buy various types of cosmetic goods for her work. M. wants to use her income to increase the living standard of her family. She also wants to provide a good education for her daughters.

loan.use: To buy cosmetic goods

loan.name: Ambica

texts.en: Ambica P. lives in Koteshwor, Nepal. Koteshwor is located in the Kathmandu district. Most of the people in this region are engaged in their own businesses. Ambica P. has four members including herself in her family. Her husband's name is Bhishma Raj P.. He works in a private office. They have two children. Her older son is studying in grade 10 and the younger son is studying in grade 9. Two years ago Ambica opened her ready made clothes shop to uplift the living standard of her family. She sells different types of clothes in her shop. She specializes in children clothes. Now Ambica is requesting a $300 loan to buy new design clothes for her shop.

loan.use: To buy clothes for her shop

loan.name: Sokha

texts.en: Sokha N., 57, and her husband, Chhout Aum, live on an island in Cambodia's Mekong River. Married for 31 years, they have four daughters. One of their daughters is married and lives at home with them; two sell silk goods in the village; and the other weaves silk at home. Sokha is requesting a loan of $400 U.S. dollars to buy wood and materials to build a house for her daughter.

loan.use: To buy wood to build a home

loan.name: Phally

texts.en:
Phally S., 35, and his wife, Sivorn Mok, 35, live in a village about 10 miles from Phnom Penh, Cambodia's capital city. Married for 16 years, they have three young children who are in school.

Phally supports his family by working as a gardener in a hotel and also farms his own land in his free time. Sivorn works in a garment factory. They are requesting a loan of $1,000 U.S. dollars to dig a well and install a water pumping machine so his family can have clean drinking water. He also plans on using the water for his small farm.

loan.use: To dig a well for his family's drinking water and a small farm

loan.name: Christine

texts.fr:
Born in about 1948 in Porto-Novo in the OuÃ©mÃ© department in south-east Benin, Mrs. Christine D. is a widow and mother of four children. Three of her children are already grown up and are no longer dependent on her. She has always lived in HindÃ© 1, the district surrounding Dantokpa market. For about twenty years she has run a business selling condiments and various food products. In 2007 she took out an initial loan of 40,000 CFA Francs ($100) in order to increase her capital and make her display more attractive. This loan proved to be a great support as her business underwent a considerable improvement. She is currently requesting a third loan of 100,000 CFA Francs ($250) to better satisfy her customers who have come to her because her business is located close to Dantokpa market.

Translated from French by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer.

loan.use: To buy three boxes of canned tomatoes and 25 kg of dried peppers.

loan.name: Sily

texts.en:
Sily Y., 42, and her husband, Pha Sim, 45, a farmer, live in a small village on an island in Cambodia's Mekong River. Married for 18 years, the couple has one son and one daughter.

For the past decade, Sily has earned a living by weaving silk into cloth, a skill she learned from her parents. She sells her finished goods to a middle man in the village, who then takes it to sell in the capital city of Phnom Penh, which is about 10 miles away. In addition to her weaving business, hard-working Sily also runs a small grocery shop in the front of her home.

To grow her businesses, Sily is requesting a loan of $700 U.S. dollars to purchase more food to sell and silk to weave.

loan.use: To buy goods for a small grocery store and silk for weaving

loan.name: Sat's Group

texts.en:
Sat P. (shown at the far left, with the rest of her group members) was nominated to be a group leader for a loan. In a group loan, all the members split the loan equally and guarantee that each will repay her portion.

All of these women live in a small village on an island in Cambodia's Mekong River, about 10 miles north of the capital city of Phnom Penh. They all help support their families by weaving silk into cloth; a middle man takes their finished products to sell in Phnom Penh's markets. To grow their businesses, they plan on purchaing more raw silk to weave.

From right to left, Sat's group includes:

1. Sat P., 45, who has been a weaver for more than a decade, a skill she learned from her neighbor. She is married to Khun San, a mason; they have one son.

2. KhO. O., 20, is a newlywed. She and her husband, a construction worker, married last year. . 3. P. Pheap and her husband, a fisherman, have six children. 4. Sitha C., 27, and her husband, Vuthy Touch, a boat driver, married this year. 5. Sreynheb P., 42, is widow with three children, all of whom are garment factory workers. .

loan.use: To purchase silk material for weaving.

loan.name: Sitha

texts.en:
Sitha H., 50, lives in a small village on Cambodia's Mekong River about 15 miles north of the capital city of Phnom Penh. A widow, Sitha has four daughters, three of whom are married and one who lives with her at home.

For the past 34 years, Sitha has supported her family by weaving silk into cloth, a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished produts to a middle man in her village, who then resells it in Phnom Penh's markets. In addition to weaving, hard-working Sitha also grows rice to sell. To grow her businesses, Sitha is requesting a loan of $1,200 U.S. dollars to purchase more silk and rice.

loan.use: To purchase silk to weave and rice for a small farm

loan.name: KakadÃ© Lucie

texts.fr: Native of Lokossa in the Mono department in south-west Benin, Mrs. KakadÃ© Lucie G. is 57 years old. She is married to Mr. Gabriel DEGBOGBAHOUN, a retired soldier, and is mother to five children. She does catering at the Suru-LÃ©rÃ© School of General Education. In March 2004 she requested and was granted a first loan of 30,000 CFA Francs ($75) so that she could offer her clientele, made up mostly of pupils from the Suru-LÃ©rÃ© school, a varied and sufficiently well-balanced daily menu. This experience proved very beneficial as, within a year, her working capital went from 50,000 CFA Francs ($125) to 85,000 CFA Francs ($210). Other loans followed this first one. The only detriment to her career as a female entrepreneur has been her health, which was a little fragile in 2006, the year when she received a loan of 70,000 CFA Francs ($175). Her health has since improved and her business has returned to normal. She is therefore requesting her seventh loan to better position herself. Translated from French by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer. loan.name: Im

texts.en:
Mrs. Im N., 34, lives in Toul Vihear Village, Kampong Cham Province. She has been had a tailoring business with her husband for eight years, making approximately $5 per day. They both buy cloth, design painted shirts and sell them to customers. They work hard everyday to generate income to care for the living and education expenses of their three children. Due a growing tailoring business, they have a chance to generate more income. Therefore, they are requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase cloths stocks to make more shirts to sell.

About Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL): Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL) is one of Cambodia's largest and most successful microfinance institutions (MFIs). It is committed to helping its clients achieve their business goals by providing sound financial services, and thereby hopes to contribute to the social and economic development of Cambodia. HKL specifically targets women and poor families in order to help them achieve increased financial security and quality of life, by offering various credit programs and encouraging savings. In accordance with its mission and its commitment to operational and financial sustainability, HKL contributes part of its net profits every year to support social development in education and healthcare.

loan.use: To purchase cloths

loan.name: MawuenyÃ©gan Komivi

texts.fr:
Mr. MawuÃ©nyegan Komivi K. was born in KÃ©vÃ© on April 8, 1978. He is single and has no children. He is a merchant of generic goods. However, since 2007, he has specialized in the sale of Forever Living products; he received training for these products and he is able to offer his clients advice about them. At present time, he has a large number of clients who want to buy his products. Yet, Mr. K.â€™s working capital is insufficient to meet the demand. As a result, he is asking for this loan, his first, so he can increase his stock.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

loan.name: Seok

texts.en:
Mrs. Seok C., 47, is a widowed grocery seller in Tonle Bet Krom Village, Kampong Cham Province. She earns around $2 per day and lives with her three children. One of her children is a driver for a private transportation company, while another works for a tobacco factory. Part of her children's income support the family's expenses. As C.â€™s business expands, she would like to request a loan of $200 to purchase more grocery stocks to sell. The loan will allow her to increase her income.

About Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL): Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL) is one of Cambodia's largest and most successful microfinance institutions (MFIs). It is committed to helping its clients achieve their business goals by providing sound financial services, and thereby hopes to contribute to the social and economic development of Cambodia. HKL specifically targets women and poor families in order to help them achieve increased financial security and quality of life, by offering various credit programs and encouraging savings. In accordance with its mission and its commitment to operational and financial sustainability, HKL contributes part of its net profits every year to support social development in education and healthcare.

loan.use: To purchase more grocery stocks

loan.name: Ou

texts.en:
Mrs. Ou S., 31, is a mother of four children, living in Boeng Kok Village, Kampong Cham Province. She is a pig raiser earning around $3 per day, while her husband is a security guard at the market, earning around $3 per day. One of her children is a bricklayer, while another is car washer. Part of their children's income helps to support the family's expenses. Due to increasing transportation expenses, S. would like to request a loan of $1000 to purchase a second hand motorcycle for household use. With the remainder of the loan, she plans to purchase more pigs to raise. The loan will allow her family to increase their income.

About Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL): Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL) is one of Cambodia's largest and most successful microfinance institutions (MFIs). It is committed to helping its clients achieve their business goals by providing sound financial services, and thereby hopes to contribute to the social and economic development of Cambodia. HKL specifically targets women and poor families in order to help them achieve increased financial security and quality of life, by offering various credit programs and encouraging savings. In accordance with its mission and its commitment to operational and financial sustainability, HKL contributes part of its net profits every year to support social development in education and healthcare.

loan.use: To purchase a second hand motorcycle

She sells cookies, toothpaste and toothbrushes. She has been running this business for seven years and she lives with her husband in her parentsâ€™ house. She got to know our organization in 2007 when she had financial problems that were restricting her ability to purchase supplies. She received a total amount of 40,000 CFA Francs ($100) in her very first loan. Her business has grown considerably and her working capital has improved appreciably. For her third loan, she is requesting 100,000 CFA Francs ($250) to improve her business.

loan.name: Sok

texts.en:
Mrs. Sok P., 28, is a farmer. She also sells bread with pork near her house. She makes about $1.8 per day. Her husband is a motorcycle taxi driver who makes around $2.5 per day. They have two children, and one is a textile worker whose income helps to support the familyâ€™s expenses. They all live in Andorng Chros Village in Kampong Cham Province. P. is requesting a loan of $300 to change her husband's motorcycle because it is old and does not attract customers.

About Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL):

Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL) is one of Cambodia's largest and most successful microfinance institutions (MFIs). It is committed to helping its clients achieve their business goals by providing sound financial services, and thereby hopes to contribute to the social and economic development of Cambodia. HKL specifically targets women and poor families in order to help them achieve increased financial security and quality of life, by offering various credit programs and encouraging savings. In accordance with its mission and its commitment to operational and financial sustainability, HKL contributes part of its net profits every year to support social development in education and healthcare.

loan.name: Rachelle

texts.fr:
Mrs. Rachelle S. was born on March 22, 1970 in Porto-Novo, the political capital of Benin, and is married to Casimir BODEHOUSSE who is a teacher. They have two children who both attend school. She has lived with her husband in the family home in the SÃ¨nadÃ© II neighborhood of Cotonou for over 10 years. She runs a business selling food products and cloth tunics (pagnes) in front of her house. As an initial loan she received 60,000 CFA Francs ($150). She has since added the sale of cosmetics to her business activities and she is requesting 150,000 CFA Francs ($375) to lay in supplies.

Translated from French by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer.

loan.name: Benkadi 1 (Lâ€™Entente Est Une Bonne Chose Group

texts.fr:
The Benkadi group is made up of married women who, on average, are 40 years old and have four children. They live in extended traditional families with their husbands, their husbandsâ€™ other wives, their brothers, their sisters, and their children in the village of Konobougou in the Baroueli prefecture (fourth largest administrative region in the Republic of Mali). They have a unique business which primarily consists of selling cloth, linens, childrenâ€™s clothing, etc. They know each other through family and neighborly relations. The members of the Benkadi group are on their third loan with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, and all of the previous loans were repaid in full, allowing them to go from a first loan of 50,000 CFA francs to this loan of 100,000 CFA francs. They intend to buy cloth, clothing, shoes, etc. in Bamako and then sell them retail at the market in piles or spread out on tables. Their retail customers are primarily women. They would all like to open a clothing and linen shop at the market in Konobougou, which is located on an international roadway.

Translated from French by Kristina Jackson, Kiva Volunteer.

loan.name: Fatima

texts.fr:
Born around 1966, Ms. Fatima O. sells ready-to-eat meals (rice mixed with some beans, called "atassiâ€ locally). She is married and the mother of four. Two of her children are in school, and the other two are in apprenticeships to learn a trade. She is on her third loan and does make her payments. For this loan, she is requesting 150,000 francs CFA, which will enable her to be consistently supplied with inventory in order to cover a big part of her orders, which are continuously growing. Also, she would like to improve her sales outlet by building a shack to attract more customers. Ms. Fatima O.â€™s sales outlet is located in the Saint Martin district, near her home. Her daily turnover can be assessed at about 8,000 francs CFA.

loan.name: Sony

texts.en:
Sony S. and her husband, Voeun Krouch, live in a small village on the Mekong River about 10 miles north of Phnom Penh, Cambodia's capital city. Married for 24 years, they have one son and four duaghters. Two of their children are married themselves; one son is a construction worker; and the youngest two daughters are in school.

For the past 16 years, Sony has helped support her family by weaving silk into cloth, a skill she learned from her neighbor. She sells her finished products to a middle man in her village, who then resells it in Phnom Penh's markets. Meanwhile, Voeun is a mason.

To help grow her weaving business, Sony is requesting a loan of $300 U.S. dollars to purchase more silk.

loan.use: To buy silk for a weaving business

loan.name: Sophea

texts.en:
Sophea K., 32, lives in a small village on an island in Cambodia's Mekong River, about 10 miles from the capital city of Phnom Penh. She is single and resides with her aging parents and one brother.

Since she was 15, Sophea has supported herself and her family by weaving silk into cloth, a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to a middle man in their village, who then resells it in Phnom Penh. To help grow her business, Sophea is requesting a loan of $200 U.S. dollars to buy more silk to weave.

loan.use: To purchase silk material for weaving.

loan.name: Benkadi 3 (Lâ€™Entente Est Une Bonne Chose). Group

texts.fr:
The women of the Benkadi group are married and, on average, are 35 years old and have five children. They live in traditional families with their husbands, generally their husbandsâ€™ other wives, and their children in Djinina, a village in the Fana subprefecture, Dioila prefecture, Koulikoro Region, Republic of Mali. They all have small businesses that consist of selling food items, clothing, charcoal, fruits and vegetables, etc. They are primarily united by the fact that they live in the same village. Benkadi has been working with Soro Yiriwaso for four years and has obtained eight group loans which were all repaid in full. The group members who sell charcoal generally buy it in other villages and then sell it for cash on market days to business clients from Bamako or SÃ©gou. The other women buy their condiments in Fana and then sell them retail in the village. With this loan, the women of the Benkadi group from Djinina, Fana hope to each earn a monthly profit of 10,000 CFA francs, which will be mostly used to pay off the interest on the loan and resolve some financial problems. The rest will be used for capital.

Translated from French by Kristina Jackson, Kiva Volunteer.

loan.use: Purchase of charcoal and fruit

loan.name: Chanthol

texts.en:
Chanthol C., 31, and his wife, Vibol Rin, live in a small village about 10 miles from Phnom Penh, Cambodia's capital city. Married for eight years, they have three young children, one son and two daughters.

For the past eight years, Chanthol has supported his family by driving a motorcycle taxi from his village to Phnom Penh, while Vibol works as a worker in a garment factory. The problem is that Chanthol's motorcycle is old, so it frequently breaks down.

Chanthol and Vibol are requesting a loan of $1,000. They plan on using a portion of that money to buy a new motorcycle, and spend the rest on building a bathroom in their home. Currently, their home has no restroom.

loan.use: For home repairs and to buy a new motorcycle for a taxi business

loan.name: Phalla

texts.en:
Phalla N., 37, and her husband, Sam-Ol Mol, live in a small village about 10 miles from Phnom Penh, Cambodia's capital city. Married for 17 years, they have two sons and one daughter. Two of their children are currently in school.

To help support her family, Phalla is woven silk into cloth, a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to a man in their village, who then sells in Phnom Penh's markets. Meanwhile, Sam-Ol works as a salesman.

Phalla and Sam-Ol have recently moved into a new house. Phalla is requesting a loan of $1,200 U.S. dollars to build a fence around their home, and also purchase more silk for weaving.

loan.use: For home repairs and to buy silk for weaving

loan.name: Christine

texts.fr:
Born on August 24, 1986 in Cotonou, Ms. Christine G. is a hairdresser by profession and the mother of two children, of whom the eldest is in her second year at the Cours PrÃ©paratoire. Her husband, an electronics technician, takes care of her children very well. Ms. Christine G.â€™s beauty salon is located in the Midombo district and on the edge of an open gutter, not far from the Midombo pharmacy. The good location of her place of business enables her to have good sale figures. The loan will allow her to stock up on hair extensions and other hair care products to meet the expectations of her customers better.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva volunteer

Son mari, technicien en Ã©lectronique s'occupe trÃ¨s bien de ses enfants. Le salon de beautÃ© de dame G. loan.name: Thy

texts.en:
Thy P., 30, and her husband, Sina Auk, 27, a construction worker, live on an island in the Mekong River, about 10 miles from Phnom Penh, Cambodia's capital city. They were married eight years ago have one son and two daughters.

For more than a decade, Thy has earned a living by weaving silk into cloth, a skill she learned from her parents. She sells her finished products to a man in her village, who then takes it to sell in Phnom Penh's markets. In addition to weaving, entrepreneurial Thy also wants to start another business of selling vegetables in front of their home.

To help grow her businesses, Thy is requesting a loan of of $400 U.S. dollars to purchase more silk to weave and vegetables to resell. .

loan.use: To purchase silk to weave and vegetables to sell

loan.name: Sitha

texts.en:
Sitha H., 49, and his wife, Phally Pich, live in a village about 10 miles outside of Phnom Penh, Cambodia's capital city. Married for 26 years, they have two sons and four daughters. For nearly three decades, Sitha has supported his family by driving a siklo, or a bicycle with a trailer in the front to carry people or goods. In Cambodia, most people use siklos or motorcycle taxis to get from place to place instead of taxis or buses.

Phally is a stay-at-home mother. Three of their children are still in school; two of their daughters work in a garment factory; and one of the sons also rides a siklo. To help drive his daughters to the factory, Sitha is requesting a loan of $300 U.S. dollars to purchase a motorcycle.

loan.use: To purchase a motorcycle to drive their daughters to work

loan.name: Rim

texts.en:
Rim C., 32, and his wife, Sros Mony Kao, live in a village about 10 miles from Phnom Penh, Cambodia's capital city. They were married six years ago and have one son and one daughter.

For the past 11 years, Rim and Sros have earned a living by working in a garment factory. However, they don't make enough to pay for home repairs, which they desperately need. To build a fence and bathroom in their home, Rim is requesting a loan of $1,000 U.S. dollars.

loan.use: To build a fence and bathroom in a family home

loan.name: Benkadi 4 (Lâ€™Entente Est Une Bonne Chose Group

texts.fr:
The women in the Benkadi 4 group are married and, on average, are 23 years old and have four children. They live in polygamous families with their husbands, their husbandsâ€™ other wives, and their children in the village of Sikouna 2, in the subprefecture of Fana (Koulikoro Region, Republic of Mali). Their business consists of selling charcoal, which they buy in neighboring villages from men who are specialized in producing charcoal. They have a place to store the charcoal in front of their family homes and generally sell it retail to a diverse clientele (men and women) and wholesale to people who have market stands in big cities like SÃ©gou Fana and Bamako. Brought together by the fact that they are in the same trade, live in the same village and are each experienced in business, the members of the group were faced with a lack of capital. After much discussion, they decided to join Soro Yiriwaso, from which they are receiving their first group loan. With this loan, they intend to buy an average of 15 bags of charcoal each (1,000 CFA francs per bag). Each bag will then be sold for 1,500 CFA francs, generating a weekly profit of 7,500 CFA francs. This profit will help them pay off the interest on the loan and meet their familiesâ€™ needs and will above all help them to develop their business.

Translated from French by Kristina Jackson, Kiva Volunteer.

loan.use: Purchase of charcoal and various items

loan.name: Hongchhay

texts.en:
Hongchhay N., 29, and his wife, Sokha Lai, 27, live in a village near Phnom Penh, Cambodia's capital city. They were married seven years ago and have three sons, one of whom is already in school.

To support his family, Hongchhay sells bricks. He buys them from a kiln in his village and resells them at a construction site in Pnom Penh. Unfortunately, the truck Hongchhay uses to drive the bricks recently broke down and he can't afford the repairs, so he's unable to work. To purchase the parts he needs, Hongchhay is requesting a loan of $1,000 U.S. dollars.

loan.use: To repair a truck needed for a brick-selling business

loan.name: Vorn

texts.en:
Vorn Y., 59, is a mother of five living in an island in the Mekong River, about 15 kilometers from the capitol city of Phnom Penh. She is married to Ou Kot, 63, a farmer.

For the past two decades, Vorn has earned a living by weaving silk, a skill that she learned from a relative. One of her sons also weaves silk. They sell their finished product to a middle man in the village, who then peddles it in Phnom Penh's markets. To expand her business, Vorn is requesting a loan of $400 U.S. dollars to buy more raw silk.

loan.use: To buy silk for a family weaving business

loan.name: FÃ©licitÃ©

texts.fr:
Born on July 10, 1972 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, Ms. FÃ©licitÃ© V. is married and the mother of three. She sells basic provisions, namely pasta, beverages, milk, rice, etc. She also sells food and has a small phone center, too. She buys goods in Tokpa, and sometimes in LomÃ© in TOGO, then markets them in a shop located in her home in the SÃ¨nadÃ© district. She is on her third loan with ALIDE and is one of the best recipients of our institution.

Mr. Joseph B. was born in Akpro-MissÃ©rÃ©tÃ©, in the county of l'OuÃ©mÃ©, in the southwest of Benin. He is 38 years old. He is married and the father of four children, who are all in school and in his care. His shop is situated in the Akpakpa-DodomÃ¨ district, and its location enables him to realize considerable sales figures each day. Joseph B. is on his third loan and always honors the due-dates of the payments associated with his loan.

loan.name: Deme (Soutien Mutuel). Group

texts.fr:
The nine women in the Deme (Mutual Support) group are married and, on average, are 20 years old and have three children. They live in polygamous families with their husbands, their husbandsâ€™ other wives, and their children in the village of Sikouna 2 (Koulikoro Region, Republic of Mali). Their business consists of selling charcoal, which they buy from farmers who have licenses to cut down trees and produce charcoal. They have a place to store the charcoal in their family homes and generally sell it retail to a diverse clientele (men and women) and wholesale to people who have market stands in big cities like SÃ©gou Fana and Bamako. Brought together by the fact that they are in the same trade, live in the same village and are each experienced in business, the members of the group decided that in order to generate additional income, they would join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, from which they are receiving their first group loan. With this loan, they intend to buy an average of 25 bags of charcoal each (1,000 CFA francs per bag). Each bag will then be sold for 1,500 CFA francs, generating a weekly profit of 12,500 CFA francs. This profit will help pay off the interest on the loan and will above all help them to develop their business. Please note that Alimate DiakitÃ© is not in the group photo, as she was helping a woman in labor at the community health center in Marka Coungo at the time it was taken.

loan.name: Ndeye Coumba

texts.fr:
Ndeye Coumba F. is a married woman and mother of six children. She lives in the CitÃ© Senghor quarter of ThiÃ¨s and sells seasonal fruits with help from the IMCEC branch located in ThiÃ¨s. She has taken out small loans before that she was able to repay on time. She is requesting this loan so she can increase her revenue.

EST UNE FEMME MARIEE ET MERE DE SIX ENFANTS .ELLE HABITE AU QUARTIER CITE SENGHOR ET VENDS DES FRUITS DE SAISON A COTE DE LA DIRECTION DE IMCEC DE THIES .ELLE A EU A BENEFICIER DE PETITES SOMMES QU ELLE A PU REMBOURSER DANS LES DELAIS. C EST DANS LE BUT D AMELIORER SES REVENUS QU ELLE SOLLICITE CE PRET.

loan.name: Djantoyerela (La Prudence Group

texts.fr:
The members of the Djantoyerela group are married women who, on average, are 40 years old and have five children. They live in extended families with their husbands, their in-laws, their husbandsâ€™ other wives, and their children in the village of Djinina, in the Fana subprefecture (Koulikoro Region, Republic of Mali). The members of the Djantoyerela group sell grains, Shea almonds and candy. They came together because they are in the same line of business and all live in the same village. The Djantoyerela group is on its eighth group loan with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, and all of its previous loans were repaid in full. They buy their products in neighboring villages (Marka Coungo, Tinkole and Santiguila), which allows them to keep a sufficient supply. These products are sold as is or are turned into flour to make â€œfarou farou,â€ a local cake adored by children. For the part of their business that consists of processing Shea almonds, a portion of the loan will be used to pay other women for the almonds. They will sell their products in the villages named above. Each member of the group is involved in at least two different parts of the business and has a great ability to adapt to economic hardships. They hope to earn an average profit of 17,500 CFA francs per month.

Translated from French by Kristina Jackson, Kiva Volunteer.

loan.name: Mohamed's Group

texts.en:
Mohamed K. (left), born in Makale, 35 years old, and married with 3 children. He works for the military and engages in agricultural activities. He will use his share of the loan to buy seeds and expand his farm.
Next to him is Abu S.. He was born in Port Loko 24 years ago. He is married with 2 children. He will use his loan to expand his food business.
Foday T. (second to right) is 34 years old and was born in Pujenhun. He is married with 4 children. Foday`s wife sells cooked rice, and Foday will use his loan to expand his wife's business. Like his colleagues, Foday will be repaying his loan out of his monthly military salary.
Borbor S. (right) is 25 years old, born in Kamabai. He currently works in Makeni with the military. Borbor will use his loan to get started in farming, a long-time dream of his,
These men are requesting a loan of Le 3,600,000.00 to improve their incomes and better provide for their families.

loan.use: To buy seed rice for farming, and expand their different businesses.

loan.name: Djekafo (Soyons Ensemble Group

texts.fr:
The members of the Djekafo group are married with an average age of 19 years and have 2 children amongst themselves. They live in traditional families with their husbands, their parents-in-law, and their children in the village of Sikouna 1 in the sous-prefecture of Fana, in the Koulikoro Region of Mali. The women have specialized in the business of consumer products such as soap, peanuts, fresh milk, and plastic cooking utensils (buckets, kettles, plates), etc. Having ties to one another due to proximity, alliances, and friendship, the women in the group have taken out their first united loan (group loan) with Soro Yiriwaso. They get their stock from various towns (Bamako, SÃ©gou, etc.) by buying from wholesalers. They sell their goods in Sikouna 1 at home as well as in the markets of surrounding villages. The client base is made up of women from the villages and a few men. In the future, they hope to become wholesalers and serve the neighboring villages.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

Elles se sont spÃ©cialisÃ©es dans le commerce des articles de consommation courante comme le savon, lâ€™arachide, le lait frais et les ustensiles de cuisine en plastiques (seaux bouilloires assiettes) etc. LiÃ©es par des relations de voisinage, dâ€™alliances et dâ€™amitiÃ©, les femmes du groupe sont Ã  leur premier prÃªt solidaire (prÃªt de groupe) avec Soro Yiriwaso. Dans le futur, elles envisagent devenir des grossistes et servir lâ€™ensemble des villages voisins.

loan.use: Purchase of buckets, plastic cups, and other various items

loan.name: Djiguiseme (Soutien Group

texts.fr:
The four women of the Djiguiseme group are married with an average age of 30 years and have three children amongst themselves. They live in polygamous families with their husbands, co-wives, and children in the village of Konobougou in the Baroueli prefecture, which is in the SÃ©gou Region of Mali. The women work in catering, but more specifically in the production of non-alcoholic beverages such as juices made from wild fruits, flavored powdered juices, etc. The members of this group are linked by ties of work relationships and personal alliances. Having trust in one another, these women decided to take out their first loan from the Soro Yiriwaso loan program. In order to keep their business stocked, they shop in the Konbougou market for raw materials such as wild fruits, powdered juice, packs of small plastic bags, dried hibiscus leaves, ginger, coloring, sugar, etc. The beverages are made (with a recognized skill), put into bags, and refrigerated before being sold at the Konobougou market, either by openly displaying the products in front of them, or by walking up to potential customers. The women each expect to make, on average, 7500 CFA (about $18) a month, which they hope to use to bolster their business.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

(RÃ©gion de SÃ©gou RÃ©publique du Mali). Elles travaillent essentiellement dans le domaine de la restauration et surtout la fabrication de boissons locales non alcoolisÃ©es (jus de fruits sauvages, jus en poudre aromatisÃ© etc ). Les membres de ce groupe sont beaucoup unis par des liens de travail et dâ€™alliances .Se faisant mutuellement confiance ces femmes ont dÃ©cidÃ© dâ€™intÃ©grer le programme crÃ©dit de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles sont Ã  leur premier prÃªt. Pour mener Ã  bien leurs activitÃ©s, elles sâ€™approvisionnent dans le marchÃ© de Konbougou en matiÃ¨res premiÃ¨res (les fruits sauvages les jus en poudre, les paquets de sachets plastiques, du dah, du zinzimbre, des colorants et du sucre, etc). Les boissons sont fabriquÃ©s (avec une technicitÃ© reconnue), mis en sachet et rafraÃ®chies avant la vente au marchÃ© de Konobougou (sur des Ã©tales ou de faÃ§on ambulante). Elles comptent rÃ©aliser un bÃ©nÃ©fice mensuel moyen de 7.500FCFAavec lequel elles envisagent dâ€™investir essentiellement dans leurs activitÃ©s.

loan.use: Purchase of raw materials for beverages

loan.name: El Renacer Group

texts.en:
Argentina C. is a 36-year-old woman who lives with her husband and four children (ages 11, 14, 17, and 18) in a small community called Quisquella Verde in the eastern province of Hato Mayor in the Dominican Republic. She began a small business selling undergarments earlier this year and continues to increase her inventory with each loan. Argentina travels by bus from town to town selling her products to people in the small communities in the countryside as many of these rural people do not have the means to travel to town to do their shopping. She has started this business so that she can provide her children with a good education and a comfortable home. In Argentinaâ€™s free time, she enjoys going to church and spending time with her family.

Argentina is the leader of the 5-person micro-bank group, Renacer. In English, this means Â´rebirth`. These unique Dominican entrepreneurs have united in solidarity, allowing them to access funding that they would never be able to receive on their own.

On behalf of Argentina, the Renacer group, and the entire team here at Esperanza International, we thank you for your support of this micro-loan!

loan.use: To buy various undergarments for re-sale

loan.name: Djiguitougou (Assurance). Group

texts.fr:
The members of the Djiguitougou group are married, with an average age of 40 years, and they have 6 children amongst themselves. They live in Fana-coura, one of the neighborhoods of the city of Fana, in the Koulikoro Region of Mali, and they have polygamous families with husbands, co-wives, and children. They make non-alcoholic beverages (fruit juices, powdered juice, juice made from dah (dried hibiscus leaves), and juice made with ginger). Due to a mutual trust for one another, and being united by work relationships and friendship, the four women of the Djiguitougou group have been in collaboration with Soro Yiriwaso for two years. The women have taken out four loans which they have repaid in full. They stock up on raw materials at the central market in Fana (wild fruits, powdered juice, packs of small plastic bags, dah (dried hibiscus leaves), ginger, colorings, and flavorings). The juices are made daily, generally at night, put into bags, and refrigerated before being sold in the morning at the market, in the schools, or at the houses of loyal and regular customers. The women expect to each make about 15,000 CFA (about $36) monthly, with which they hope to bolster their business.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

Les membres du groupe Djiguitougou sont mariÃ©s avec une moyenne dâ€™age de 40 ans 6 enfants et vivent Ã  Fana coura un des quartiers de la ville de Fana (RÃ©gion de Koulikoro RÃ©publique du Mali) dans des familles polygames avec maris, coÃ©pouses et enfants . Elles font essentiellement la fabrication de boissons locales non alcoolisÃ©es (Jus de fruits sauvages, jus en poudre, jus de dah et de zinzimbre etc). Se faisant confiance et unies par des liens de travail et dâ€™amitiÃ©, les quatre femmes du groupe Djiguitougou ont deux ans de collaboration avec Soro Yiriwaso. Elles ont bÃ©nÃ©ficiÃ© de quatre prÃªts tous remboursÃ©s. Elles sâ€™approvisionnent au grand marchÃ© de Fana en matiÃ¨res premiÃ¨res (les fruits sauvages, les jus en poudre, les paquets de sachets plastiques, le dah, le zinzimbre, les colorants et les aromes). Les jus sont fabriquÃ©s quotidiennement gÃ©nÃ©ralement le soir, mis en sachet et rÃ©frigÃ©rÃ©s avant la vente le matin au marchÃ©, dans les Ã©coles ou Ã  la maison Ã  une clientÃ¨le fidÃ¨le et rÃ©guliÃ¨re. Elles comptent rÃ©aliser chacune un bÃ©nÃ©fice mensuel moyen de 15.000FCFA avec lequel elles envisagent investir essentiellement dans leurs activitÃ©s.

loan.use: Purchase of raw materials for beverages; purchase of incense

loan.name: Adugbe

texts.en:
Adugbe A. is a fishmonger. She is a widow with 4 children. Demand for her fish is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

She is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loan.use: Additional capital to expand her business

loan.name: Vladislava

texts.en:
Vladislava is married with two children. She lives in Zaporozhye, where she sells clothing in the Yubileinyi market. She has been in this trade for ten years. Presently, she has about $3000 in inventory. Her gross income is about $1000.

Vladislava has an active entrepreneurial mind that is always looking for the next big opportunity. Her business is profitable and stable, but she would like to press on and expand it even more. Today Vladislava is requesting a loan of 4500 Grivnas to increase her clothing stock and meet the growing demands of the summer season. She is hoping to open a second vending facility in the future.

loan.use: Expand clothing business to meet summer demands

loan.name: Oksana

texts.en:
Oksana is married. She is an entrepreneur from Zaporozhye where she sells clothing in the busy Yubileinyi market. She has been in this business for 10 years. Currently, Oksana has about $2400. Her gross income is about $2400.

Oksana is requesting a 5000 Grivna loan to purchase seasonal clothing in bulk. She is achievement-oriented and has confidence in her abilities and powers. We believe these crucial characteristics that Oksana possesses will secure further growth of her trade and prompt loan repayment.

loan.use: To increase sales stock

loan.name: Doris

texts.en:
Doris A. is a seamstress who is specialized in the sewing of school uniforms. She is a single parent with 3 children. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

She is asking for additional capital to buy more fabrics for the sewing of school uniforms.

loan.use: to buy more fabrics for the sewing of school uniforms

loan.name: Foday's Group

texts.en:
This group is request a loan of Le 3,500,000.00. The members are (from right to left): Foday M., Mohamed Koroma, Abu-Bakarr J. and Alfred T..
Foday will give his loan to his wife who is sells clothes(gara lappers) so she can improve her business. Foday`s plan is to see his wife`s business booming as this (together with his monthly salary) can help them a lot in improving the living standard of their family. The two have 4 children.
Mohamed K.`s ambition is to further his education. Though currently working for the army, he will use his loan to pursue his education while still military work.
Abu-Bakarr will use his loan to buy more timber and other essential working materials he uses in making furniture to sell. Abu-Bakarr is a skilled carpenter working with the army.
33-year-old Alfred T., will buy more local produce to sell. The proceeds he gets from his sales add to his small monthly salary from the military.

loan.use: To buy cement, timber, and other working materials, and for education

loan.name: Galina

texts.en:
Galina has operated her small retail business at the busy Yubileinyi market in Zaporozhye for ten years. Zaporozhye is located in the south-east of Ukraine. She has learned a lot over the years sheâ€™s been in business. She has enjoyed the opportunity to work for herself and her income has been a big help to her. Presently, she has about $5000 in inventory.

Galina has requested a loan that will enable her to buy product in bulk to sell in her kiosk. The ability to purchase in large quantities can save a lot of time, effort and money for her as she can obtain better pricing from her suppliers and make fewer trips to buy inventory. Galina is grateful for the financial support she has received through â€œNadiya Ukraineâ€. We look forward to seeing her business continue to be successful and provide for Galinaâ€™s needs.

loan.use: To buy more products

loan.name: Natalya

texts.en:
Natalya has been running her retail business for four years. She started as a small vendor in a store called â€œKashtanâ€ (â€œChestnutâ€). The store is located in the central street of her hometown which is very convenient for customers who shop downtown Ordzhonikidze. Natalya sells household chemicals and little necessities that each family can use at home. Presently, she has about $6000 in turnover capital. Her income is about $900 each month.

Natalya would like to keep her income stable and increase her turnover capital which is why she is requesting a loan of 2500 Grivnas to be repaid in two months. We believe consistent demand, outstanding credit history and entrepreneurial enthusiasm will guarantee loan repayment without any delinquencies.

Note: this is a short term â€œseasonalâ€ loan that will be repaid in 2 months.

loan.use: To re-stock her inventory

loan.name: Alexei

texts.en:
Alexeiâ€™s family consists of his wife and four children. Nearly 2 years ago he decided to launch a small venture offering lithography and gravestone technique services--a business he says that was his calling. He was able to rent a small facility in his town which works as his shop and is easily accessible to many customers. Today, Alexeiâ€™s business yields $700 a month in income.

Alexei sees a great opportunity for business growth in the future. His expertise in this sphere of business is greatly appreciated by his customers. His desire to assist clients and his entrepreneurial spirit are part of what makes his business successful. Alexei has requested a loan for 5,000 Grivnas to broaden the assortment of equipment he uses in his work so that he will be ready for more complicated orders. He has proven to be a strong and reliable client with â€œNadiya Ukraineâ€. We believe that this loan will be a big help to Alexei as he looks for ways to increase his business activity.

loan.use: To purchase equipment

loan.name: Afi

texts.en:
Afi F. is a fishmonger. She is a single parent whose income is not sufficient for herself and her 5 children. Demand for her processed fish is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

Afi is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loan.use: Additional capital to expand her business

loan.name: Tatyana

texts.en:
Tatyana is a married mom with one daughter. She runs a small business selling leather goods in the local market of Nikolaev called "Sigma-sport". Her business doesn't face much competition as there are very few other businessmen with similar products. Tatyana started this venture about a year ago. However, she has already making about $400 in profit each month.

Tatyana is seeking a loan of 5000 Grivnas for 8 months. She is hoping to see her business grow further and expand even more. On the personal level she would like to invest a part of profits generated in remodeling of her apartment which has been her dream for awhile. Tatyana is known as an entrepreneur of integrity and determination. We believe her commitment to her venture and personal characteristics will help her repay the current loan without any problems.

loan.use: Increase working capital

loan.name: Tatyana

texts.en:
Tatyana is married with three sons. She supports the essential needs of her household by running a small business selling household items and clothing merchandise in the busy city market in Berdyansk. Currently, Tatyana has about $3000 of working capital in her business and her income amounts to $2,000.

Tatyana is very patient and polite. Her commitment to good business and her natural friendliness attract many potential clients. A variety of quality products also makes her kiosk a popular stop for passing customers. Tatyana continues to work hard investing her time and efforts in the growth of her business. She has been in this trade for 7 years and her business is continuously expanding. Tatyana is requesting a loan of 2500 Grivnas to purchase assorted merchandise at good wholesale prices. This loan will help to significantly boost Tatyana's revenue and grow her business, further improving the quality of life for her and her family.

Note: this is a short term "seasonal" loan that will be repaid in 2 months.

loan.use: To purchase assorted merchandise

loan.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria W. is a fishmonger. She is a single parent whose income is not sufficient for herself and her 2 children. Demand for her processed fish is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

Victoria is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loan.use: Additional capital to expand her business

loan.name: Natalya

texts.en:
Natalya is married with two children. Five years ago she started her retail business selling clothing and footwear in one of the local markets in Berdyansk. High sales rates, loyal customers, and a convenient location for her vending kiosk all contributed to good performance. Natalya admits lending services from "Nadiya Ukraine" have benefited her a lot in this area of business.
Today, Natalya has about $2400 of working capital. She has proven to be a hard-working, dedicated entrepreneur and runs her business with integrity and innovation. She doesn't hesitate when taking risks, which has helped her to succeed despite serious competition in the market. Natalya is requesting a loan of 2500 Grivnas to purchase merchandise at wholesale prices to sell in her vending location. This loan will help her expand her business and will have a positive impact on her trade profitability, helping to further improve the economic and social situation of her family.

loan.use: To increase inventory

loan.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice K. is a fishmonger. She is married, but her husband's income as a fisherman is not sufficient for Beatrice and her 6 children. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

Beatrice is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loan.use: Additional capital to expand her business

loan.name: Sorie's Group

texts.en:
This group consists of (from left to right): Sorie D., Abu-Bakarr K. and John Sahr F.. These men work for the military and are also engaged in either agriculture or business. They are requesting a loan of Le 2,600,000.00. This will be repaid through their monthly military salaries.
Sorie D., 33, is married with 4 children. He will use his loan to invest in business. Abu-Bakarr will invest his in agriculture. He is age 34, born in Banta-Gbenti. He is married with 2 children. And John will invest his loan in business too. He sells food stuffs and has 5 years of experience in the business. John was born in Kailahun District 32 years ago. He is married with 3 children.

loan.use: To expand existing businesses

loan.name: German

texts.es:
German lives together with his parents in â€œBrazil Streetâ€, in the neighborhood of Ballivian in the city of El Alto.

German sells spare parts; he buys cars which have had an accident, dismantles them and later on sells the spare parts at the main market of El Alto. The loan he will receive he will use it to buy more cars and sell spare parts.

It is the first loan he takes with Impro and the analysis that was done qualifies him to obtain the credit.

Translated from Spanish by Jimena Almendares Leistner, Kiva Volunteer.

German vive en la calle Brasil de la zona BalliviÃ¡n en la ciudad de El Alto. Vive en la casa de sus padres. Trabaja en la comercializaciÃ³n de chatarra, la cual consiste en la compra de vehÃ­culos siniestrados (volcados, chocados) los cuales los desmantela y los vende como repuestos en la principal feria de la ciudad de El Alto El crÃ©dito lo destinarÃ¡ como capital de trabajo, para la compra de mÃ¡s vehÃ­culos y poder vender los repuestos y partes que aÃºn estÃ¡n en estado de uso. Es el primer crÃ©dito con Impro, la evaluaciÃ³n realizada la califica para otorgarle el prÃ©stamo.

loan.use: To buy more damaged cars and sell spare parts

loan.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama F. is a fishmonger. She is married, but her husband's income as a soldier is not sufficient for Ama and her 1 child. Demand for her processed fish is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

Ama is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loan.use: Additional capital to expand her business

loan.name: Anastacia

texts.es:
Anastacia and her husband have 6 children. Love has always united them and given them strength to confront difficult moments together. As a help to support her home and supplement her husbandâ€™s income, Anastacia opened a convenience store in their home, with a little bit of merchandise to start, but is has been growing and she has noted how useful her store has been to her neighbors. Her neighbors see her as a just person, one who doesnâ€™t take advantage of the needs of others and she always charges a fair price. For this reason Anastacia has seen her work not only as an economic means but also as a service to her community. Therefore, she is here asking for a loan that will be used to expand her store, she would like to improve the lighting and buy a greater variety of merchandise to meet her customerâ€™s needs. She promises to be faithful and responsible in her payments, as she is an honored and honorable woman.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

Anastacia y su esposo tienen 6 hijos, el amor que siempre los ha unido le ha dado fuerza para afrontar juntos los momentos difÃ­ciles. Como una ayuda para el sustento de su hogar y complemento del trabajo de su esposo, Anastacia puso una bodega en su casa, con poca mercaderÃ­a para comenzar, pero ha ido creciendo la demanda y ella se ha dado cuenta lo Ãºtil que su bodega es para sus vecinos, ya que ven en ella una persona justa, que no se aprovecha de su necesidad y siempre les cobra el precio justo. Por esta razÃ³n Anastacia ha visto en su trabajo no sÃ³lo un medio de ganancia econÃ³micas, sino tambiÃ©n un servicio a favor de su comunidad.Debido a ello, se presenta aquÃ­ solicitando un prÃ©stamo que utilizarÃ¡ para la ampliaciÃ³n de su bodega, quiere ambientarla mejor y comprar mayor y variada mercaderÃ­a para seguir complaciendo a sus clientes. Ella promete ser fiel y responsable en sus pagos, ya que es una mujer honrada y honorable.

loan.use: Expand and remodel her store to better serve her neighbors

loan.name: MarÃ­a

texts.es:
MarÃ­a has been a widow for 13 years. After getting over the pain of losing her life companion, MarÃ­a gained strength and educated and took care of her children by herself. She is dedicated to working the land and after the death of her husband, she had to redouble efforts to take care of living costs. Times have changed; for MarÃ­a, who sees rising prices and costs each day, the loan that she seeks will be used to buy fertilizer for her land. She wishes that her next harvest will be more productive than the previous one, so she can make large profits in the market. She goes through lots of trouble for this endeavor.

Translated from Spanish by Geraldine Kim, Kiva Volunteer.

Hace 13 aÃ±os MarÃ­a quedÃ³ viuda, tras sobreponerse de la pena de perder a su compaÃ±ero de toda la vida, MarÃ­a sacÃ³ fuerza y sola supo educar y cuidar de sus 6 hijos. Ella se dedica a los trabajos en el campo, y tuvo que redoblar esfuerzos para suplir los gastos en su casa, luego de la muerte de su esposo, es un trabajo duro, pero tuvo que hacerlo. Los tiempos han cambiado, y tambiÃ©n para MarÃ­a que ve como los precios de lo que ella necesita a diario suben cada dÃ­a, el prÃ©stamo que solicita hoy es para la compra de abonos y fertilizantes, ella desea que su prÃ³xima cosecha sea mÃ¡s productiva que la anterior, para obtener mayores ganancias en el mercado, y eso se puede lograr con esmero.

loan.use: to buy fertilizer to cultivate her land

loan.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace O. is a fishmonger. She is married, but her husband's income as a fisherman is not sufficient for her and her 3 children. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

Grace is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loan.use: Additional capital to expand her business

loan.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary has been trading in the market for the past 10 years. She is divorced, with two children. Mary enjoys selling and she is motivated to work hard because she dreams of a better future for her children. She trades in onion, ginger, and eggs on top of a table. She would like a loan of $975 to add rice, sugar and vegetable oil to her inventory of goods to increase her income. She hopes to use part of her profits to support her children in school. Mary belongs to the community group called Living Faith Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for the repayment of each others' loans through pledge.

loan.use: To add rice, sugar ,and vegetable oil to her inventory of foodstuffs for sale at the market

loan.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca K. produces â€˜tie and dyeâ€™ fabric for sale. She is married, but her husband's income is not sufficient for Rebecca and her 1 child. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

Rebecca is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loan.use: Additional capital to expand her business

loan.name: Paul

texts.en: Paul is 29 years old and married with one child. He has supported his family as a photographer for the past 10 years. He owns a photography shop where his clients pose for their photographs. He also goes to parties and concerts to take photos of his clients. Paul would like a loan of $975 to purchase tools and materials like a camera, flash, video camera etc. to expand his business. His goal is to earn extra income and improve the welfare of his family. Paul belongs to the community group called Living Faith Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee the repayment of their loans through pledge.

loan.use: To buy tools and materials like a camera, flash, and video camera for his photography business

loan.name: Lumor

texts.en: Lumor is 36 years old and single. He has been a general photographer for 10 years and loves his work. He also does glass cutting and shoots video. Lumor owns a photography and video shop where his clients pose for their photographs. He also goes to parties and concerts to take photos of his clients. He requests a loan of $975 to buy additional tools and materials like a new camera, flash, video camera, glass, and other materials to expand his studio. Lumor belongs to the community group called Living Faith Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee the repayment of their loans through pledge.

loan.use: To buy additional cameras and materials for his photography business

loan.name: Alimamy B.'s Group

texts.en:
This group consists of: (from right to left): Alimamy B. K., Sinneh C., Alie K. and George H..
Alimamy was born in Makeni. He is now 38, married with 4 children. Alimamy is currently engaged in building a house, and will use his loan to complete the building process. Though he is an army officer, his monthly salary cannot buy him the materials he needs.
Sinneh, will use the loan to help him increase his current business. He skilfully combines his military work with petty-trading within the barracks. Sinneh is married with 2 children. He is 38 and was born in 4 Mile.
Alie was born in Mile 91. He is 34, married with 3 children. He will give his loan to his wife who sells a variety of items like pastes, bars of soap, cigarettes, matches etc. This will help her expand her business.
George H., 34, will use his loan to develop his farm.
These soldiers are requesting a loan of Le 3,500,000.00 in total. The loan will be repaid out of their monthly military salaries.

loan.use: To buy building materials.

loan.name: Bismarck

texts.en: Bismarck is 33 years old, married, and has one child. He has been a dealer in used refrigerators and parts for the past 10 years. He also repairs refrigerators for his customers. Bismark buys supplies from importers at wholesale prices and sells them to his customers at retail prices. Used refrigerators are in high demand for those who cannot afford to buy a new one. Bismark requests a loan of $975 so he can purchase additional refrigerators and parts. He belongs to the community group called Evergreen Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee the repayment of their loans through pledge.

loan.use: To procure additional refrigerators and parts

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Sinapi Aba Trust (SAT) - Oct 26, 2008)

loan.name: Djiguiya (Espoir Group

texts.fr:
The members of the Djiguiya group are married with an average age of 37 and seven children. They live in traditional families with their husbands, parents-in-law and children in the village of Konobougou in the Baroueli prefecture, located in Maliâ€™s SÃ©gou region. They specialize in selling food spices and traditional utensils for cooking, etc. The relationship among the women of the Djiguiya group is one of neighborhood bonds and friendship. They are on their third solidarity loan from Soro Yiriwaso and all previous loans were repaid without problem. They get their supplies from a variety of sources depending on the item, but for utensils, they mainly buy their stock from local people in the surrounding villages. For food spices, they go to Bamako or SÃ©gou. Sales take place in Konobougou, either at home or in the market, especially on market days when customers are itinerant merchants from neighboring towns and villages. With this loan, the members of the Djiguiya group expect to make a monthly profit of CFA 20,000, which they will use to pay the loan interest and invest the remainder in their respective businesses.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer.

Les membres du groupe Djiguiya sont mariÃ©s avec une moyenne dâ€™age de 37 ans et 7 enfants. Elles vivent dans des familles traditionnelles avec leurs maris, les beaux parents et les enfants dans le village de Konobougou prÃ©fecture de Baroueli (RÃ©gion de SÃ©gou RÃ©publique du Mali). Elles se sont spÃ©cialisÃ©es dans le commerce de condiments alimentaires et des ustensiles traditionnels de cuisine etc. Les femmes du groupe Djiguiya ont une relation de voisinage dâ€™alliances et dâ€™amitiÃ©. Elles sont Ã  leur troisiÃ¨me prÃªt solidaire avec Soro Yiriwaso et les prÃ©cÃ©dents ont Ã©tÃ© remboursÃ©s sans difficultÃ©. Les sources dâ€™approvisionnement sont diverses et variÃ©es suivant les articles mais pour les ustensiles câ€™est essentiellement dans les villages environnants avec les paysans quâ€™elles se ravitaillent. Pour les condiments alimentaires, elles le font Ã  Bamako ou Ã  SÃ©gou. Les ventes se font sur place Ã  Konobougou Ã  domicile ou au marchÃ© surtout les jours de foire Ã  une clientÃ¨le composÃ©e de forains venant des villes et villages voisins. Avec ce prÃªt les membres du groupe Djiguiya comptent rÃ©aliser un bÃ©nÃ©fice moyen mensuel de 20.000 FCFA quâ€™elles utiliseront pour payer les intÃ©rÃªts du prÃªt et investir le reste dans leurs activitÃ©s respectives.

loan.use: To buy utensils and miscellaneous items

loan.name: Mujeres Decidida De Restauracion Group

texts.en: Maria M. is the leader of her Bank of Hope, Mujeres Decidida D. Restauracion ("Women Determined for Restoration"). She is the mother of four, aged 24, 26, 28, and 30, and has used her Esperanza loan to start her craft-selling business. Her future ambitions incluD. expanding her business and providing a comfortable life for her grandchildren.

loan.use: Manualidades Nazareno (Christian crafts)

loan.name: Efua

texts.en:
Efua M. sells oil, tomatoes, pepper, and other food items. She is married, but her husband's income as a fisherman is not sufficient for Efua and her 5 children. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

Efua is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loan.use: Additional capital to expand her business

loan.name: Djiguiseme 2 (Soutien Group

texts.fr:
The women in the Djiguiseme group are mostly married with an average age of 30 and four children each. They live in traditional families with their husbands, co-wives and children in the village of Konobougou in the Baroueli prefecture (in Maliâ€™s SÃ©gou region). They run a business mainly selling food spices and traditional beauty products (incense, etc.). Brought together through neighborhood ties and friendship, they have been working with Soro Yiriwaso for one year and are on their third group loan. All previous loans were repaid without problem. They stock up on raw materials in Konobougou on market days, buying spices from wholesalers from SÃ©gou and incense primarily from wholesalers from Bamako. They sell at the same market in Konobougou, either at stalls or by walking around, and do this throughout the year. Their customers are women who sell to neighboring villages or women from Konobougou. The group plans to buy 15 kg of spices (pepper, abutilon, laurel, etc.) at CFA 2,000/kg to sell at CFA 2,500/kg, hence a weekly profit of CFA 7,500, and incense ingredients (2 kg of magnonkisÃ¨ni, 5 kg of gueni, and 4 bottles of perfume) at a cost of CFA 25,000, which would yield a profit of CFA 30,000 per month. Each member of the group hopes to make a monthly profit of CFA 30,000 with which they will pay the loan interest and increase their capital.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer.

loan.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth M. is a fishmonger. She is married, but her husband's income is not sufficient for Elizabeth and her 3 children. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

Elizabth is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loan.use: Additional capital to expand her business

loan.name: Mukarwego's Group

texts.en:
Mukarwego B. was born in 1968 in Kimisagara. She is a married woman with seven children and two orphans under her charge. She sells crops. She began her business in 1999 with 5000RWF as capital. She currently has a capital of 200,000RWF. She has seven children in secondary school and pays for the school fees from income generated by her business. She has also been able to build their own shelter.
She is requesting a loan to increase her business and expects to extend it by selling honey from Umutara producers.

loan.use: Increase and extend her business by adding honey

loan.name: VÃ­ctor

texts.es:
Victor is 43 years old and he is married. His wife, Natividad, is a very hardworking and understanding woman. Together, hand in hand, they sustain their household and pay for the education of their children.

Victor works in public transportation. Where he lives the three-wheeler light vans are often used for public transportation and that is why he decided to buy one and become a driver. Time has passed by and Victor would like to try other activities, one day he would like to open a small workshop to repair motorcycles.

He now requests a loan to buy another three-wheeler light van to provide work to a young man who works with him as a driver and he will keep on driving the three-wheeler he already owns. Victor wants to ask you to trust in him, he believes that he is a hard working and honest person. He gives his word that he will pay back the money within the agreed loan term.

Translated from Spanish by Jimena Almendares Leistner, Kiva Volunteer.

VÃ­ctor tiene 43 aÃ±os, es casado, su esposa, Natividad es una mujer muy compresiva y trabajadora con la que mano a mano y diariamente soportan la educaciÃ³n de sus hijos y el sustento de su hogar.

El trabajo de VÃ­ctor es el transporte de pasajeros, en la zona donde Ã©l vive es muy usado el motocarro para el traslado urbano, y Ã©l optÃ³ por comprarse uno y ser Ã©l mismo el chofer. Ha pasado el tiempo y VÃ­ctor quiere optar por otras actividades a la par del transporte, Ã©l desea poner un pequeÃ±o puesto de venta de repuestos para moto.

Ã‰l solicita un prÃ©stamo para adquirir otro motocarro, y darle trabajo a un muchacho trabajador como chofer, mientras Ã©l sigue manejando el otro motocarro. VÃ­ctor quiere pedirles que confÃ­en en Ã©l, ya que Ã©l considera que es una persona trabajadora y honrada, da su palabra de devolver el dinero en el plazo mencionado.

loan.use: To buy another three-wheeler light van to provide work to a young man who works with him as a driver

loan.name: Jackeline

texts.es:
Jackeline is 20 years old and dedicates herself to selling clothes. When she started this job it was like a hobby for her, but now that she is growing and maturing, she has realized that this is a job which has brought her a lot of money, and which has taught her the value of work. She knows that with her young age, she can work even harder to become a prosperous businesswoman in the near future. With the help of some relatives who live in the capital city of Lima, Jackeline continues to acquire very high quality items in all styles and for all ages. Thank God she has the unconditional support of her parents, who encourage her every day to continue with her business for them and for her future. Jacklen has decided to ask you for the amount of money she is asking to borrow, so that she can rent a small place to sell her goods, also allowing her to get more merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Zach Frey, Kiva volunteer.

Jackeline tiene 20 aÃ±os, y se dedica a la venta de ropa, cuando ella iniciÃ³ este oficio era como un pasatiempo para ella, pero ahora que va creciendo y madurando se ha dado cuenta que es un negocia que la ha traÃ­do muchas ganancias y le ha enseÃ±ado el valor del trabajo, sabe que con su juventud puede esforzarse aÃºn mÃ¡s para ser una prÃ³spera empresaria en un futuro cercano.Con la ayuda de unos familiares que viven en Lima, la capital, Jackeline consigue adquirir prendas de muy buena calidad y de variados modelos para todas las edades. Gracias a Dios, ella cuanta con el apoyo incondicional de sus padres, quienes le incentivan a seguir con su trabajo cada dÃ­a, por ellos y por su futuro, Jackeline decidiÃ³ recurrir a ustedes para que tengan a bien proporcionarle la cantidad de dinero que pide, en prÃ©stamo, para alquilar un pequeÃ±o local donde vender sus prendas y asÃ­ poder adquirir mayor mercaderÃ­a.

loan.use: Renting a place to sell her clothes.

loan.name: Djiguiya 2 (Soutien) Group

texts.fr:
The members of the Djiguiya 2 group are married. Their average age is 30 and they have, on average, 6 children. They live in Sikouna 2, one of the villages of the Fana Sous-prefecture, Republic of Mali, in polygamous families with their husbands, co-spouses, parents-in-law, brothers, sisters, and children.

They are essentially engaged in selling grocery items: bags of powdered milk, packets of pasta, dried and smoked fish, sugar, salt, soap, etc. With confidence in each other and united by ties of work and friendship, these women have decided to collaborate with the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso this year. This is their first loan as a group. They generally procure their merchandise in the big open-air market in Fana or at the Marka Coungo fair, their economic metropolis for the aforementioned items.

They sell on a cash or credit basis, generally retail, at the same fair, under shed roofs, on tables, often even on the ground, or as ambulant salespeople going to village houses. Their clientele is essentially composed of women, children and male heads of families wanting to vary their meals.

With this loan, the women of Djiguiya will purchase 50 packets of pasta, 10 kg of fish, 20 bags of powdered milk, 10 kg of sugar, packets of tea, etc., that is, they will spend 50,000 FCFA, hoping to make a monthly average profit of 15,000 FCFA with which they plan to make payments on the loan, re-invest in their businesses, and contribute to family living expenses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Elles effectuent leurs ventes au comptant Ã  crÃ©dit gÃ©nÃ©ralement en dÃ©tail dans la mÃªme foire sous des hangars sur des Ã©tales souvent a mÃªme le sol, dâ€™une faÃ§on ambulante devant dans les maisons aux villages .La clientÃ¨le est essentiellement composÃ©e de femmes dâ€™enfants et de pÃ¨res de famille dÃ©sirant changer de repas

loan.name: Edgar

texts.es:
Edgar is 40 years old with three children. Because of irreparable differences, he had to end his marriage and move away from his children, but although he doesnâ€™t live with them, he continues to dedicate his efforts to their future. Without doubt he tells them to be good and responsible every time they are near him. Years ago, Edgar started his work as a motorcycle taxi driver, and today after a lot of work, he is the proud owner of his own motorcycle taxi. At the same time, he dedicates himself to raising corn, yucca, and bananas, products which he takes to sell at the market in his area. Edgarâ€™s vehicle has presented mechanical faults and the loan which he is asking you for is to buy the parts and pay the mechanic in charge of the repairs. This father needs your support to continue in his daily work, which is his sustenance.

Translated from Spanish by Zach Frey, Kiva volunteer.

Edgar tiene 40 aÃ±os y 3 hijos, por diferencias irreparables tuvo que separarse de su pareja y alejarse de sus hijos, pero a pesar que no vive con ellos, Ã©l sigue dedicando su esfuerzo para el futuro de ellos, no duda en aconsejarles, cada vez que los tiene cerca, que sean buenos y responsables.AÃ±os atrÃ¡s el seÃ±or Edgar empezÃ³ su trabajo como chofer de motocarro para el trasporte de pasajeros, hoy despuÃ©s de mucho es fuerzo ya es propietario de su propio motocarro y se dedica paralelamente al cultivo de maÃ­z, yuca y plÃ¡tano principalmente, productos que lleva a vender al mercado de su zona.El vehÃ­culo de Edgar ha presentado fallas mecÃ¡nicas y el prÃ©stamo que Ã©l les pide es para la compra de repuestos y el pago al mecÃ¡nico que se encargarÃ¡ de la compostura. Este padre, necesita de tu apoyo para continuar en su diaria labor, cual es su sustento.

loan.use: Purchase of parts and payment for the repairs of his motorcycle taxi.

loan.name: Eloy

texts.es:
Eloy started working as a motorcycle taxi driver at a very early age. When he saw the needs of his parents and siblings, he knew that he could help with his strength and his work. After all these years, heâ€™s now 27, and he has become one of the main supporters of his family now that his parents are losing their strength and cannot work as hard as they used to. Because of this, Eloy knows that the fruits of his labor are not only for him to spend, but also for his parentsâ€™ retirement. He is also single and hopes with his heart to keep working so that he can support what will eventually be his own family. Because of his starting as a driver, he now has his own motorcycle taxi, which is the reason he is asking for this loan, to repair the mechanical faults of his vehicle and continue with his work.

Translated from Spanish by Zach Frey, Kiva volunteer.

Eloy empezÃ³ a trabajar desde muy temprana edad, como chofer de motocarro, al ver la necesidad de sus padres y hermanos, supo que Ã©l podÃ­a ayudar con su trabajo y esfuerzo. Luego de tantos aÃ±os, Ã©l tiene ya 27, se ha convertido en uno de los sustentos primordiales de su casa, ya que la fuerza de sus padres se van desvaneciendo y no pueden dedicarse al trabajo con tanta fuerza como lo hacÃ­an antes, por ello Eloy sabe que las ganancias de su trabajo no son sÃ³lo para sus gastos personales, sino tambiÃ©n para la vejez de sus padres. loan.name: Hannah

texts.en:
Hannah M. buys fish in large quantities for sale in smaller and affordable quantities. She is married, but her husband's income as a fisherman is not sufficient for Hannah and her 3 children. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

Hannah is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loan.use: Additional capital to expand her business

loan.name: Hugo

texts.es:
Hugo became independent at 20 years old and his energy and enthusiasm led him to work as a mototaxi driver. Now, 9 years later, Hugo is the owner of his own vehicle which he cares for and personally drives. This young man would like to rent a space where he could sell spare parts and lubricants for mototaxis, and he has been saving his money for this. Unfortunately his mototaxi has been having problems and Hugo would like you to help him obtain the loan that he is requesting in order to repair the mototaxi. He does not want to fall behind on his goal of having his own lube center. For now he depends on your support to continue his efforts.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Westin, Kiva volunteer.

Hugo se independizÃ³ a los 20 aÃ±os, su Ã­mpetu y entusiasmo lo llevÃ³ empezar a trabajar como chofer de un motocarro, hoy luego de 9 aÃ±os, Hugo ya es dueÃ±o de su propio vehÃ­culo que cuida y maneja personalmente, el deseo de este joven es alquilar un local donde pueda vender repuestos y lubricantes para motos, y es por ello que ahorra diariamente. Lamentablemente su motocarro estÃ¡ sufriendo desperfectos y Hugo desea que le puedan brindar el prÃ©stamo que solicita para poder arreglarlo, Ã©l no quiere retroceder con su meta de tener su lubricentro, y por ahora depende de tu apoyo para continuar en su esfuerzo.

loan.use: Repair his mototaxi

loan.name: Faida (Finesse) Group

texts.fr:
The women of the Faida group, on average 25 years old with 5 children, live in extended traditional families with their husbands and children in the village of Konobougou, Baroueli Prefecture, (Region of SÃ©gou, Republic of Mali).

The group sells diverse items: cosmetics, clothing and especially condiments (smoked fish, dried fish, spices, etc.).

They are essentially linked by professional and neighborhood ties, and by ties of friendship.

Group solidarity being strong, the members of Faida group have decided to continue with Soro Yiriwaso which has given them three group loans so far. The previous loans have all been reimbursed correctly.

The group generally stocks up at the end of the month, buying from wholesalers in the big open-air market in Bamako as far as clothing and cosmetics are concerned, getting their fish in SÃ©gou and spices in their own village of Konobougou. They sell their products either out of their homes or at the open-air market, or as ambulant salespeople. The group generally sells on credit to salaried purchasers but also for cash and retail at the market.

The members of Faida group hope that with 30 kg of smoked fish (bought at 1500 FCFA per kilo and sold on credit at 2500 FCFA per kilo) they will make an average monthly profit of 30,000 FCFA which will essentially be re-invested in their businesses.

Elizabeth E. is a fishmonger. She is married, but her husband's income as a fisherman is not sufficient for Elizabeth and her 5 children. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

Elizabeth is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

Matilda is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

John is asking for additional capital to expand his business.
