texts.fr:
Mrs Anna K. is married and the mother of five children. She is requesting a loan to set up a business selling womenâ€™s clothing, watches and chains in order to help improve the living conditions and health of her family. She will repay the loan after six months in a single installment. Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer.
La dame Anna K. est mariÃ©e et mÃ¨re de 05 enfants. Elle va rembourser au bout de six mois en une seule Ã©chÃ©ance.

loan.name: Murorunkwere

texts.en:
Murorunkwere S. Emerthe was born in 1963 and lives in Kimisagara. Murorunkwere was married in 1993, but her husband was killed one year later. She has three children and is in charge of two orphans. She began her business in 1996 taking a small amount of money from Nyarugenge money lenders (20,000RWF). She started selling crops. At the end of 1997, she had saved 450,000RWF. She started a new business going to Kampala to buy clothes and selling them in a small shop. She has been able to build a house with value of five million RWF.
She is requesting a loan of 500,890 RWF to increase her capital and expects to go to Dar-es-Salaam to purchase additional stock.

loan.use: Increase business capital

loan.name: Heremakono (Attente Du Bonheur) Group

texts.fr:
The members of the Heremakono group are married women whose average age is 30 and who have, on average, 6 children each. They live in polygamous families with their husbands and children in the village of Sikouna 1, Fana Sous-Prefecture (Koulikoro region, Republic of Mali).

The principle business of this group of women is selling firewood, charcoal, and pottery. They have a place to store their wares in the country and near their concessions. The charcoal and firewood are bought from farmers who are licensed to participate in this business. They generally retail the charcoal in small quantities on a cash basis to a clientele made up essentially of women and sell it wholesale to foragers who come from the bigger cities such as SÃ©gou and Bamako. Handicrafts, made by the women themselves, consisting of pots, â€œcanarisâ€ (earthenware jars for water), jars, incense burners, etc., are purchased in quantity in the village by wholesalers who come from the city.

United by professional and neighborhood ties, the members of the group are requesting their first group loan with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. They plan to buy 25 sacks of charcoal (at 1000 FCFA, resold at 1500 FCFA) and thus make a monthly average profit of 12,500 FCFA which will go toward repayment of the loan and to bolster their businesses.

Please note that Malado K. is absent from the group photo because she was seeing a doctor at the Marka coungo infirmary.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Unies par des liens professionnels et de voisinage les membres du groupe sont Ã  leur premier prÃªt solidaire avec lâ€™institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso. Il est Ã  noter que la nommÃ©e MALADO K. Ã©tait allÃ© pour consultation au centre de santÃ© de Marka coungo, elle est absente de la photo de groupe.

loan.name: Margarita Lisseth

texts.es:
Margarita is 26 years old and lives in the â€œHialeah II Etapaâ€ neighborhood. She is single and has no children.

Margarita works as a cashier at a bank in the city of Managua and at nights she goes to the university. She has been working as a cashier for a year.

Margaritaâ€™s house is half in concrete and the other half in zinc. That is why she requests a loan so that she can change all the zinc walls into concrete. She will do the changes little by little with the financing she will receive.

Margarita would like to have a better standard of living so that when she has a family, she can give her children the comforts they need.

Translated from Spanish by Jimena Almendares Leistner, Kiva Volunteer.

loan.name: Egya

texts.en:
Egya E. sells fish and owns a canoe. He is married, but his wife's income as a fishmonger is not sufficient for Egya and his 3 children. Demand for his goods is high, and he is looking to expand his business to increase his profits.

He is asking for additional capital to expand his business.

loan.name: Silvia Elena

texts.es:
Mrs. Silvia is 57 years old and sells fruits and Nacatamales (local tamales served as breakfast on Sundays or lunch during the week) on Saturdays and Sundays. she is married and her 4 children are adults and live outside the home. 15 years ago, Mrs. Silvia started her business selling nacatamales, but over time was able to extend to the sale of fruits from her home.

Mrs. Silvia's husband is an electrician, but is currently unemployed, a situation that has brought Silvia to search for other sources of income. As a result she is requesting a loan in order to be able to purchase construction materials to make a small room in her house that she can rent and be able to count on other income the will permit her family to live comfortably and stably.

Translated from Spanish to English by Laura Jung, Kiva Volunteer

Hace 15 aÃ±os DoÃ±a Silvia empezÃ³ el negocio de las ventas de nacatamales pero con el tiempo pudo extenderse tambiÃ©n a la venta de frutas en su casa de habitaciÃ³n. El esposo de DoÃ±a Silvia es electricista pero en estos momentos se encuentra desempleado, situaciÃ³n que lleva a DoÃ±a Silvia a buscar otras fuentes de ingresos, es por eso que solicita el crÃ©dito, para la compra de materiales de construcciÃ³n para hacer un pequeÃ±o cuarto en su vivienda, y asÃ­ ponerlo de alquiler y poder contar con otros ingresos que le permitan a esta familia una condiciÃ³n de vida estable.

loan.use: Construction of a bedroom.

loan.name: Khady

texts.fr:
Khady D. is married and has been a member of the Boucotte village bank for six years. She is requesting this loan to strengthen her business so that she can better satisfy her customers. She will therefore continue to sell palm oil, dried fish and honey. She plans to repay the loan after six months in a single installment.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer.

loan.use: To strengthen her business of selling dried fish, palm oil and honey

loan.name: Aba

texts.en:
Aba G. is a fishmonger. She is married, but her husband's income as a fisherman is not sufficient for Aba and her 3 children. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

Aba is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loan.use: Additional capital to expand her business

loan.name: Fatou

texts.fr: Fatou S. is married and has seven children in her care. She is requesting this loan to strengthen her business which consists of buying and selling vegetables and fabrics dyed with indigo using a resist-dye technique found in Senegal called "thioup.â€ She wants to use this loan to improve the health and living conditions of her family. This loan will be repaid in a single installment at the end of six months. Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer. Fatou S. est mariÃ©e et a 07 enfants Ã charge. Ce prÃªt sera remboursÃ© en une seule Ã©chÃ©ance au bout de six mois.

loan.name: Charlotte

texts.fr:
Born on August 12, 1977 in ZinviÃ©, in Atlantique County, Ms. Charlotte O. is originally from SakÃ©tÃ©, in OuÃ©mÃ© County. She is married and the mother of two. Her husband Germain ADEYE is a tailor-embroiderer by profession. She is improving in the sale of various goods, such as: sandalettes (flip-flop sandals), plates, drinking glasses, kitchen utensils, etc. She has been in sales and distribution for almost seven years and stocks up at the international marketplace of Cotonou. She is on her fifth loan. After the distribution of her different articles, she sees her customers to collect payment. Her plan is to get settled in a shop in order to limit trips to her customers.

loan.name: Honronya (Lâ€™IndÃ©pendance) Group

texts.fr:
The members of Honronya group are on average 25 years old and have an average of 4 children each. They live in extended traditional families with their husbands and children in the village of Sikouna 1, Fana Sous-Prefecture, (Koulikoro Region, Republic of Mali).

The group sells various items: charcoal and especially condiments (smoked fish, dried fish, spices, salt, etc.)

They are linked to each other by ties of profession, neighborhood, and friendship.

Their solidarity being firmly established, the members of Honronya have decided to work with Soro Yiriwaso, which has just approved their first group loan. Their purchasing is done via wholesalers coming from Bamako, generally on market days as far as the condiments are concerned, and, as for charcoal, in surrounding villages. They sell their merchandise either out of their homes, or at the market, or as ambulant salespeople. Their sales are generally made retail on a cash basis, especially at the market, and on credit to neighbors in the village.

The members of the Honronya group, by buying with this loan 10 sacks of charcoal, 5 kg of smoked fish, 10 kg of dried fish, and big quantities of spices, expect to make an average monthly profit of 7500 FCFA which will be mostly reinvested in their businesses.

In future, these women of the Honronya group hope to become wholesalers.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

loan.name: Bladimir

texts.es:
Bladimir is 34 years old, married, and has 2 children, ages 16 and 3. His wife works at home, taking care of the children. Bladimir is employed as an external auditor, apart from which he owns a general store and some billiard tables which he rents out. He has 8 years experience in his business and started by selling candies and cleaning supplies. However, through loans he was able to obtain billiard tables to rent.

His plans for his business are to be able to increase the physical size of his business in order for their employees to be more comfortable and more independent of one another. While he is working (as an Auditor) his mother manages the store and the billiard tables. Some of the most demanded products for the store are basic grains and milk products, and with the loan that you grant him he will buy these products and also purchase more cleaning supplies.

Translated from Spanish to English by Laura Jung, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Purchase of basic grains, milk products, and cleaning products.

loan.name: Yazmin Arely

texts.es:
YazmÃ­n started her business because she liked working and having her own money to buy herself things as well as contributing to the household expenses to relieve some of the burden from her husband. She began her business selling tamales more than 2 years ago and initially only sold to close family. Gradually, she sold to more people, usually working on request so that her tamales didnâ€™t sit unsold and so that she didnâ€™t end up with a bad investment that could be very difficult to recover later.

She needs a $300 loan, which she will repay in six months, to purchase ingredients and put out requests for events and ultimately provide her customers with good service.

Translated from Spanish by Amani Roland, Kiva volunteer.

YazmÃ­n iniciÃ³ el negocio porque le gusta trabajar y tener su propio dinero para comprarme sus cosas, ademÃ¡s de que tambiÃ©n coopera con los gastos de la casa para que a su esposo no se le haga pesado. ComenzÃ³ su negocio de venta de tamales hace mas de dos aÃ±os y en un inicio solo vendÃ­a a sus familiares cercanos, pero poco a poco fue vendiendo a mas personas, por lo general trabaja sobre pedido para que no se queden sin vender y que no resulte una mala inversiÃ³n porque despuÃ©s es muy difÃ­cil recuperar.

Ella necesita un prÃ©stamo por US $300 que pagara en 6 meses el cual le servirÃ¡ para comprar materia prima y poder sacar varios pedidos para eventos y hay que darles un buen servicio a sus clientes.

loan.use: To purchase ingredients.

loan.name: Mukawera

texts.en:
Mukawera J. was born in 1961. She lives in Gatsata. She has been a widow since 1994 when her husband died during the genocide. They had four children when her husband died. After the genocide, she took another three orphans under her charge. Currently, one child is in secondary school while the others are in primary school. In 1996, with 20,000 RWF as capital, she began selling dresses second-hand in the local market. At the end of the year, she had 80,000 RWF as capital.

She came to VFC requesting a loan in order to increase her capital and diversify the goods she sells. She wants a loan to begin a new kind of business selling tires.

loan.use: Increase her business capital

loan.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria is 57 years old, and married with one child, who has completed school and is working. She trades in curtain and suiting materials, upholsteries, flowers, perfumes, jewelry, and other items in the town of Koforidua. Due to low working capital, she sometimes buys her supplies on credit and repays the cost at high interest after sales. She wants to use the loan of $975 to purchase bulk quantities of curtain and suiting fabric, upholstery material, flowers, perfumes, jewelry etc. to enable her reduce the cost of sales and increase her income. She hopes to use part of her profit to acquire decent shelter for her family in future. She is a member of the community group called Evergreen Trust Group. The group guarantees a loan through repayment pledge.

loan.use: To purchase bulk curtain and suiting fabric, upholstery material, flowers, perfumes and other goods

loan.name: Kelenya (Lâ€™UnitÃ©) Group

texts.fr:
The members of the Kelenya group, 20 years old and with 4 children on average, live in extended traditional families with their husbands, co-spouses, and children in the village of Sikouna 1, Sub-Prefecture Fana (Koulikoro Region, Republic of Mali).

The members of the group sell various items: condiments (smoked fish, dried fish, fresh tomatoes, etc.), fresh cowâ€™s milk, cosmetics, fruit and vegetables, etc.

They are bound together essentially by profession, neighborhood, friendship, or are related to each other.

Their firm solidarity has motivated the members of Kelenya to become part of the lending program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso which has just approved their first group loan. The members of the group do their purchasing exclusively from wholesalers who come from populous areas such as Bamako, SÃ©gou, and Fana once a week to the market fair at Marka coungo. They sell their wares either at home (in the village) or in the market in stalls, or as ambulant salespeople. Their sales are generally retail on a cash basis and also on credit.

The members of Kelenya group intend to buy 5 kg of fish, 5 kg of spices, 2 baskets of fresh tomatoes, 3 baskets of fruit and vegetables. They hope to use this loan to make a monthly average profit of 7500 FCFA, which will essentially be reinvested in their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

loan.name: Paul

texts.en: Paul is 30 years old and has two children. He owns a boutique and sells women's clothing, shoes, and accessories. He has been in business for the past 4 years. Paul has observed that selling women's clothing is a better business than selling men's clothes, because men hardly ever buy new clothes. Paul would like a loan of $975 to help him meet his customers' demand for quality clothes, bags and shoes. He believes that with the loan he will be able to improve the quality and stock of inventory in his shop. He belongs to the community group called Adonai Trust Group. Peer pressure and support provide the incentive to repay the loan.

loan.use: To buy increased stock of ladies' clothing, slippers, and purses

loan.name: Victoire

texts.fr:
Originally from SakÃ©tÃ© in the OuÃ©mÃ© department, Mrs. Victoire A. was born on 1st September 1967. She is married and has 4 children, all adults. She does not live with her husband. Having settled and survived by herself for a decade, she is very dynamic and organized in her work. She owns her own shop situated in Agongbomey, where she sells various convenience goods. She travels to neighbouring Nigeria herself to make her purchases.She is asking for her very first loan, and would like to have a larger shop in order to enlarge her business.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loan.name: Diana

texts.en: Diana is 42 years old. She is a wife and mother of two children. Dianna is a resourceful, hardworking mother and a successful business woman. One of her children is currently in school. She trades in women's shoes and slippers, children's shoes, and sachet water in the Koforidua market. Diana has inadequate working capital to grow her business but she believes that with the loan, she will be able to provide her customers with higher-quality shoes and slippers, and buy more goods to sell at the market. She hopes to raise good income to support her family. She belongs to the community group called â€˜Nyame mmereâ€™ (meaning, Godâ€™s time) Trust Group. In this group, members agree to guarantee each other as social collateral to repay the loans.

loan.use: To buy more ladies' slippers and shoes, children's shoes, and other items for resale

loan.name: Konotieyele (La LumiÃ¨re De Lâ€™Oiseau Male) Group

texts.fr:
The members of the Konotieyele group are married women, aged 38 and with 7 children on average. They live in polygamous families with their husbands and children in the village of Konobougou, Sub-Prefecture of Baroueli (SÃ©gou Region, Republic of Mali).

The principal business activity of these women of the Konotieyele group (so named in memory of the founder of the village: male bird Diarra) is the sale of firewood and charcoal which they buy from farmers (supplying the village of Konobougou) who have a permit to cut wood. They have storerooms in their husbandsâ€™ compounds and generally sell charcoal retail to a local clientele (women, men) and wholesale to buyers who come out to the country from the big towns like SÃ©gou and Bamako.

United by ties of profession and neighborhood and very active in economic activities, the members of the group are requesting their third group loan with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, having repaid prior loans correctly. With this loan they intend to buy 80 sacks of charcoal and 5 loads of firewood and hope to make an average monthly profit of 35000 FCFA which will be used to make repayments on the loan, to pay for family necessities, and above all bolster their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

loan.name: San Juana

texts.es:
San Juana started her business to help her husband with the household expenses and to have an activity that would keep her busy, but also allow her to care for her children and maintain her house. She began her grocery store with her motherâ€™s help since she was unable to work and she didnâ€™t have anyone to care for her children for about three years. She hopes to succeed and put a lot of effort into her business to provide her customers with good service and earn good profits.

She needs a $200 loan, which she will repay in six months, to restock her merchandise and to buy new products for the store that customers have been requesting. With your help, San Juana will succeed.

Translated from Spanish by Amani Roland, Kiva volunteer.

San Juana iniciÃ³ el negocio por la necesidad de ayudar a su esposo con los gastos de la casa y de la familia y tener alguna actividad para mantenerse ocupada y al mismo tiempo cuidar a sus hijos y realizar las actividades de la casa. ComenzÃ³ su tienda de abarrotes con la ayuda de su mama debido a que ella ya no pudo trabajar porque tuvo hijos y no tenia quien se los cuidara hace aproximadamente 3 aÃ±os. Ella desea salir adelante y echarle muchas ganas al negocio para dar un buen servicio al cliente y asÃ­ mismo para obtener buenas ganancias.

loan.use: To purchase merchandise and restock grocery store.

loan.name: Laidou (Promesse) Group

texts.fr:
The members of the Laidou group are married. Their average age is 22; they have, on average, 3 children and live in traditional families with their spouses, co-spouses, and children in the village of Konobougou, Prefecture of Baroueli (SÃ©gou Region, Republic of Mali).

They sell various small items (cosmetics, condiments, clothing, sugar, tea, cigarettes, etc.)

The women of Laidou group do their purchasing essentially on market fair days in Konobougou from wholesalers who are specialized in the items mentioned above. They generally sell retail on a cash basis at established market stalls or as ambulant salespeople in the village. Their clientele is mostly female with a few males.

The group is presently on its third loan with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, and all the preceding loans were reimbursed in a timely manner.

They want to use this loan to buy: 5 cartons of cigarettes, 1 small case of tubes of skin crÃ¨me, 5 kg of fish, 10 pants, shirts or dresses for children, and a large quantity of condiments.

With this loan they hope to make a weekly average profit of 2500 FCFA, i.e., monthly 10,000 FCFA per member.

Each of them hopes to open a little shop and specialize in one item.

She has been selling a paste, known as "kom" in AgbodjÃ¨do, for more than two years, and other food goods. This paste, made from a maize base, is accompanied by a spicy fish sauce. This paste is highly prized by the residents of Cotonou, especially those who are of "Guin" ethnicity. She is asking for this loan to stop having to buy maize at retail, so as to increase her profits.

loan.name: Laidou 2 (Promesse) Group

texts.fr:
The members of this Laidou group are all married. On average, they are 36 years old and have 5 children. They live in traditional families with their husbands, co-spouses, and children in Fana coura, a neighborhood in the sub-prefecture of the same name (Koulikoro Region, Republic of Mali).

The Laidou group sells decorative rugs, carpeting, womenâ€™s clothing, cosmetics, and a number of other articles for women.

As the members of this group are related to each other or bound by ties of friendship, they have confidence in each other and continue to borrow as a group through Soro Yiriwaso.

They are on their fourth group loan and have not missed a payment. Whereas the rugs and carpets are purchased from the Islamic Republic of Mauritania, the lengths of African print cloth and such come from Bamako, capital of the Republic of Mali. The sale of these articles is essentially on credit, payable weekly or monthly. The clientele is mostly made up of women and workers.

With this loan they intend to buy 6 carpets at 15,000 FCFA each to resell for 22,500 FCFA and Dutch â€œwaxâ€ print cloth at 4000 FCFA sold for 5500 FCFA.

They expect to make a monthly profit of 30,000 FCFA with which they will make payments on the loan and bolster their businesses.

The members of the group hope to organize themselves and protect their interests by becoming an legal, registered company.

loan.name: Darlin Del Socorro

texts.es:
In the town of Nagarote, which is part of the city of LeÃ³n, Darlin M. works very hard in her home business of raising pigs. She has been working at this for the past three years and she does it in order to maintain her humble one-room house.

Darlin is seeking support from Ceprodel, with the goal of obtaining credit with which to purchase pigs. It is for this reason that she has turned to the institution hoping that her loan will be approved. That way she will be able to keep up with the maintenance of her home. She has had three loans and paid them all back on time, according to the policies of the institution.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

loan.name: Karla Susana

texts.es:
Karla decided to sell shoes through a catalog in order to earn some extra income in addition to her partnerâ€™s salary and thus improve their childrenâ€™s quality of life. She began selling shoes from her home to family members, and after a few recommendations people began to know her. This is how she started her sales business and sheâ€™s now been in business for four years.

She needs a $200 loan, which she will repay in six months, to buy shoes for school season since the start of classes is approaching and she wants to have enough merchandise. With your help Karla will succeed.

loan.name: Jeanne

texts.fr:
Born around 1968 in Abomey Calavi in the Atlantique department in the south of BENIN, Mrs. Jeanne E. is married and has 6 children, of which the eldest, Anne-marie, is 25 years old, and the youngest, Terrence, is 12. She is a seamstress by profession, but in parallel with this she sells yams and fried sweet potatoes. The demands of her customers are increasing and her financial means are unable to meet them; she is asking for this loan of 100,000 francs to supply herself in order to increase her production and respond appropriately to the demands of her clientele.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loan.name: Mougnou (Patience) Group

texts.fr:
The members of Mougnou group, with an average age of 30 and 6 children on average, live in traditional extended families in the village of Sikouna 1, Sub-prefecture of Fana (Koulikoro Region, Republic of Mali).

The group sells various items: cigarettes, tea, clothing, condiments (smoked fish, dried fish, spices, etc.)

They are essentially bound by ties of neighborhood, similar age, and friendship.

The solidarity of the group being firm, the members of Mougnou have decided to work together with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso which has approved their first group loan this month.

They do their purchasing from wholesalers who come from Bamako and SÃ©gou to market days in Marka coungo. They sell their goods either from home or at the market or as ambulant salespeople. Their sales are generally retail and on a cash basis.

The members of the group intend to buy 25 kg of fish, 5 kg of spices, packets of tea, a carton of cigarettes and some clothing items. With this loan, they hope to make a profit of 7500 FCFA which will be used essentially for reinvesting in their businesses.

loan.name: Yrma Edit

texts.es:
Yrma is a member of the "Solidarity" Communal Bank. She lives at Jr. Maya de Brito NÂº 651 in the Calleria District of the Ucayali area. She is a 47-year-old mother with 4 children, 3 of whom are older in age and 1 younger in age. She is married, and her husband works as a carrier. With her first loan from Kiva field partner Manuela Ramos, Yrma invested in a small store.

Yrma rises at 6:00am in order to buy perishable products to be sold that day. She waits on customers at the same time she does chores around the house. Yrma's store is open until 9:00pm each night.

With a loan of S/. 1,800 to be re-paid in 5 months, Yrma will buy 3 sacks of rice, 3 sacks of sugar, 2 oil buckets, 3 packages of hygienic paper, 1 box of milk, 21 packages of detergent, 2 boxes of eggs, 1 soda water box, and treats; in this way, she will be able to increase sales in her store.

Yrma is very happy. She started her business little by little. Her greatest wish is that her 15-year-old daughter will be able to become a working professional. Thanks to Manuela Ramos, her business has grown. She has more clients and economic stability than she had dreamed of for her family.

Translated from Spanish by Kara Gibson, Kiva volunteer.

loan.name: Julieta

texts.es:
Juliet has three children who are the most important things in her life. Therefore, when she realized that the family wasn't getting by on her husband's salary, she decided to help with household expenses by doing something that came easily to her like making meals such as tamales and also selling cosmetics through a catalog. She began business out of economic necessity since her husband was going through a period where he really was not working. She started approximately 5 years ago, selling house-to-house and now has a good number of customers.

She needs a $200 loan, which she will repay in six months, to buy merchandise and fill an order of cosmetics that is pending.

Yessica is a member of the Lilies II Communal Bank, located in Jr. Comandante Barrera 276 in the Calleria District in the Ucayali area of Peru. She is 26 years old and has one son; her husband is a mechanic. With the first loan received from Manuela Ramos in the amount of S/. 300, she started a business selling local fruits. She wants to continue in this line of work, selling fruits and beverages of the region (aguaje, hungurahui, manÃ­ and other refreshments).

With the requested loan of S/ 1,200, which is to be repaid in 5 months, she will buy sacks of aguaje fruit, hungurahui fruit, trays and glasses. Additionally, she will make modifications in her sales module and will pay for a Municipal license.

Yessica is very grateful to the Manuela Ramos Bank for their support. She realizes that implementing her own business will allow her to take care of her own as well as her family's needs.

She has run a business selling ready-to-eat meals for more than 3 years. She does not have any formal job training, but has devoted herself to this business, which provides her with more value. Currently, she is facing several financial difficulties in supplying herself with products, and she also envisions enlarging her array of goods. Faced with this situation, she is asking for her second loan, a sum of 100,000 francs, in order to better satisfy the demands of her clientele.

loan.name: Sabougnouma (Porte Bonheur) Group

texts.fr:
The members of Sabougnouma group are married, 32 years old on average, and have an average of 8 children. They live in traditional families with their husbands, co-spouses, and children in the village of Sikouna 2, Sub-prefecture of Fana (Koulikoro Region, Republic of Mali).

The women of the Sabougnouma group are specialized in the sale of condiments: onions, pepper, tomato concentrate, dried and smoked fish, Magi cubes, greens, vermicelli, salt, etc.

The Sabougnouma group, made up of relatives, friends, and co-habitants, is on its first loan with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso.

They want to use this loan to buy 1 kg of tomato concentrate, 1 packet of Magi cubes, 1 basket of onions, 5 kg of fish and some piles of greens on market days in Fana, Marka coungo, or Santiguila from the wholesalers who attend these weekly markets. The afore-mentioned locations are the traditional place for this group of village women to do their purchasing.

Their sales are made retail and on a cash basis in the village out of their homes or as ambulant salespeople going through the lanes from door to door. Their clientele is mainly composed of women with a few men.

With this loan, they expect to make a monthly average profit of 5000 FCFA which will be used to make repayments on the loan and invest in their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

loan.name: Maria Del Carmen

texts.es:
Carmen is an enterprising woman with two children. Since she was no longer able to work, she decided to start a business to care for her children and support her husband with the household expenses since they are now paying for their home. She began her business a year a go with her mother's help. She started a grocery store and little by little the business has improved.

She is seeking a loan for $1,000, which she will repay in 6 months, to restock merchandise and to remodel some things in the store such as advertisements. With your help, Carmen will advance.

Translated from Spanish by Amani Roland, Kiva volunteer.

loan.name: Milka

texts.es:
Milka is a member of the "Solidarity" Communal Bank. She resides at Jr: Oscar R Benavides N Âº234 in the CallerÃ­a District within the Ucayali region of Peru. She is 39 and widowed, with no children. She lives with her elderly parents, whom she assists.

Milka rents out 2 motorcars that are kept at her own home. She must wake every morning at 5:30am to tend to her chauffeurs and to give them the motorcars. Later, she prepares breakfast for her parents and provides care for her beloved mother, who suffers from arthritis.

With the requested loan of S/. 2,000, which is to be repaid in 5 months, she will buy 1 motorcar and renew her insurance policy and licenses.

Milka is a very giving woman, affectionate and a blessing to her parents. She is trustworthy and receives a strong endorsement in this opportunity offered to her by way of Manuela Ramos.

loan.name: Sabougnouma (Porte Bonheur) Group

texts.fr:
The members of this Sabougnouma group are married women with an average age of 45 and on average, 8 children. They live in polygamous families with their husbands, co-spouses, brothers, sisters, parents-in-law, and children in the village of Sikouna 1, Sub-prefecture of Fana (Koulikoro Region, Republic of Mali).

This is a group that sells: condiments (salt, spices), edibles (shelled peanuts, cowpeas and cowpea flour, dah leaves for tea), locally produced soaps, cola nuts, etc.

Sabougnouma is bound by ties of neighborhood and friendship.

They do their shopping for condiments and cola nuts at the big market in Bamako and sometimes in Fana where locally produced soap is always available. They procure their foodstuffs right in Sikouna 1 and in the surrounding villages. They form a network of suppliers for the retailers of the villages who purchase from them on credit in their homes in the village. They also go to the weekly market fairs such as the one at Marka coungo (where lots of sales are made) where they retail goods on a cash basis.

This groupâ€™s clientele is essentially made up of retailers (women, men) and consumers. They expect to buy 15 kg of spices for 1800 FCFA each to be sold for 2500 FCFA the kilogram, i.e., at a profit of 10,500 FCFA, 50 kg of dried cowpeas at 11,000 FCFA to be sold at 20,000 FCFA, i.e., at a profit of 9000 FCFA, 1 kg of cola nuts at 2000 FCFA to be sold by the piece making a profit of 2000 FCFA.

The women of the group expect to make an average monthly profit of 10,000 FCFA with which they will make repayments on the loan and especially reinforce their businesses.

Purchase and re-sale of various items

loan.name: Norma Lizeth

texts.es:
Norma is married and has two children who are very important to her. Therefore, she and her husband decided to start a hardware store, which now is very well stocked and is well situated in the city. She started this business to provided additional income because she and her family only counted on her husband's salary and they children were getting older and they were the majority of the household expenses. She began the business more than a year ago with her and her husband's savings.

She needs a $1,000 loan, which she will repay in 6 months, to restock her merchandise and to add new products. With your help, Norma will grow her business.

Translated from Spanish by Amani Roland, Kiva volunteer.

Norma es casada y tiene dos hijos que son los mas importante para ella es por eso que entre su esposo y ella decidieron poner un negocio de ferreterÃ­a el cual esta muy buen surtido y tiene muy buena ubicaciÃ³n en la cuidad. IniciÃ³ el negocio para tener un ingreso adicional ya que solo contaban con el sueldo de su esposo y los hijos estaban creciendo y eran mayores los gastos de la casa. Comenzo el negocio hace mas de un aÃ±o con los ahorros que tenian ella y su esposo.

Ella necesita un prestamo por US $1,000 que pagara en 6 meses para resurtir mercancÃ­a y tambiÃ©n para meter nuevos productos en el negocio. Con tu ayuda Norma hara crecer su negocio.

loan.use: To purchase merchandise and restock her hardware store.

loan.name: Carmen Rocio

texts.es:
Carmen belongs to â€œLas Azucenas IIâ€ Communal Bank located at Avenida SeÃ±or de los Milagros #190 in the Yarinacocha district of the state of Ucayali. She is 40 years old and the mother of three children. Her husband works at a petroleum distribution company.

With the first loan of 300 soles that Carmen received from Manuela Ramos she invested in beauty products. These products are from different lines (Avon, Unique, Esika, etc.) and she offers them door-to-door to an established clientele. To keep her clients happy she gives them small gifts that they appreciate.

With this loan of 1,200 soles, which she plans to repay in five months, she will buy perfumes, talcum powders, deodorants, earrings and lipsticks. She has a method of working in which she leaves her products with clients and then later charges them weekly and this works very well for her.

She is very satisfied with her business because she gives support to her husband and contributes to the livelihood of her family. Carmen is happy to receive loans because they are a great support for her family.

Translated from Spanish by Hugh Yarbrough, Kiva Volunteer.

Estos productos son de diferentes lÃ­neas (Avon, Unique, Esika), ofrece de casa en casa ya tienen una cartera de clientes, para mantenerlos contentos a sus clientes les regala detalles que son apreciados por sus clientes. loan.use: Purchase beauty products and accessories

loan.name: Sarakognouma (Bon Remboursement) Group

texts.fr:
The members of the Sarakognouma group are married women with an average age of 40 and an average of 6 children. They live in extended traditional families with their husbands, co-spouses, and children in the village of Djinina, Sub-prefecture of Fana (Koulikoro Region, Republic of Mali).

This group deals in: charcoal, condiments and various small items such as peanuts, guinea fowl eggs, epinares, baobab leaves, etc.

They met because of professional reasons, because they live near each other, or are relatives. In searching for business capital, the members of the Sarakognouma group decided to join the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso with whom they have just received a first loan. Sarakognuoma are a group of retailers, plain and simple, who stock up on condiments exclusively on weekly market days in Fana, buying from wholesalers who come from Bamako, SÃ©gou, Dioila, or from those living in Fana itself. They purchase smaller items in the village and surrounding areas or get them in the countryside (by harvesting them) or collect guinea fowl eggs along the edges of the fields. They sell essentially out of their houses in the village, retail and on a cash basis and also on credit.

The members of the Sarakognouma group intend to buy with this loan: 50 kg of condiments (composed of various sorts used in preparing dishes) at 1500 FCFA the kilogram and re-selling in small quantities making a monthly average profit margin of 30,000 FCFA which will be used to make repayments on the loan and to invest in their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

loan.name: Jeanne

texts.fr:
Born on 27 December 1995 in ALLADA in the Atlantique department in the south of BENIN, Mrs. Jeanne HOUNTO is married and has 3 children : Douglas, a 28 year old agronomist, Sylviane, 18 years old and in the second class (equivalent to 10th grade), and James, 12 years old and in the CM2 class (equivalent to 3rd grade). She is a weaver by profession and has been so for 15 years. She began selling ready-to-eat meals about 1 year ago because she has always wanted to break new ground and start many different business activities. With the hope of meeting her current financial needs and to satisfy the demands of her customers, she is asking for her second loan, a sum of 100,000 francs.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loan.name: Roxana Luisa

texts.es:
Roxana belongs to the â€œMujeres Audacesâ€ Communal Bank located at Avenida 21 de octubre #102 in the CallerÃ­a district of the state of Ucayali. She is 23 years old, the mother of two minor children and is married.

Roxana had the intention of supporting her husband and for that reason decided to invest in an Internet cafe business. She did that with her first loan of 300 soles from Manuela Ramos. Nowadays she has a business offering Internet access from cubicles installed in her own home. In addition to running the business she continues doing the household chores. She gladly does this because another thing she values is the opportunity to have lunch each day with her entire family.

With this loan of 900 soles, which she plans to repay in five months, she will invest in purchasing three Web cams, five mice, replacement computer parts and five Playstation accessories.

Effort and dedication motivate her every day to be a strong woman and she is thankful to life for having a united family and the support of her husband.

Translated from Spanish by Hugh Yarbrough, Kiva Volunteer.

Roxana tenÃ­a la intenciÃ³n de apoyar a su esposo por ello decide invertir en el negocio de alquiler de cabinas de Internet y esto lo efectÃºa con el primer prÃ©stamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/ 300. loan.name: Asteria

texts.es:
Asteria is 39 years old and a mother of 5 school age children, the oldest of who helps her in her business. Asteria makes and sells delicious ice cones (ice and fruit syrup) and refreshments, which are consumed often in the hot climate of the area. Mrs. Asteriaâ€™s husband is a teacher at a high school and together they move their home forward and provide for the needs of their children in the hopes of having a happy life. The dream of this mother is to have a small ice cream store. She is coming to you asking for a loan to be able to build a stand from which she can sell her refreshments and ice cones and make her customers and herself more comfortable.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva volunteer.

Asteria es una madre de 39 aÃ±os y 5 hijos, en edad escolar, el mayor de ellos le ayuda en su negocio. Asteria se dedica a la elaboraciÃ³n y venta de deliciosas raspadillas (hielo y jarabe de fruta) y refresco, muy consumidos por el clima cÃ¡lido de la zona.El esposo de doÃ±a Asteria es profesor en un gimnasio y juntos sacan adelante a su hogar y proveen las necesidades de sus hijos, en espera de que vivan felices. El sueÃ±o de esta madre es tener una pequeÃ±a heladerÃ­a. Ella recurre a ustedes en solicitud de un prÃ©stamo para construir un kiosko, para la venta de sus refrescos y raspadillas, y asÃ­ brindar mayor comodidad a sus clientes y a ella misma.

loan.name: Desarrollo Y Progreso Group

texts.en: Ercilia M. is the leader of her Esperanza International Bank of Hope, Desarrollo y Progreso ("Development and Progress"). She is the mother of four--aged 6,11,13, and 15--and has used her loan to open her shop "Novedades Ercilia," which sells clothes and novelties. With her future loans she hopes to expand her business and offer her loyal customers more merchandise so that she can ensure that her children are never lacking anything.

loan.use: growing Novedades Ercilia (sale of clothes, food, etc.)

loan.name: Susana

texts.es:
Susana is the owner of a mototaxi and also sells chickens. She has two minor children who are still in school. Her husband JosÃ© is the one in charge of the care of the mototaxi and he uses it to transport passengers. These two parents dedicate their efforts to their childrenâ€™s future, and both of them know that the children depend on them to become good men. Susana has turned to you to request a loan for which part will be used to repair the mototaxi and the other part will be used to increase their capital for their chicken business. In the future, they want to build their own stall where they can sell their chickens and be more comfortable.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Westin, Kiva volunteer.

Susana es propietaria de un motocarro, y tambiÃ©n se dedica a la venta de pollo, ella tiene 2 hijos menores que aÃºn estudian. Su esposo el seÃ±or JosÃ© es quien se dedica al cuidado de su motocarro y lo maneja haciendo transporte de pasajeros. Estos dos padres dedican su esfuerzo para el futuro de sus hijos, ambos saben que de ellos depende que sean hombres de bien.Susana se dirige a ustedes para solicitar un prÃ©stamo, el cual usarÃ¡ para la reparaciÃ³n de su motocarro y otra parte para incrementar el capital de su negocio de pollo, para en un futuro poder construir su propio puesto de venta y tener una mayor comodidad.

loan.use: Repair their mototaxi and have more capital for their chicken business

loan.name: Leni Beatriz

texts.es:
Leni belongs to the â€œMujeres Audacesâ€ Communal Bank located at Jr. Roca Fuerte #421 in the CallerÃ­a district of the state of Ucayali. She is 42 years old, the mother of three minor children and her husband is employed. Leni sees the necessity of having a business and so with the first loan of 300 soles received from Manuela Ramos, she decided to invest in the business of renting Internet booths installed in her own home. Besides the business, she attends to all of the household chores and takes her children to school. Her daily routine is very tiring but at the end of the day she feels satisfied because she sees herself as an accomplished woman, mother and wife.

With this loan of 1,500 soles, which she plans to repay in five months, she will invest in five Web cams, two used computers and a printer.

Every day Leni is growing as a businesswoman and she feels happy because she is providing for the necessities of her children. She is thankful for the immense support that Manuela Ramos gives to her.

Translated from Spanish by Hugh Yarbrough, Kiva Volunteer.

Leni pertenece al Banco Comunal â€œMujeres Audacesâ€ domiciliada en el Jr: Roca Fuerte NÂº 421 del Distrito de CallerÃ­a en el Departamento de Ucayali tiene 42 aÃ±os, es madre de 3 hijos menores, su esposo es empleado. Leny ve la necesidad de un negocio, es asÃ­ que con el primer prÃ©stamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/ 300 soles decidiÃ³ invertir en el negocio de alquiler de cabinas de Internet. En la actualidad cuenta con su negocio de alquiler de cabinas de internet instalado en su propio domicilio. loan.use: Purchase five Web cams, two used computers and a printer

loan.name: Ines

texts.en:
Ines is the mother of four and grandmother of 14. She lives with her daughter and two grandchildren in the province of El Seibo. Ines works as a cleaning lady in both homes and buildings. The government pays her for cleaning large government buildings. Its hard for her to clean sometimes because the buildings are so tall and the windows and walls are very high up.

With this loan, Ines plans to start a small business selling food that she will cook herself. Here, such a business is called a Â¨fritura,Â¨where all sorts of snacks and homemade food are prepared and sold. With the profits from the fritura, Ines hopes to one day buy a stove for her house. She would also love to install a glass window to keep out the flies and mosquitoes. Glass windows are very rare here and quite a luxury, so this is a big dream for her.

loan.use: To start up a small snack stand

loan.name: Clara

texts.es:
Clara belongs to Banco Comunal Las Asucenas II, located in Jr Bellavista, block 9 post 32 in the Calleria District in the Ucayali Department. She is 47 years old and is mother to three children. With her first loan of S. 300 from Manuela Ramos, Clara invested in her beauty shop. Her shop is located in the city center and has many customers who know that Clara can provide beautiful hairstyles, as well as provide in-home services.

With this loan of S. 1,500, which will be repaid in five months, Clara will purchase shampoo, dyes, and other hair products. Clara is very charismatic and attends to all customers who come to her beauty shop. She is grateful to the Manuela Ramos movement for the backing provided.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer.

La seÃ±ora Clara pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Azucenas II, ubicado en el Jr Bellavista cdra. 9 puesto 32, del Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 47 aÃ±os y es madre de 3 hijos. Clara con el primer prÃ©stamo recibido de Manuela Ramos S/. 300 decide invertir en su peluquerÃ­a. Su PeluquerÃ­a queda en el centro de la ciudad y tiene muchos clientes que saben que Clara les hace C., peinados bonitos, ademas da sus servicios a domicilio.. Con este prÃ©stamo recibido de S/ 1,500 el cual serÃ¡ pagado en 5 meses, comprarÃ¡ champÃº, tintes y lÃ­quidos para peinados. Clara es muy carismÃ¡tica para atender a todos(as) sus clientes que llegan a su peluquerÃ­a, para ser atendidas por ella. Y agradece a movimiento Manuela Ramos por el respaldo que le brinda.

loan.use: Purchase various items for a beauty shop.

loan.name: Fuente De Esperanza (Source Of Hope) Group 8

texts.en:
Francisca B. lives with her parents, her husband, and her two children, ages three and six. She is currently 4 months pregnant with her third child. She owns and cooks in a small â€œfrituraâ€ where she sells fried foods like empanadas along with other snacks. While sheâ€™s at work, her 6 year-old goes to school and the 3 year-old stays at home with her parents. Francisca has successfully repaid three loans to Esperanza International and is currently applying for her fourth.

Francisca has great ambitions for the future. She wants to expand her business so that she will have money to pursue many dreams. She has completed her first year of high school and, though she is not currently in school, she hopes to go back and finish her diploma. She would love to be able to have her own house for her family. She also dreams of being able to send her three kids through school all the way to college so that they can have professional careers.

Note: Mariana Isa was not able to come because her niece was very sick, so her husband appears in this photo in her place.

Note: This is a group loan for 5 people.

loan.use: To grow her business selling fried foods

loan.name: Mirela

texts.es:
MÃ­rela belongs to â€œLas Azucenas IIâ€ Communal Bank located at Jr. Yarina Cocha, Mz. B Lt. 7, in the Yarina Cocha district of the state of Ucayali. She is 20 years old and single. With the first loan received from Manuela Ramos of 300 soles, MÃ­rela started a business selling candies. She also works in an accounting firm which enables her to bring additional income to her family while receiving the support of her mother who takes care of her business until she returns.

With this loan of 1,000 soles, which she plans to repay in five months, she will buy five cases of cookies, five bags of lollipops, one bag of â€œchisitos,â€ one case of gum, one bag of toilet paper and three cases of soft drinks.

MÃ­rela is a very enthusiastic young lady with a lot of desire to get ahead, both professionally and economically, as she is a help to her parents. She is very happy to be a part of the Manuela Ramos bank.

Translated from Spanish by Hugh Yarbrough, Kiva Volunteer.

La seÃ±orita MÃ­rela pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Azucenas II, ubicado en el Jr. Yarina cocha Mz.B Lt.7, Distrito de Yarina Cocha del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 20 aÃ±os es soltera, Mirela con el primer prÃ©stamo recibido de Manuela Ramos S/. 300 implemento su negocio en venta de golosinas. MÃ­rela tambiÃ©n trabaja en un estudio contable y es asÃ­ que trae un ingreso mas a su familia ella recibe el apoyo de su mama ya que ella queda a cargo de su negocio hasta que ella regrese.. Con este prÃ©stamo recibido de S/ 1,000 el cual serÃ¡ pagado en 5 meses, comprarÃ¡ 5 cajas de galletas 5 bolsas de chupetines, 1 bolsa de chisito, 3 tiras de ch, 1 caja de chicle ice, 1 bol. papel higiÃ©nico, 3 paquetes de Gaseosas, Mirela es una seÃ±orita muy entusiasta tiene muchas ganas de salir adelante tanto en lo profesional y econÃ³micamente; ya que ella es un apoyo para sus padres y esta muy contenta de participar en el Banco Manuela Ramos.

loan.use: Purchase candies and soft drinks at wholesale prices

loan.name: Mujeres De Debora Group

texts.en:
Lucelia C. runs a small cafeteria in the little community of Llano De Perre, Dominican Republic. As a single mother of three, the income from this mini-restaurant is the livelihood of her family. She sought out Esperanza to help her with her first ever loan, valuing $150. The money that Lucelia gets from this loan will go towards purchasing bread, meat, oil, and fresh fruit to make smoothies at her local venue. In typical Dominican fashion, her favorite dish is rice, beans, and chicken, a customer favorite as well. She dreams of one day being able to travel outside of the country with her three children.

Lucelia is one of the leaders of the 15-person micro-bank Mujeres de Debora. Many of the women in this 15-person bank have recently immigrated from Haiti in search of a better future. Their businesses are simple, but offer a stream of income that could never have been accomplished without such a loan for initial capital. Several of the women sell clothes and shoes in the street, while others go from office to office vending fresh fruit and vegetables daily. These unique entrepreneurs have united in solidarity, allowing them to access funding that they would otherwise never be able to receive on their own.

The concept of this group bank repaying their loan together is to reduce the risk of one person defaulting, as the other members gladly help cover one anotherâ€™s payments in order to receive their next loan together. As these 15 entrepreneurs embark upon their first ever loan from Esperanza, we are confident that they will all succeed in bettering their lives and the lives of their families with this loan.

On behalf of Lucelia C., the Mujeres de Debora group, and the entire team here at Esperanza International, we thank you for your support and awareness of the global issue of poverty, where your efforts are helping to make a difference.

loan.use: To purchase meat, bread, fruit, and a blender for a small restaurant

loan.name: Doris

texts.es:
Doris is 41 years old. Together with her husband she makes a living selling fish. While he travels selling, she sets up in front of the door to her house, where she sells fresh and salted fish on a table that she places there. This couple works hard to be able to cover the expenses of their home and the education of their children. Because of the intense heat, she is in need of a loan to be able to construct what in her area is called a â€œramadaâ€, which is a covering made of branches woven together, and will be placed over her selling area as a form of roof. She needs to purchase the materials and is counting on you to enable her to do so.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva volunteer.

Doris tiene 41 aÃ±os, ella y su esposo se dedican a la venta de pescado, mientras que Ã©l se va por diferentes lugares para vender, ella se acomoda en la puerta de su casa, y en una mesa acomoda su pescado fresco y salado. Esta pareja se esfuerza en su trabajo para cumplir con los gastos de su casa y el estudio de sus hijos.Por el intenso calor ella se ve en la necesidad de pedir este prÃ©stamo para la elaboraciÃ³n de lo que llaman en su localidad, una ramada, que es una especie de trenzado de ramas en plancha, para colocarlo como techo del espacio donde vende, necesita comprar esos materiales y confÃ­a en ustedes para ello.

loan.use: Purchase of materials to construct a shelter of branches to cover the area where she sells fish.

loan.name: Alida

texts.es:
Mrs. Alida is a woman with a strong drive to overcome her obstacles and progress. She sells cold beverages ( sodas and beer) and also when requested she prepares meals in the evening. Alida is 59 years old and mother of 9 daughters, four of whom are independent. and have their own families. Five are still single, work and still live with her. Her husband Julio is a farmer, and they both support each other in their work. Alida wants to better supply and expand her business and be able to bring more variety to her customers. She needs a loan to realize her goal.

Translated from Sapnish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva volunteer.

La seÃ±ora Alida es una mujer con muchos deseos de superaciÃ³n y progreso, se dedica a la venta de bebidas heladas (gaseosas y cervezas), y aparte cuando se lo piden, tambiÃ©n vende comida por las noches. Alida tiene 58 aÃ±os y es madre de 9 hijas siendo cuatro de ellas ya independientes y de familia, mientras que 5 son aÃºn solteras, trabajan, pero todavÃ­a viven con ella, su esposo, Julio, es agricultor y ambos se apoyan en sus labores.Alida quiere implementar y ampliar su negocio para brindar a sus clientes una mejor acogida, necesita de un prÃ©stamo para realizar su propÃ³sito.

loan.use: Investment capital to increase inventories and expand her business.

loan.name: Betman

texts.es:
Betman is 25 years old. He works as a taxi driver and in agriculture with the help of his wife. They have a small child and both work hard in order to give him all the necessities, especially an education. Betman is the driver of a mototaxi, which is having mechanical issues. As a result, he is relying on you to provide him with a loan so he may repair his mototaxi, as well as invest in his farmland for a better harvest.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer.

Betman tiene 25 aÃ±os, trabaja en el transporte de pasajeros, y en la agricultura con la ayuda de su esposa, tienen un pequeÃ±o hijo, y ambos trabajan duro para darle lo necesario, en especial para los gastos estudiantiles. Betman es dueÃ±o de un motocarro, el que estÃ¡ presentando fallas mecÃ¡nicas, por lo que recurre a ustedes para que le brinden un prÃ©stamo con el que pueda reparar su motocarro e invertir en sus tierras de cultivo para una mejor cosecha.

loan.use: Repair his mototaxi.

loan.name: Rita

texts.es:
Rita makes a living by selling fruit at a stand in the market. The change in the climate in her area has compromised her products; there have been many losses and shortages. For this reason she has moved away from this business and until the situation improves is working in the sale of animals (chickens, ducks, turtles and such). Rita has five children, and both her and her husband work to be able to give them what is necessary. One of Ritaâ€™s dreams is that her children will someday become professionals; another is to be able to construct a home of quality materials. For these reasons she is requesting your support in the acquisition of a loan that she will use to purchase more animals thus increasing her sales and her income. She is anxiously waiting for her acceptance.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva volunteer.

Rita se dedica a la venta de frutas en un puesto del mercado, pero por el cambio de clima en su zona a perjudicado mucho sus productos, ha habido tambiÃ©n muchas pÃ©rdidas y una gran escasez por ello ha dejado de lado esta actividad y hasta que mejore la situaciÃ³n estÃ¡ trabajando en la venta de animales (gallinas, patos, motelos y otras variedades) Rita tiene 5 hijos, y tanto ella como su esposo trabajan para darles lo necesario. Uno de los sueÃ±os de Rita es que sus hijos sean algÃºn dÃ­a profesionales, y el otro es poder construir su casa con material noble. Para ello pide su apoyo con un prÃ©stamo que utilizarÃ¡ en la compra de mÃ¡s animales para aumentar su venta y con ello sus ganancias. Espera con ansias su aceptaciÃ³n.

loan.use: Capital for the purchase of more animals for later resale in the market of the area.

loan.name: JesÃºs

texts.es:
Jesus is 38 years old and is dedicated to transporting passengers in his mototaxi. With help from his wife, he cultivates a small plot of land and sells produce. In this manner, this couple is able to pay their bills and support their children's education. The reason why Jesus is here in front of you is so he may request a loan so he can maintain his mototaxi and purchase some parts. At the same time, he wants to continue saving for the purchase of another vehicle so he may increase his earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer.

JesÃºs tiene 38 aÃ±os, y se dedica al transporte de pasajeros en motocarro, a la par con la ayuda de su esposa, cultivan un pequeÃ±o terreno para luego vender los productos producidos, de esta manera, esta pareja de esposos sostienen los gastos de su casa y los estudios de sus hijos.El motivo por el que JesÃºs se presenta ante ustedes es para pedir un apoyo econÃ³mico en prÃ©stamo para el mantenimiento de su motocarro y la compra de algunos repuestos, asÃ­ mismo seguir ahorrando para la compra de otro vehÃ­culo para aumentar sus ganancias.

loan.use: Mototaxi maintenance and the purchase of parts.

loan.name: Geysi

texts.es:
Geysi has a small glass shop. She began selling paintings and now she has her own business, which makes her feel happy and proud. Geysi is 26 years old and has three children. Her husband is a carpenter and together they take care of their family's needs. She thinks that this project of helping people get ahead is a great idea: If there were more groups around the world working so that others can progress, the world would be a better place. She is thankful for the assistance that you can provide and feels emotional to think that, of all the people in the world, she may receive a friendly helping hand. Geysi promises to be punctual and responsible with her payments. The money that she is requesting will be invested in the purchase of materials for her glass shop and to improve the space that she uses.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer.

Geysi tiene una pequeÃ±a vidrierÃ­a, ella empezÃ³ vendiendo cuadros y ahora ha logrado tener su propio negocio por el que se siente muy feliz y orgullosa. Geysi tiene 26 aÃ±os y 3 hijos, su esposo es maderero y juntos sostienen las necesidades familiares. Ella considera que este proyecto donde personas ayudan a otras a salir adelante es una gran idea, ya que si hubieran mÃ¡s grupos trabajando para que otros progresen el mundo serÃ­a un lugar mejor. Por ello que agradece el apoyo que le puedan brindar y se siente emocionada al pensar en la gente en todo el mundo, que como ella puede recibir una mano amiga.Ella promete ser puntual y responsable en sus pagos, y el dinero solicitado serÃ¡ invertido en la compra de materiales para su vidrierÃ­a y para la mejora del espacio que utiliza.

loan.use: Investment capital for her glass business.

loan.name: Sara

texts.es:
Sara belongs to â€œLas Azucenas IIâ€ Communal Bank located in the UniÃ³n de Damnificados neighborhood of CallerÃ­a in the state of Ucayali. She is 42 years old and the mother of three children. Her husband is an electrical technician.

With the first loan of 300 soles that Sara received from Manuela Ramos, she decided to invest in the purchase of products for a grocery store. Nowadays she continues to sell groceries and little by little is introducing hardware items. In the evenings she receives additional income selling foods typical of the region and is very happy because she is progressing. With this loan of 1,800 soles, which she plans to repay in five months, she will buy three sacks of rice, three sacks of sugar, two cases of milk and some hardware items. Sara feels very grateful to the Manuela Ramos bank because thanks to it, she can continue to grow her business. She has the desire to continue growing until she has her own bookstore and mini hardware store.

Translated from Spanish by Hugh Yarbrough, Kiva Volunteer.

La seÃ±ora Sara pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Azucenas II , ubicado en el AA.HH UniÃ³n de Damnificados Mz.B Lt.8, del Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 42 aÃ±os es madre de 3 hijos, su esposo es TÃ©cnico Electricista. Sara con el primer prÃ©stamo que recibiÃ³ de Manuela Ramos de S/.300 decidiÃ³ invertir en la compra de productos de abarrotes. En la actualidad continua con su venta de productos de abarrotes y esta implementÃ¡ndose poco a poco en lo que es ferreterÃ­a; por las noches tambiÃ©n tiene otro ingreso vende comida lo que son comidas regionales y que esta muy contenta por que esta progresando. Con este prÃ©stamo recibido de S/ 1,800 el cual serÃ¡ pagado en 5 meses, comprarÃ¡ 3 sacos de arroz, 3 sacos de azÃºcar, 2 caja de leche, y un poco de ferreterÃ­a Sara se siente muy agradecida con el Banco Manuela Ramos ya que gracias a ello puede seguir creciendo su negocio ella tiene toda esperanza de seguir creciendo hasta lograr formar su librerÃ­a y mini ferreterÃ­a.

loan.use: Purchase products for a general store at wholesale prices

loan.name: Sonia Luz

texts.es:
Ms. Sonia belongs to the bank Banco Comunal Las Azucenas II, located in Jr. EmancipaciÃ³n Mz.F Lt.18, in the District of San Fernando, Department of Ucayali. Sheâ€™s 42 years old and has one child. Her husband works as a personal assistant. Sonia was able to stock her clothing business with the first loan she received from Manuela Ramos S./300 (300 soles, Peruvian currency). She also provides tailoring services. With this loan in the amount of 1,500 soles, which will be repaid in 5 moths, she will invest in purchasing material by the meter, 12 shoe sole inserts, 6 pairs of jeans, 12 blouses and 5 sets childrenâ€™s clothing. Sonia is very happy with the bank Banco Manuela Ramos because thanks to them business is increasing. She hopes to buy a display case so that she can sell jewelry, perfume and to better display her products.

Translated from Spanish by Sandy JuÃ¡rez, Kiva volunteer.

La seÃ±ora Sonia pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Azucenas II, ubicado en el Jr. EmancipaciÃ³n Mz.F Lt.18, Distrito de san fernando del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 42 aÃ±os y tiene un solo hijo y su esposo es Asistente Personal, Sonia con el primer prÃ©stamo recibido de Manuela Ramos S/. 300 implemento su negocio de venta de ropas. TambiÃ©n brinda servicio de costura. Con este prÃ©stamo recibido de S/ 1,500 el cual serÃ¡ pagado en 5 meses, ella invierto comprando telas por metros, 12 plantilla de zapatos, 6 pantalones jean, 12 blusas y 5 conjuntos para niÃ±os. Sonia esta muy contenta con el Banco Manuela Ramos por que gracias a ello su negocio esta surgiendo. Ella tiene toda la esperanza de comprarse su vitrina para que asÃ­ que venda sus joya, perfumerÃ­a y para que asÃ­ pueda tener mejor exhibiciÃ³n sus productos.

loan.name: Teresa Mercedes

texts.es:
Ms. Teresa belongs to the bank Banco Comunal Las Azucenas. She lives in Jr. Contamana #183, District of Yarina Cocha, Department of Ucayali. Sheâ€™s 52 years old and she has 5 children. Her husband is an electrician. With the first Manuela Ramos loan of S/.300 (300 soles, Peruvian currency) received, she decided to purchase Unique and Avon brand cosmetics. AsiD. from selling cosmetics, she makes additional income as a fast food street vendor in the evenings, selling items such as salchipapas (a potato and sausage dish and sandwiches). Her business is doing well. With this 1,800 Soles loan, which will be repaid in 4 moths, she will stock her business, buy a display case for her cosmetics, purchase perfumes, deodorants, cologne, talcum powders, jewelry, etc. Teresa is very happy with the loan she received since it helped her business grow, in this way reaching her goals and dreams. Teresa wants to sell cards and cell phones. In this ways she will be able to pay for her childrenâ€™s education especially for one of her children who is studying at university.

Translated from Spanish by Sandy JuÃ¡rez, Kiva volunteer.

La seÃ±ora Teresa pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Azucenas, vive en el Jr. Contamana #183, del Distrito D. YarinaCocha del Departamento D. Ucayali. Tiene 52 aÃ±os y es madre D. 5 hijos, su esposo es Electricista. Con el primer prÃ©stamo recibido D. Manuela Ramos D. S/. 300 decidiÃ³ invertir en la compra D. productos D. belleza D. las marcas Unique y Avon. Ademas D. la venta D. productos D. belleza, por las noches tambiÃ©n tiene otro ingreso adicional, ella venD. comida rÃ¡pida en forma ambulante, como por ejemplo salchipapas y sandwichâ€™s. Le estÃ¡ yendo bastante bien. Con este prÃ©stamo D. S/ 1,800 el cual serÃ¡ pagado en 4 meses, implementÃ³ su negocio, comprÃ³ una vitrina para que pueda exhibir sus productos D. belleza, tambiÃ©n comprarÃ¡ perfumes, desodorantes, colonias, talcos, joyas, etc. Teresa se siente muy bien con el prÃ©stamo recibido por que le ayuda a seguir creciendo su negocio, y asÃ­ pueD. cumplir sus metas y sus sueÃ±os. Teresa quiere vender tarjetas y celulares; y asÃ­ pueda ayudarle a pagar sus estudios a sus hijos sobre todo a uno que esta en la universidad.
