loan.name: Violeta

texts.es:
Violeta belongs to the bank Banco Comunal â€œSolidaridadâ€, her home is located in Jr: libertad NÂº 1182, District of Calleria, Department of Ucayali. Sheâ€™s 47 years old and is the mother of 4 children, 3 older children, and 1 underage child. She is married and her husband is a teacher. Violeta with the goal of feeling like a sense of accomplishment hopes to take secure a loan from Manuela Ramos in the amount of 300 Soles (Peruvian currency) to sell ice. She currently has 2 refrigerators to sell ice and since she is close to the market, the salespeople are her clients. As additional income she rents out her mini-gym. Violeta wakes up at 5 am to get ready for the day, with her husband, because she also works as advocate for Pronoi, an educational center. She returns at 1 pm to begin work in her business. With this loan of 1,300 Soles, which will be repaid in 5 months, she will buy a thousand bags and will fix her freezer, which is in need of repair due to the high demand. Violeta is very happy because she started slowly, and her biggest wish is to make her business larger and be a great businesswoman. This is why she is very grateful to Manuela Ramos, who has given her the opportunity to secure a credit for her business.

Translated from Spanish by Sandy JuÃ¡rez, Kiva volunteer.

Violeta pertenece al Banco Comunal â€œSolidaridadâ€, su domicilio esta ubicado Jr: libertad NÂº 1182, del Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 47 aÃ±os y es madre de 4 hijos 3 adultos y 1menor de edad, estÃ¡ casada y su esposo es docente (profesor). Violeta con la finalidad de sentirse realizada decide hacer un prÃ©stamo a Manuela Ramos de S/. 300.00 para vender hielo. En la actualidad cuenta con 2 refrigeradoras para vender sus hielos ya que esta cerca al mercado y los vendedores son sus clientes. AsÃ­ mismo alquila su mini gimnasio, es otro ingreso mÃ¡s. Violeta tiene que levantarse a las 5.00 a.m. para alistarse juntamente con su esposo porque tambiÃ©n trabaja como promotora de Pronoi (Centro educativo), esta de regreso a la 1:00pm lista para atender su negocio. Con este prÃ©stamo de S/. 1,300 soles, el cual serÃ¡ pagado en 5 meses, comprarÃ¡ 1 millar de bolsas e invirtirÃ¡ en la reparaciÃ³n de su congelador pues, es necesario darle mantenimiento por la mucha demanda que tiene. Violeta esta muy contenta, por que empezÃ³ de poco a poco y su mas grande deseo es ampliar su negocio y ser una gran empresaria, por ello esta muy agradecida a Manuela Ramos que le brindo la oportunidad a un crÃ©dito para su negocio.

loan.use: To purchase plastic bags and to fix a freezer.

loan.name: Diolizana

texts.es:
Diolizana belongs to the bank Banco Comunal â€œLas Golondrinas 2â€. She lives in Jr: Zavala NÂº 775, District of Calleria, Department of Ucayali. Sheâ€™s 37 years old and is the mother of 3 young children, and her husband is a laborer. Diolizana has decided to ask for a loan of 300 soles from Manuela Ramos to invest and open a multi-services business: providing photocopies, lamination, notebooks, and digitizing of documents. She currently maintains a business in her own home, allowing her to do home chores, but besides all this work, she able to take a small break from 1 to 4 pm. With this loan of 2,000 soles (Peruvian currency), which will be repaid in 4 moths, she will invest in the purchase of supplies: 2 thousand sheets of bond paper, 3 printer ink cartridges, 20 laminate sheets, 25 notebooks, 50 manila folders, 50 poster boards. Diolinzana is very happy because she contributes to the household income and her biggest wish is to grow as a businesswoman and she thanks Manuela Ramos for the support they have given.

Translated from Spanish by Sandy JuÃ¡rez, Kiva volunteer.

Diolizana pertenece al Banco Comunal â€œLas Golondrinas 2â€domiciliada en el Jr: Zavala NÂº 775 del Distrito de CallerÃ­a en el Departamento de Ucayali tiene 37 aÃ±os, es madre de 3 hijos menores, su esposo es obrero. Diolizana decide hacer un prÃ©stamo de Manuela Ramos S/ 300.para invertir y abrir un negocio de Multiservicios: fotocopias, enmicados, espiralados y digitaciÃ³n de trabajos. En la actualidad cuenta con su negocio en su propio domicilio, esto le permite ver los quehaceres de la casa, a pesar de todo el trajÃ­n, ella puede darse un pequeÃ±o descanso de 1.00 pm hasta las 4.00pm Con el este prÃ©stamo de S/. 2,000 el cual serÃ¡ pagado en 4 meses, invertirÃ¡ en la compra de insumos: 2 millares de papel bond, 3 tintas para impresora, 25 micas, 25 espirales, 50 fÃ³lderes de Manila y 50 cartulinas. Diolizana se siente muy contenta porque apoya en los gastos que tiene en su hogar y su mayor anhelo es crecer como empresaria y agradece a Manuela Ramos por el apoyo brindado

loan.use: To purchase supplies (paper, ink, lamination supplies, poster board etc.)

loan.name: Esther

texts.es:
Ms. Esther belongs to the bank Banco Comunal Mujeres Audaces, located in Jr. Manco capac #151 in the town of Joven Bellavista, District of San Fernando, Department of Ucayali. She is 60 year old and is the mother of 4 children, and she is a widow. With the first loan of 300 Soles (Peruvian currency) she received from Manuela Ramos, she decided to continue investing in her banana business. She currently continues to sell bananas at wholesale and individual prices in the Bellavista Market and bijao leaf (a type of leaf similar to banana leaf). She works from 5 am to 6:30 pm and she also sells her banana fritters. With this loan of 2,000 Soles, which will be repaid in 5 month, she will buy banana bunches and bijao laves at wholesale prices. Esther, despite her ages is a strong woman who doesnâ€™t tire, and she continues to move ahead despite the obstacles she has faced.

Translated from Spanish by Sandy JuÃ¡rez, Kiva volunteer.

La seÃ±ora Esther pertenece al Banco Comunal Mujeres Audaces, ubicado en el Jr. Manco capac #151 Pueblo Joven Bellavista, Distrito de San Fernando del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 60 aÃ±os y es madre de 4 hijos, es viuda. Esther con el primer prÃ©stamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300 decidiÃ³ seguir implementando su negocio de venta de plÃ¡tanos. En estos momentos sigue con la venta de plÃ¡tanos al por mayor y menor en el mercado bellavista y venta de hoja de bijao. Sale a vender a las 5:00 am hasta las 6:30 pm y ahÃ­ aprovecha tambiÃ©n en vender sus chifles (PlÃ¡tano frito). Con este prÃ©stamo de S/. 2,000 el cual serÃ¡ pagado en 5 meses, comprarÃ¡ racimos de plÃ¡tanos y hoja de bijao al por mayor.. Esther a su edad es una mujer muy luchadora que no desmaya y sigue adelante a pesar de los tropiezos que ella tuvo.

loan.use: To purchase bananas and bijao leaves at wholesale price.

loan.name: Lilian

texts.es:
Lilian belongs the bank Banco Comunal â€œSolidaridadâ€, her home is located in the Municipal city of 6 de Diciembre Mz A Lt 1, District of Calleria, Department of Ucayali. She is 43 years old and she is the mother of 3 children, 1 older child and 2 younger ones. Her husband is employed. Lilian wants to help out economically at home, and because of this she has asked for a loan of 300.00 Soles (Peruvian currency) from Manuela Ramos. She currently runs a small clothing sales business and she travels once a month to the city of Tacna to buy clothing. She wakes up every day at 6 am to go to the market and leaves everything ready at home, so she can run her business. Lilian delivers ordered clothing from 10 am until 1pm, when she rests and eats. She continues working from 5 pm to 9:30 pm. With this loan of 1,500 Soles from Manuela Ramos, which will be repaid in 5 moths, Lilian will buy 3 dozen blouses, 3 dozen pieces of underwear, etc. Lilian is very happy, because she says she has a stable client base, which she has won through her effort and perseverance. She feels like her dreams are coming true, and the greatest satisfaction she gets is that her family doesnâ€™t have to suffer the lack of so many things, this makes her feel like a strong person.

Translated from Spanish by Sandy JuÃ¡rez, Kiva volunteer.

Lilian pertenece al Banco Comunal â€œSolidaridadâ€ su domicilio esta ubicado en la UrbanizaciÃ³n Municipal 6 de Diciembre Mz A Lt 1, del Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 43 aÃ±os y es madre de 3 hijos, 1 mayor y dos menores de edad, su esposo es empleado. Lilian quiere ayudar econÃ³micamente en casa, es asÃ­ que solicitÃ³ un prÃ©stamo a Manuela Ramos por S/. 300.00 soles. En la actualidad cuenta con un pequeÃ±o negocio de compra y venta de ropa, donde Lilian viaja una vez por mes hasta la ciudad de Tacna para comprar las prendas. Cada dÃ­a se levanta a las 6.00 am. Para ir al mercado, dejar todo listo en casa para luego dedicarse a su negocio. Lilian reparte sus pedidos desde las 10:00am hasta la 1:00 pm de ahÃ­ se da el tiempo de almorzar y descansar y desde las 5:00pm hasta las 9:30 pm vuelve a su labor. Con este prÃ©stamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 1,500, el cual serÃ¡ pagado en 5 meses, comprarÃ¡ 3 docenas de blusas, 3 docenas de ropa interior, etc. Lilian esta muy contenta, porque tiene clientes estables la cual se ha ganado a base de esfuerzo y perseverancia, siente que sus sueÃ±os se estÃ¡n realizando y la mejor satisfacciÃ³n que siente es que su familia ya no tiene que sufrir tantas necesidades y eso la hace sentir fuerte.

loan.use: To purchase clothing at wholesale value.

loan.name: Mujeres Solidarias (Women In Solidarity) Group 3

texts.en:
Yameris M. is the single mother of a two-year-old baby girl. She has a small business killing and selling chickens in her community. She has already successfully repaid two loans to Esperanza International and is now applying for her third. With the loan money she will be able to buy more chickens to raise and then sell so that she can better her life.

Yameris has hopes of becoming a better person and she really wants to â€œser alguien en la vida,â€ (to be someone in life). She dreams of being able to provide well for her daughter and of sending her all the way through college so that she can have a professional career. She also dreams of one day owning her very own little house. With your help and her continued loans, Yameris is on her way to making her dreams come true.

Note: This is a group loan for 5 people.

loan.use: to raise, kill and sell more chickens

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Esperanza International, a partner of HOPE International - Oct 23, 2008)

loan.name: Lita Sabel

texts.es:
Lita belongs to the â€œLas Azucenas IIâ€ comunal bank and lives in the Calleria district of the department of Ucayla. She is 38 years old and is a single mother with one son. With the first loan of S/. 300.00 that she received from Manuel Ramos, she decided to invest in a small business selling food. She currently has a restaurant and, with the help of her mother, business is doing well. Lita also works part time in a clinic in administrative services.

With this loan of S/. 1,000.00, which she will repay in 5 months, she will buy supplies for her restaurant: 1 sack of rice, sugar, a gallon of cooking oil, soft drinks, napkins, and bags. Lita has a lot of dedication and energy for her business, which she tends to with great care since her customers are the reason it exists. She hopes to eventually obtain a larger business space and to open an internet cafÃ©. She wants to continue making progress and also give the best to her parents.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

La seÃ±ora Lita pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Azucenas II, ubicado en el Jr. Andres Razuri #186, del Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 38 aÃ±os y es madre soltera y tiene 1 hijo. Con el primer prÃ©stamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300 decidiÃ³ invertir en un pequeÃ±o negocio de venta de comida. En la actualidad tiene un restaurante y con la ayuda de su mamÃ¡, su negocio esta surgiendo. Lita tambiÃ©n trabaja medio tiempo en una clÃ­nica en la parte administrativa. Con este prÃ©stamo de S/ 1,000 el cual serÃ¡ pagado en 5 meses, implementarÃ¡ su restaurante, comprarÃ¡ 1 saco de arroz, azÃºcar, galÃ³n de aceite, gaseosas, servilletas y bolsas. Lita tiene una gran energÃ­a y dedicaciÃ³n para su negocio, el cual atiende con mucho esmero por que sus clientes son la razÃ³n de ser, ella tiene la expectativa de tener un negocio mÃ¡s grande y poner un Internet y seguir progresando y darle de lo mejor a sus padres.

loan.use: To buy ingredients at wholesale price

loan.name: Union Y Amor (Unity & Love) Group 1

texts.en:
Juana is the mother of 4 children, ages 20, 21, 29 and 32. She is also the proud grandmother of 2, ages 6 and 16. Juana has a small business cooking and baking various foods like bread, chicken, and fried foods such as empanadas. She then sells her goods to a traveling salesman who will travel around to various communities on a motorcycle or in a car. This way Juana is able to work from home and be close to her family. She also sews clothing that she then sells in the community. Business can be hard sometimes when there is not enough demand for her products. Having a loan helps her to better weather the dry spells of business and to continue progressing.

Juana has successfully paid back 5 loans to Esperanza International and is now requesting her sixth loan. With the money, she hopes to expand her businesses even more to better proviD. for her family. She wants her children to be able to finish their educations and find good jobs.

Note: This is a group loan for 5 people.

loan.use: to buy more ingredients to bake and sell more food products

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Esperanza International, a partner of HOPE International - Oct 23, 2008)

loan.name: Sara Esther

texts.es:
Sara belongs to the â€œLas Golondrinas 2â€ comunal bank. She lives in the CallerÃ­a district of the department of Ucayali. She is 58 years old, she is a teacher by profession, and has been separated from her husband for more than 20 years. She has 5 children, all of whom are independent. With her first loan of S/. 300.00 from Manuela Ramos, Sara decided to invest in buying and selling of lingerie and perfume. The business is located in her home. She also sews clothing people have ordered from her: trousers, bras, polo shirts for women and men, which she takes to the Educational Institution, where the students are the majority of her clients.

With this loan of S/. 1,000.00, which she will pay back in 4 months, she will buy 12 bra sets, 20 meters of cotton fabric, 10 meters of lace, 10 meters of elastic, and 20 meters of fabric for towels. Sara is happy because she feels fulfilled and she also feels young enough to take care of her grandchildren so that her children can use the time to work and continue studying in the educational centers in their town.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

Sara pertenece al Banco Comunal â€œLas Golondrinas 2â€ actualmente vive en el AA. HH. Paican Mz F Lt 20 del Distrito de CallerÃ­a en el Departamento de Ucayali tiene 58 aÃ±os. Es docente (profesora) de profesiÃ³n y estÃ¡ separada de su esposo desde hace mas de 20 aÃ±os. Tiene 5 hijos, todos independientes. Sara con el primer prÃ©stamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/.300 decidiÃ³ invertir en la compra y venta de lencerÃ­a y perfumerÃ­a. En la actualidad cuenta con su negocio de lencerÃ­a y perfumerÃ­a en su propio domicilio. al mismo tiempo que confecciona los pedidos: trusas, brasier, toallas polos de damas y caballeros para llevarlo a la InstituciÃ³n Educativa y entregar a sus colegas que son la mayorÃ­a de sus clientes. Con este prÃ©stamo de S/. 1,000 soles, el cual serÃ¡ pagado en 4 meses, iInvertirÃ¡ en la compra 1 docena de conjuntos de brasiers, 20 metros de tela de algodÃ³n, 10 metros de blonda 10 metros de elÃ¡stico, y 20 metros de tela para toallas. Sara se siente feliz por que ademÃ¡s que se siente realizada aun se siente joven para atender a sus nietos y asÃ­ sus hijos puedan aprovechar el tiempo para trabajar y seguir estudiando en los centros superiores de la localidad.

loan.use: To buy lingerie, fabric, and lace at wholesale price

loan.name: Amor Y Paz (Love & Peace) Groups 1&2

texts.en:
Elena is the busy mother of 6 children, ages 22, 24, 26, 28, 29 and 36. She also has two grandchildren, ages 3 and 10. She lives with her husband, daughter, and one grandchild. Elena has a small business making juice, which she then sells in front of her house. With the loan money, she is able to buy more fruit and cups so that she can sell more juice. Business can be hard sometimes when fewer people buy juice. The loan helps her overcome this vulnerability of her small business so that she can continue progressing.

Elena has successfully repaid 5 loans to Esperanza International and is now requesting her 6th loan. She hopes to continue growing her business so that she can better proviD. for her family. She wants all her children to be able to continue studying and to attend the university here. Already two of her children have finished college and she is very proud of them. She would also love to be able to afford her own house one day.

Note: This is a group loan for 10 people.

loan.use: To buy more fruit in order to make and sell more juice

loan.name: Lucinda Aura

texts.es:
Lucinda belongs to the â€œMujeres Audacesâ€ comunal bank, and lives in the Yarinacocha district of the department of Ucayali. She is 54 years old and is the mother of 4 children, all of whom are adults. Her husband is an electrician. Lucinda decided to invest in raising chickens and ducks, for which she requested a loan of S/. 300.00 from Manuela Ramos. She has the business in her home. She gets up every day at 5:30am to prepare breakfast and lunch so that her husband can go to work and then she takes care of her animals. In the afternoons from 3:00 to 6:00pm she sells her medicinal products.

With this loan of S/. 1,500.00, which she will repay in 5 months, she will buy 20 hens, 10 roosters, 12 ducks, and 10 jars of medicinal products. Lucinda continues to achieve success in life and she is very happy about the income she is able to generate for her family. She is grateful to Movimiento Manuela Ramos for the support they have provided her.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

Lucinda pertenece al Banco Comunal â€œMujeres Audacesâ€ domiciliada en Fonavi Mz 183 Lt S del Distrito D. Yarinacocha en el Departamento D. Ucayali. Tiene 54 aÃ±os, es madre D. 4 hijos todos mayores D. edad. Su esposo es electricista. Lucinda decidiÃ³ invertir en la crianza D. gallinas y patos, para solicitÃ³ un prÃ©stamo D. S/. 300.00 a Manuela Ramos. En la actualidad este negocio lo maneja en su propio domicilio, para lo cual se levanta todos los dÃ­as a las 5:30am para preparar el desayuno y el almuerzo para su esposo que sale a trabajar, luego se dedica al cuidado y crianza D. sus animales. AsÃ­ mismo por las tardes D. 3:00pm a 6:00pm sale a ofrecer y a repartir sus productos medicinales. Con este prÃ©stamo D. S/. 1,500 el cual serÃ¡ pagado en 5 meses, invertirÃ¡ en la compra D. 20 gallinas, 10 gallos, 12 patos y 10 potes variados D. productos medicinales. Lucinda sigue logrando muchos Ã©xitos en su vida y esta muy feliz por los ingresos que pueD. generar para su familia .agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por el respaldo brindado.

loan.use: To buy hens, roosters, and ducks. To buy medicinal products.

loan.name: Zoraida

texts.es:
Zoraida belongs to the comunal bank â€œMujeres Audacesâ€, located in the Yarina Cocha district of the department of Ucayali. She is 47 years old and is the mother of 3 children. Her husband is a teacher. With the first loan of S/. 300.00 that she received from Manuela Ramos, Zoraida invested in lingerie. She sells lingerie and she is also a teacher in Initial Education. In the morning she tends to her garden and in the afternoon she sews lingerie.

With this loan of S/. 1,500.00, which she will pay back in 5 months, she will buy elastic lace and fabrics by the kilo. Zoraida appreciates the support and payment plans offered by Manuela Ramos. She has high hopes to open a lingerie workshop and storage space so that she can continue to grow her business.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

La seÃ±ora Zoraida pertenece al Banco Comunal Mujeres Audaces, ubicado en el Jr. Dos de Mayo # 544 Distrito de Yarina Cocha del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 47 aÃ±os y es madre de 3 hermosos hijos, su esposo es docente (profesor). Zoraida con el primer prÃ©stamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300 invirtiÃ³ en lencerÃ­a. En la actualidad ella se dedica a la venta de lencerÃ­a, ella tambiÃ©n es docente en EducaciÃ³n Inicial, en las maÃ±anas se va trabajar es su jardÃ­n y en las tardes se pone a coser todo lo que es lencerÃ­a. Con este prÃ©stamo de S/.1,500 el cual serÃ¡ pagado en 5 meses, comprarÃ¡ blondas elÃ¡sticas y telas por kilo. Zoraida agradece el apoyo y las facilidades que le brinda Manuela Ramos, y ella tiene toda la esperanza de hacer su taller de lencerÃ­a y formar su bodega para que asÃ­ pueda seguir incrementando su negocio.

loan.use: To buy lace and fabric at wholesale price

loan.name: Lourdes

texts.es:
Lourdes belongs to the â€œLas Golondrinas 2â€ comunal bank and she lives in the CallerÃ­a district of the department of Ucayali. She is 61 years old, is a widow, and has 9 children, all of whom are adults. Her father, her 37 year-old single son, and 3 grandchildren live with her. The money that her son gives her from his taxi driver job isnâ€™t enough to make ends meet. Therefore, with the firs loan of S/. 300.00 from Manuela Ramos, she decided to invest in buying and selling fruits and ice creams. She currently runs the business from her home. Lourdes gets up very early in order to make breakfast for her father, son, and grandchildren before going to the market to make her purchases for the day. She then prepares lunch and tends to her business. She finishes her work at 9:00pm.

With this loan of S/. 1,000.00, which she will repay in 4 months, she will buy 200 oranges, 200 tangerines, and 200 ice creams. Each day is a challenge for Lourdes. She is very happy for the opportunity provided by Manuela Ramos to obtain a loan and thereby help her grandchildren, who are her greatest treasure.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

Lourdes pertenece al Banco Comunal â€œLas Golondrinas 2â€domiciliada en el Jr: espinar NÂº 371 del Distrito de CallerÃ­a en el Departamento de Ucayali tiene 61 aÃ±os. Viuda, con 9 hijos todos mayores. Su papÃ¡, su hijo soltero de 37 aÃ±os y sus 3 nietos menores viven con ella. El apoyo que le brinda su hijo que trabaja como motocarrista no le alcanza, es asÃ­ que con el primer prÃ©stamo de Manuela Ramos de S/ 300 decide invertir en la compra y venta de frutas y chupetes. En la actualidad cuenta con su negocio instalado en su propio domicilio. Lourdes se levanta muy temprano para preparar el desayuno para su padre, hijo y nietos, para luego ir al mercado y realizar sus compras del dÃ­a. Lourdes se da tiempo para preparar el almuerzo y atender su negocio. Termina su trabajo a las 9:00pm. Con este prÃ©stamo de S/. 1,000 el cual serÃ¡ pagado en 4 meses, invertirÃ¡ en la compra de 2 cientos de naranja, 2 cientos de mandarina, 1 ciento de tanchello y 2 cientos de chupetes. Cada dÃ­a, para Lourdes es un reto. Se siente muy feliz por la oportunidad que le brinda Manuela Ramos de recibir un prÃ©stamo e invertir y asÃ­ poder ayudar a sus nietos que son su mayor tesoro.

loan.use: To buy a variety of fruits at wholesale price and ice cream

loan.name: Meri

texts.es:
Meri makes a living selling fruit. She and her husband watch out for the well being of their 6 children and together have been able get all of them ahead and take care of the smaller ones. Her husband works outside of the home but when he is home and has the time he helps Meri in whatever she needs, especially in work that requires physical labor. Meri wishes to get the loan so that she can purchase goods for the improvement of the space where she sells her fruit.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva volunteer.

Meri se dedica a la venta de fruta, ella y su esposo velan por el bienestar de sus 6 hijos y juntos han sabido sacar adelante a todos y cuidar de los menores. Su esposo trabaja fuera de casa, pero cuando estÃ¡ y tiene el tiempo para hacerlo apoya en a Meri en lo que necesite, en especial en el trabajo de esfuerzo fÃ­sico.Meri desea obtener el prÃ©stamo que solicita para la compra de mercaderÃ­a, asÃ­ como para mejorar el espacio donde conserva la fruta que vende.

loan.use: Funds to invest in her fruit sales business.

loan.name: Kim QuyÃªn's Group

texts.vi:
Mrs. Ngo Kim Quyen (ID Number 03070052), born in 1973, would like to borrow 1,972,000VND to invest in woodcarving and crafting at home. She lives in Ngoc Loi, Duc Tu, Dong Anh, Ha Noi, Vietnam. Her husband is a carpenter while she is a seamstress earning stable daily income. She has 2 school-going children. Her family's average monthly income is 4,000,000VND (about 250USD). As she is responsible and friendly, she is voted as the group leader even though it is only the first time she joined a group to apply for loans. Her group also consists of:

Mrs. Nguyen Thi Thuan (ID Number 03070053), born in 1978, would like to borrow 1,972,000VND to invest in breeding pigs.

Mrs. P. Thi Hanh (ID Number 03070054), born in 1987, would like to borrow 1,972,000VND to invest in her scrap business.

Mrs. Nguyen Thi Tham (ID Number 03070055), born in 1983, would like to borrow 1,972,000VND to invest in woodcarving.

Mrs. Nguyen Thi Tuyet Nhung (ID Number 03070056), born in 1974, would like to borrow 1,972,000VND to invest in breeding chickens.

Mrs. Nguyen Thi Lua (ID Number 03070057), born in 1986, would like to borrow 1,972,000VND to purchase more begetables to sell.

The total amount requested is 725USD.

Translated from Vietnamese by Pham Yen Thanh, Kiva Volunteer.

loan.use: invest in woodcarving

loan.name: Ulugbek

texts.en:
H. Ulugbek is 27 years old. He is married with two children. Ulugbek is a very diligent and hard-working man. He uses his car to provide taxi services inside the city of Istaravshan. For the last four years the current business had been the main income for the family. It allows Ulugbek to improve the living conditions of his large family. In addition to his wife and children, he is also supporting his parents.

As with any business, it requires some investments from time to time. Thus, the car now needs to be fixed. For this purpose Ulugbek requests 600 USD for the term of 6 months. Ulugbek has proved himself to be a reliable client and promises to repay the current loan promptly. He thanks everyone for supporting him.

loan.use: Minor fixes of the vehicle used to provide taxi services.

loan.name: Halima

texts.en:
H. Halima is 51 years old. She and her husband have raised 5 children. The 2 eldest children are already married and the youngest is still under their care. Halimaâ€™s husband is retired on a pension. Halima's business is the main source of income for the family. She has been running her business for 35 years. Halima embroiders national skull-caps for men and women. She is really hard working. Halima gets up very early and goes to bed very late. Halima sells the skull-caps in the local market. Halima, as any Muslim, dreams to make Hadj (she wants to travel to Mecca). Halima wants to expand her business to meet this purpose.

She requests 750 USD for the term of 12 months. Halima plans on purchasing the fabric to embroider the national skull-caps. Halima has been a client of IMON since September 2007. She has shown herself to be a reliable client. Your support will really help her. Letâ€™s get behind this dedicated mother to make her dream become a reality.

loan.use: Purchase fabric to embroider the national skull-caps.

loan.name: Thi Khiem's Group

texts.vi:
Mrs. N. Thi Khiem (ID Number 03070006), born in 1974, would like to borrow 3,604,000VND to purchase more fruits and vegetables to sell. She has 2 school-going children. Everyday she sells fruits and vegetables in the market whiL. her husband works as a carpenter, earning stabL. income. Her family's average daily income is 150,000VND (about 9.50USD) so it is quite easy for her to repay the loan on an installment basis. Seeing the advantages of borrowing to increase income, she and other villagers have decided to apply for loans so that they can improve their families' economy and skills. Her group also consists of:

Mrs. L. Thi Thuoc (ID Number 03070009), born in 1964, would like to borrow 3,604,000VND to purchase a buffalo and invest in breeding ducks.

Mrs. H. Thi Chien (ID Number 03070010), born in 1965, would like to borrow 3,604,000VND to invest in her cafe.

Mrs.N. Thi Hoai (ID Number 03070046), born in 1985, would like to borrow 2,756,000VND to open a woodcarving shop.

Mrs. L. Thi Xuyen (ID Number 03070007), born in 1966, would like to borrow 3,604,000VND to invest in crafting.

Mrs. H. Thi Thao (ID Number 03070008), born in 1984, would like to borrow 3,604,000VND to invest in her souvenir shop.

Mrs. L. Kim Oanh (ID Number 03070011), born in 1959, would like to borrow 3,604,000VND to invest in her butcher shop.

The total amount requested is 1450USD.

Translated from Vietnamese by Pham Yen Thanh, Kiva Volunteer.

loan.use: Sellign fruits and vegetables

loan.name: Shahlo

texts.en:
N. Shahlo is 26 years old. She is married and is the loving mother of two children. Shahlo has been in business since 2000. She embroiders national skull-caps for men and women. Shahlo produces national skull-caps of various types. As a result, she has many clients and usually there are many orders. Her mother-in-law helps her with the business. Shahlo sells the skull-caps in the local market. The business is stable and enables Shahlo to contribute significant income to the family budget.

Shahlo requests 800 USD for the term of 12 months. The loan is required to purchase fabric for embroidering the national skull-caps. Shahlo thanks everyone for supporting her and promises to repay the loan in time.

loan.use: Purchase fabric for embroidering the national skull-caps.

loan.name: Islomjon

texts.en:
S. Islomjon is 39 years old. He is married with three children. Islomjon sells confectioneries such as candies, cookies, pastries, and fruit jelly. He has been in this business for about 6 years. Islomjon buys the goods from the neighboring country of Uzbekistan. He has been working with IMON for more than two years and has a positive credit history. The generated income allows Islomjon to support his large family. He also has dreams to educate all of his children with higher education.

Islomjon requests 800 USD for the term of 6 months. He is going to use the loan to purchase more confectioneries and expand his range of goods. He plans to use his income to purchase the private store as well as to educate his children. Islomjon thanks you for all of your support and promises to repay the loan in time.

loan.use: Expand the range of goods and purchase the private store

loan.name: Ahadjon

texts.en:
V. Ahadjon is 31 years old. He is married with three children. Ahadjon drives a taxi car. He has been engaged in this work for more than five years. The current business is the main source of income for his large family. In addition to his children and wife, he is also supporting his parents and brothers. Ahadjon has told us that this type of work requires a lot of effort. In order to obtain a decent wage he has to work at night, particularly in the early morning hours. Ahadjon has to get up early and go to bed late to try to not to lose any clients. Ahadjon has no higher education but he wants this for his children and younger brothers.

Ahadjon wants to fix his car in order to provide higher quality services and earn more to support his younger brothers with a higher education. Ahadjon requests 600 USD for the term of 6 months. He is planning to purchase spare parts for his car. The well-being of this family is in your hands. Help them by contributing to the growth of Ahadjonâ€™s business, and they will sincerely thank you.

loan.use: Purchasing the spare parts for the car.

loan.name: Rohat

texts.en:
Z. Rohat is 39 years old. She is married with 3 children. Rohat embroiders and sells national skull-caps for men in the local market. She has been in this business for 28 years. She learned this skill from her grandmother and now she is teaching her daughters. Rohat 's husband came from Russia and is currently unemployed. Her husband has heart disease and canâ€™t be engaged in hard labor. Rohat is supporting the family by herself with the help of her daughter, who is pictured on the photo.

Rohat wants to expand the business and generate income to improve the living conditions for her family. With this purpose she needs 950 USD for the term of 12 months. She plans to purchase fabric to embroider national skull-caps. Rohat is counting on your help. Be an important part of the growth of Rohatâ€™s business.

loan.use: Purchase the fabrics for embroidering the national skull-caps.

loan.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret A. is a 50 year old widow. She lives in Dunga with her seven children. Four are in school. Margaret buys traditional mats in bulk and supplies them to her customers at the market. She has applied for US $600 to further expand her business.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loan.use: For business expansion

loan.name: Thi Vinh's Group

texts.vi:
Mrs. T. Thi Vinh (ID Number 03110033), born in 1973, would like to borrow 3,180,000VND to expand her confectionery shop. Her family owns this small shop to meet the demand of all the local people so she always needs more capital to purchase more goods. Her husband works in a steel and iron factory with other men in the village. Her family's average monthly income is 4,000,000VND (about 250USD). However, this income is still not enough as she has to raise 3 school-going children. She has asked her neighbours to join her and form a group to apply for loans. She was voted to be the group leader. Her group also consists of:

Mrs. H. Thi Nha (ID Number 03110029), born in 1983, would like to borrow 3,180,000VND to purchase more wood to craft.

Mrs. Dam Thi Hang (ID Number 03110031), born in 1987, would like to borrow 3,180,000VND to invest in breeding pigs.

Mrs. T. Thi Luan (ID Number 03110032), born in 1985, would like to borrow 3,180,000VND to purchase more wood to craft.

Mrs. K. Thi Bao (ID Number 03110030), born in 1984, would like to borrow 3,180,000VND to purchase more wood to craft.

The total amount requested is 950USD.

Translated from Vietnamese by Pham Yen Thanh, Kiva Volunteer.

loan.use: invest in confectionery shop

loan.name: Thi Hien's Group

texts.vi:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi Hien (ID Number 03110006), born in 1979, would like to borrow 3,180,000VND to purchase more fruits and vegetables to sell. Her husband, like many other men in the village, is a factory worker in the steel and iron factory in Da Hoi, Dong Anh, Ha Noi city, thus earning stable income. Besides, Mrs. Hien sells fruits and vegetables in the market, so her family's average monthly income is about 3,500,000VND (about 225USD). She has 2 small children. With her current income, she can easily repay the loan on an installment basis. Her group also consists of:

Mrs. Nguyen Thi Su (ID Number 03110036), born in 1973, would like to borrow 3,180,000VND to invest in breeding pigs.

Mrs. Nguyen Thi Boc (ID Number 03110040), born in 1954, would like to borrow 1,972,000VND to purchase more fruits and vegetables to sell.

Mrs. Nguyen Thi Huong (ID Number 03110041), born in 1984, would like to borrow 1,972,000VND to invest in her cafe.

Mrs. Do Thi Mai (ID Number 03110037), born in 1977, would like to borrow 2,436,000VND to invest in her souvenir shop.

The total amount requested is 775USD.

Translated from Vietnamese by Pham Yen Thanh, Kiva Volunteer.

loan.use: Selling fruits and vegetables

loan.name: Vumilia

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 30 year-old Vumilia M.. She is married and has three children ages seven, three, and one. In 2005 Vumilia established her clothes business. Working 6 days a week and five to eight hours a day, she earns about US $100 every month from this business. Vumilia requires a loan in order to buy more clothes in bulk. In the future, Vumilia plans to expand her business. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment â€“ a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement

loan.use: To buy more clothes in bulk.

loan.name: Mwaji

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 26 year-old Mwaji M.. She is married and has one child, aged one. In 1999, Mwaji established her guest house business. Working seven days a week and sixteen to twenty-four hours a day, she earns about US $100 every month from this business. Mwaji has already received and successfully repaid one loan from SELFINA, and now requires a new loan in order to open another new business. In the future, Mwaji plans to invest in other businesses. She thanks you for your support.

loan.use: To open other new businesses.

loan.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 30 year-old Mariam M.. She is married and has two children aged 7 and 11. In 2002 Mariam established her small shop. Working seven days a week, and thirteen to sixteen hours a day, she earns about US $30 every month from this business. Mariam requires a loan in order to buy more cooking oil, sugar, soaps, salt, and other utensils. She thanks you for your support.

The Swahili word for this type of outside shop, or stall, is genge. A genge is usually a very basic structure made of wood, with a tin roof, which sells general items such as onions, tomatoes, chili, oil, rice, and dried fish. It is the kind of place local people usually send their children running to fetch something when they are in the middle of cooking the evening meal, and donâ€™t have time to go all the way to the market to buy the missing ingredient.

loan.use: To buy more cooking oil, sugar, soaps, salt, and other utensils.

loan.name: Em

texts.en:
Mrs. Em Y., 50, is a farmer and her husband is tuk-tuk taxi driver. Their combined income is $15 per day. The couple has five children, one of whom is married and lives in Toul Thnort Village, Kandal Province.

Y. owns a few oxen, which she uses to farm various kinds of fruit, including banana, jackfruit, and mango. Due to growing demand for her crops, Yeourn is requesting a loan of $700 to purchase wood. She will use the wood to build a stable for her oxen. The remainder of the loan will be used as working capital for her farming business. The loan will allow her to protect her business assets, and thereby increase the stability of her business.

About Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL): Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL) is one of Cambodia's largest and most successful microfinance institutions (MFIs). It is committed to helping its clients achieve their business goals by providing sound financial services, and thereby hopes to contribute to the social and economic development of Cambodia. HKL specifically targets women and poor families in order to help them achieve increased financial security and quality of life, by offering various credit programs and encouraging savings. In accordance with its mission and its commitment to operational and financial sustainability, HKL contributes part of its net profits every year to support social development in education and healthcare.

loan.use: To build a stable for her oxen

She thanks you for your support.

loan.name: Anna

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 32 year-old Anna N.. She is a widow and has two children aged 11 and 13. In 2001 Anna established her grocery business. Working seven days a week, and nine to twelve hours a day, she earns about US $130 every month from this business. Anna requires a loan in order to buy more stocks of beer and soft drinks. She thanks you for your support.

Her bar is a good place to chill with a beer if you manage to finish work early on a Friday afternoon. Itâ€™s the kind of place where you kick back on a plastic chair under a tree, with a local beer in hand, the aroma of roasting â€˜mishikakiâ€™ (kebabs made on an open fire) wafting around you, and talk to anyone and everyone who happens to wander by.

loan.use: To buy more stocks of beer and soft drinks.

loan.name: Yung

texts.en:
Mrs. Yung S., 37, sells perfume and similar goods and earns around $4 per day. She has been selling these kinds of goods for two years now. Her husband is a motorcycle taxi driver and earns around $2 per day. They live with six children in Toul Vihear Village, Kampong Cham Province. The family is also supported by her two daughters, one of whom is a face decorator and the other a tailor.

Now S. is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase more perfume to sell. She will use the remainder of the loan to purchase face decorating tools for her daughterâ€™s business.

About Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL): Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL) is one of Cambodia's largest and most successful microfinance institutions (MFIs). It is committed to helping its clients achieve their business goals by providing sound financial services, and thereby hopes to contribute to the social and economic development of Cambodia. HKL specifically targets women and poor families in order to help them achieve increased financial security and quality of life, by offering various credit programs and encouraging savings. In accordance with its mission and its commitment to operational and financial sustainability, HKL contributes part of its net profits every year to support social development in education and healthcare.

loan.name: Zunny

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 44 year-old Zunny M.. She is married, and has three children aged 14,17 and 24. She has two dependents who live with her because they are orphans. In 2004, Zunny established her Mama Lishe/cafÃ© business. Working seven days a week, and thirteen to sixteen hours a day, she earns about US $90 every month from this business. Zunny requires a loan in order to buy more kitchen utensils. In the future, Zunny plans to investing in other businesses. She thanks you for your support.
When you see a SELFINA entrepreneur whose business title is â€˜restaurantâ€™ or â€˜cafÃ©â€™, you may have to adjust your mental image of what that is. A local restaurant or cafÃ© in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches, with the sky as a ceiling. Such places donâ€™t even appear in the Lonely Planetâ€™s budget guide, but if youâ€™re looking for a cheap and tasty meal, and someone to have a chat with, this is the place to be. The food is all-local; rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough, made from maize flour), plantain (a cooked savoury banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of yummy sauces.

loan.use: To buy more kitchen utensils.

loan.name: Ket

texts.en:
Mrs. Ket C. is a broom-maker. Her husband transports the brooms to the local market to sell. Together they earn around $5 per day. The couple has three children, all of whom are in school. The family lives in Chmkar Samrong Village, Battambang Province.

Because their income is not sufficient to support the familyâ€™s expenses, she wants to pursue an additional business of oxen rental. Mrs. C. is requesting a loan of $300 to purchase an ox. She will then be able to rent out the ox to local farmers that need it to plow their fields, but cannot afford to purchase and take care of an ox on their own. By pursuing this business venture she hopes to increase her family income.

About Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL): Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL) is one of Cambodia's largest and most successful microfinance institutions (MFIs). It is committed to helping its clients achieve their business goals by providing sound financial services, and thereby hopes to contribute to the social and economic development of Cambodia. HKL specifically targets women and poor families in order to help them achieve increased financial security and quality of life, by offering various credit programs and encouraging savings. In accordance with its mission and its commitment to operational and financial sustainability, HKL contributes part of its net profits every year to support social development in education and healthcare.

loan.name: Tiessiri (Courage) Group

texts.fr:
The members of the Tiessiri group are married women with an average of 42 years of age and 7 children. They live with their husbands and children in polygamous families in Djinina, a village in the Fana area (Koulikoro region in Mali). The Tiessiri group trades various items: peanuts, cowpea flour, gathering products (shea tree), eggs, etc. This group is made up of relatives, neighbors and friends and has borrowed together from the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution for the past 3 years. This is their eighth group loan and all previous loans were refunded in time. The group members buy their peanut and cowpea supplies in Djinina and its surrounding villages. They each store their items in a joint store until they have sufficient quantities for sale. They usually carry out their cash sales on market days at the Fana and Marka coungo village stands to a mainly female customer base. For peanuts and cowpea supplies, their customers come to their village from many different areas such as Bamako, Koulikoro and SÃ©gou. With this loan they would like to buy 120 kilogrammes of peanuts and 20 kilogrammes of cowpea, bought at an average costs of 275FCFA and resold at 375FCFA. This will allow them to attain an average monthly income of 20,000FCFA which will be help them build their businesses.

Translated from French by Ivana Kostic, Kiva translator

loan.name: Fanta's Group

texts.fr:
The members of the Tiessiri 2 group are married women with an average of 28 years of age and 5 children. They live in polygamous families in the village of Sikouna 2 in the Fana area (Koulikoro region in Mali). The main activity of this group of women is the sale of wood for heating, charcoal (which they sell to peasants in Sikouna 2 and in surrounding villages) and various other items (gathering products, etc). They have a stock room for the charcoal or keep the wood in front of their joint sales stands. They generally sell the charcoal for cash or credit in the village or wholesale to buyers from big cities like SÃ©gou and Bamako, who also come to the village to buy cargoes of heating wood. Linked by professional and friendship ties, and very experienced in the business, the members of the group decided to request their first group loan from the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution. They intend to buy 50 charcoal bags and 3 loads of heating wood and plan to attain an average monthly income of 12500FCFA, which will be used for paying the interest on the loan, providing for the needs of their families and especially for building their business activities.

Translated from French by Ivana Kostic, Kiva Volunteer.

loan.use: Purchase of coal and heating wood

loan.name: Sesilia

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! Sesilia M., 35 is married, and has three children aged 6,10 and 13. In 2004, Sesilia established her tailoring business. Working seven days a week, and nine to twelve hours a day, she earns about US $260 every month from this business. Sesilia requires a loan in order to buy more material. She thanks you for your support.
SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facilities as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed uncreditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.
SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from the client, extending a loan to then, then leasing back the same equipment â€“ a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loan.use: To buy more material.

loan.name: Mwanaida

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 36-year-old Mwanaida S.. She is married and has five children. In 2008, Mwanaida established her small shop business. Working seven days a week, and nine to twelve hours a day, she earns about US $210 every month from this business. Mwanaida has already received and successfully repaid one loan from SELFINA and now requires a new loan in order to buy more soaps, salt, cooking oil, kerosene, lotion, and rice in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

The Swahili word for this type of outside shop, or stall, is "genge". A genge is usually a very basic structure made of wood, with a tin roof, where the vendor sells general items such as onions, tomatoes, chilli, oil, rice, and dried fish. It is the kind of place local people usually send their children running to fetch something when they are in the middle of cooking the evening meal and donâ€™t have time to go all the way to the market to buy the missing ingredient.

loan.use: To buy more soaps, salt, cooking oil, kerosene, lotion, and rice in bulk.

loan.name: Bertha

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! Bertha M., 44 is married, and has seven children aged between 12 and 27. In 1999, Bertha established her crops business. Working six days a week, and five to eight hours a day, she earns about US $50 every month from this business. Bertha has already received and successfully repaid two loans from SELFINA, and now requires a new loan in order to buy more crops in bulk. She thanks you for your support.
SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facilities as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed uncreditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.
SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from the client, extending a loan to then, then leasing back the same equipment â€“ a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loan.use: To buy more crops in bulk.

loan.name: Zaituni

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! Zaituni C., 33 is married, and has one child, aged 16. She has two dependents, who live with her because they are orphans. In 2006, Zaituni established her bread making (Bakery) business. She opens her business six days a week, and nine to twelve hours a day. Zaituni requires a loan in order to buy flower and cooking oil in bulk. She thanks you for your support.
SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facilities as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.
SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from the client, extending a loan to then, then leasing back the same equipment â€“ a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loan.use: To buy flower and cooking oil in bulk

loan.name: Enea

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! Enea Z., 31 is a widow, and has three children aged 3,6 and 12. In 1994, Enea established her clothes store. Working seven days a week, and nine to twelve hours a day, she earns about US $260 every month from this business. Enea requires a loan in order to buy more clothes for resale. She thanks you for your support.
SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facilities as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. loan.use: To buy more clothes for sale

loan.name: Modester K

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! Modester M., 28 is not married, and has no children. In 2003, Modester established her tailoring business. Working six days a week, and nine to twelve hours a day, she earns about US $190 every month from this business. Modester requires a loan in order to buy more material. She thanks you for your support.

loan.name: Edina J

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! Edina M., 36 is married, and has four children aged between 3 and 15. She has one dependent, who lives with her because she is an orphan. In 2004, Edina established her crops business. Working seven days a week, and nine to twelve hours a day, she earns about US $250 every month from this business. Edina requires a loan in order to buy more stock of maize in bulk. She thanks you for your support.
SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facilities as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

loan.name: Sophal

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophal S., 50, and her husband, Mr. Nha In, 50, who live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, were married in 1975 and have four children, three sons and one daughter. One of her children has full-time employment and the other three are enrolled in a local school.

Mrs. Sophal has been farming for over ten years. She grows melons, papayas, and corn in her farm not so far from her house. Her husband is a fisherman and does construction work when he has free time.

Sophal is requesting a loan of US$ 500 to purchase a boat for her husband's fishing, build a shelter for cows, and pay fees for renting more plots of land for farming.

loan.use: To purchase a boat for fishing, build a shelter for cows, and rent more plots of land for farming

loan.name: Eness Y

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! Enesy H., 35 is married, and has five children aged between 5 and 20. She has two dependents, who live with her because they are orphans. Enesy owns a small shop business. Working six days a week, and sixteen to twenty four hours a day, she earns about US $650 every month from this business. Enesy requires a loan in order to buy more general household goods for sale. She thanks you for your support.
SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed uncreditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.
SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from the client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment â€“ a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loan.use: To buy more home needs items.

loan.name: Mercy B

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! Mercy K., 23 is married, and has one child, aged 1. She has two dependents, who live with her because they are orphans. In 2004, Mercy established her tailoring business. Working seven days a week, and nine to twelve hours a day, she earns about US $20 every month from this business. Mercy has already received and successfully repaid one loan from SELFINA, and now requires a new loan in order to buy material and a sewing machine. She thanks you for your support.
SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facilities as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed uncreditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support; hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.
SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from the said client, extending a loan to them, then leasing back the same equipment â€“ a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loan.use: To buy material and a sewing machine.

loan.name: Ayesha's Group

texts.en:
Ayesha baji is the wife of N. M. and lives in Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan. She has six children and owns a two-room brick house where she has lived for 10 years. For the last five years, her husband has made a living as a watchman.

In addition to taking care of her children and doing housework, Ayesha baji produces and sells milk. She has successfully repaid three loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan), and is now applying for a new loan to buy an additional buffalo to increase her production of milk.

She is joined in her loan group by a four other people. Samina baji wants a loan to buy tools. Fatima baji, Zareena baji and Nusrat baji each want a loan to buy a buffalo for their own milk-producing businesses.

This is a group loan. Funds will be distributed among the members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loan.use: To expand their businesses

loan.name: Thuy Mai's Group

texts.vi:
Mrs. N. Thuy Mai, born in 1970 (ID Number: 10040024), wants to borrow 4,452,000VND to expand her hair salon. Beside this shop, she also sells drinks so she has a stable daily income. Her husband works in an advertising agent, earning stable income. Her family's average monthly income is 3,000,000VND (about 188USD). She likes to join this Fund because she can repay the loan on an installment basis. Her group also consists of:

Mrs. N. Thi Thu Huong (ID Number: 10040026), born in 1980, wants to borrow 3,604,000VND to invest in selling furniture and electronic products.

Mrs. N. Thi Thuy Ngan (ID Number: 10040025), born in 1982, wants to borrow 3,604,000VND to invest in a breakfast eatery.

Mrs. P. Thu N. (ID Number: 10040042), born in 1960, wants to borrow 2,204,000VND to invest in selling drinks.

Mrs. T. Thi Thu Ha (ID Number: 10040028), born in 1971, wants to borrow 4,028,000VND to invest in breeding pigs.

The total amount requested is 1,075USD.

Translated from Vietnamese by Pham Yen Thanh, Kiva Volunteer.
