loan.use: Invest in hair salon

loan.name: Parveen's Group

texts.en:
Parveen baji is the wife of H. Muhammad and lives in Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan. She and her husband have no children, but run a livestock business and treat their animals as if they were children. Parveen has successfully repaid four loans from Asasah (a micorofinance institute in Pakistan), and is now applying for a new loan to buy another buffalo so that she can produce and sell additional milk.

Parveen has three other people in her loan group. Aimna baji, Naseem baji, Zahoor baji and Amna baji each want a loan to buy a buffalo for their own milk-producing businesses.

This is a group loan. Funds will be distributed among the members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loan.use: To expand their businesses

loan.name: Ruqaiya's Group

texts.en:
Ruqaiya baji is the wife of M. Hanif and lives in Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan. She has ten children, and her husband is a land owner and farmer. Ruqaiya baji and her older daughter make a living sewing clothes and doing embroidery. Ruqaiya has successfully repaid four loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan). Now she is applying for a new loan for her husband, who wants to buy another buffalo to increase his production of milk.

Ruquiya is making this application with three other people. Hafizan baji, Jamila baji and Nusrat baji each want a loan to buy a buffalo for their own milk-producing businesses.

This is a group loan, and funds will be distributed among the members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loan.use: To expand their businesses

loan.name: Sharifan's Group

texts.en:
Sharifan baji is the wife of A. A. and lives in Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan. She has two sons and runs a livestock business, selling milk produced by the buffaloes she owns. Her husband is a land owner and farmer. Sharifan has successfully repaid one loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan), and has now applied for a second to buy another buffalo to expand her production of milk.

She is joined in her loan group by three other people. Naziran baji, another woman also named Naziran baji and Bashiran baji each want a loan to buy a buffalo so that they can expand their own milk production.

This is a group loan. Funds will be distributed among the members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loan.use: To expand their businesses

loan.name: Vang

texts.en:
Mrs. Vang N., 58, is a widow who lives in a small village across the Mekong River about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh. She has seven children, five sons and two daughters. Three of her children are married and live outside the family home. One son is a construction worker, another one sells silk products, and the last one weaves silk at home.

Since she was young, Mrs. Vang has been a silk weaver, a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh.

She is requesting a loan of US$ 600 to purchase silk materials for weaving.

loan.use: To purchase silk material for weaving

loan.name: Tito

texts.en:
Mr. Tito B. (not shown in the picture), 35, and his wife, Mrs. Chanthol Touch (shown in the picture with her son), 30, who live in a Phnom Penh suburb married in 2001 and have three sons.

Mr. Tito has been a driver for a factory for six years, while Mrs. Chanthol used to be a garment factory worker for many years but now she has stopped for a while to take care of her little son. Tito is requesting a loan of US$ 300 to add to his own money to purchase a motorcycle scooter to drive to work.

loan.use: To purchase a motorcycle scooter to drive to work

loan.name: Saira's Group

texts.en:
Saira baji is the wife of M. Aslam and lives in Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan. She is the mother of seven children, and her husband makes a living running a shop that sells schoolbags. Saira baji is an independent woman with her own milk-selling business. She has successfully repaid one loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan), and is now applying for a second loan to buy another buffalo to increase her production of milk.

There are four other people in her loan group. Zeenat baji , Bushra baji, Rehana baji and Zainab baji each want a use their loan to buy buffalo for their own milk-selling businesses.

This is a group loan. Funds will be distributed among the members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loan.use: To expand their businesses

loan.name: Sean

texts.en:
Mr. Sean S., 38, and his wife, Mrs. Sophal Chi, 29, who live in a small village off of National Road Two about twenty kilometers south of Phnom Penh, married in 1999 and have four children: one son and three daughters. Two of them are in local school.

Mr. Sean has been growing vegetables (see photo) for twenty years. His wife has been selling vegetables for seventeen years. She buys them from Ta Khmao market and some from her own farm and carries them on her motorcycle for re-sale in Phnom Penh.

Mr. Sean is requesting a loan of US$ 1000 to purchase a new motorcycle to replace their old one and to expand his wife's business.

loan.use: To purchase a new motorbike and expand their business selling vegetables

loan.name: Phoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Phoeun P., 51, is a widow with five children, two sons and three daughters, who lives in a small village across the Mekong River about twenty kilometers north of Phnom Penh. Three of her daughters are married and live outside the family home and the other two have full-time employment.

For eleven years, Mrs. Phoeun has been a silk weaver, a skill she learned from her neighbor. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. Now she is requesting a loan of US$ 400 to purchase silk material to continue her weaving business.

loan.use: To purchase silk materials for weaving

loan.name: Nasreen's Group

texts.en:
Nasreen baji is the wife of M.Rafique and lives in Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan. She is the mother of four sons and three daughters. For the last six years, her husband has made a living running a clothing-making business. Nasreen has successfully repaid one loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan), and is now applying for a new loan so her husband can buy more garments and expand his business.

Nasreen is applying for this loan with six other people. Shahida baji wants a loan for her gold business. Abida baji wants a loan to make additional garments to sell. Haleema baji wants to buy a thread-making machine. Tahira baji wants to buy supplies for her food stall. Umran baji wants to buy cloth to make handkerchiefs. Naseem baji wants to buy a machine to stitch borders on scarves and shirts.

This is a group loan. Funds will be distributed among the members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loan.use: To expand their businesses

loan.name: Keang

texts.en:
Mrs. Keang S.,39, and her husband, Mr. Mengtich Ly, 49, who live in a small village about seventeen kilometers south of Phnom Penh, married in 1990 and have four children: two sons and two daughters. Three of them are in local school.

Mrs. Keang has been selling vegetables for two years. She buys them from Ta Khmao market for re-sale at the market in Phnom Penh. Her husband has been a motor taxi driver for fifteen years. His motorcycle scooter is very old and breaks down very often.

So, Keang is requesting a loan of US$ 1200 to purchase a new motorcycle to replace the old one for her husband to drive as a motor taxi and to expand her business.

loan.use: To purchase a new motorbike for running a motor taxi and expand business of selling vegetables

loan.name: Louy

texts.en:
Mrs. Louy L., 55, and her husband, Mr. Khoun Khem, 58, who live in a small village across the Mekong River about twenty kilometers north of Phnom Penh, married in 1971 and have eight children, four sons and four daughters. Four of their children are married and live outside the family home. One son has full-time employment, one is a fisherman, one daughter weaves silk, and the youngest one is in school.

Since she was young, Mrs. Louy has been a silk weaver, a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. Mr. Khoun has been a fisherman since he was young as well.

Now Louy is requesting a loan of US$ 500 to add to her own money for building a house for her daughter who got married and is in the process of building her house.

loan.use: To add to her own money for building a house for her daughter

loan.name: Samnang

texts.en:
Mr. Samnang B., 41, and his wife, Mrs. Chanthorn Mob, 43, who live in a small village across the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, married in 1990 and have five children, four sons and one daughter. The first son does construction work with his father, and two other children are in local school.

Mr. Samnang has been a mason for sixteen years. He does his work in the village and nearby province while his wife stays at home taking care of their children. The couple is in the process of building their new house and they need a loan to finish it.

Samnang is requesting a loan of US$ 500 to make a stair rail and wall of the house and fill in the ground.

loan.use: To build a stair rail and wall of their house and fill in the ground

loan.name: Jamila's Group

texts.en:
Jamila baji is the wife of U. and lives in Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan. She is the mother of six children and runs a thread-making business. Her husband runs a power loom. She is applying for a loan to buy another power loom for her husband.

She is making this loan with four other people. Kosar baji wants a loan for her own power loom business. Naseem baji wants a loan for her business selling utensils. Farhat baji wants a loan to buy land. Sajida baji wants a loan to buy more supplies for her carpet-making business.

This is a group loan. The funds will be distributed among the members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loan.use: To expand their businesses

loan.name: Run

texts.en:
Mrs. Run K., 43, and her husband, Mr. Yul San, 47, who live along National Road Number Five about eighteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, married in 1986 and have four children, two sons and two daughters. Two of their children have full-time employment, one is in school, and the youngest one stays at home.

Mrs. Run and her husband have been selling firewood for eight years. Mr. Yul travels to buy their goods from other provinces for Run to sell at their house. The business is running very well and the couple needs more money to expand their business.

So, Run is requesting a loan of US$ 1000 to purchase a machine for cutting firewood and to buy more firewood for re-sale.

loan.use: To purchase a machine for cutting firewood and buy more firewood for re-sale

loan.name: Sarum

texts.en:
Mr. Sarum K. (shown in the picture with his mother), 32, and his wife, who live on an island in the MeK. River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, married in 2000 and have two daughters. Sarum is living with his mother who is a silk weaver.

Since he was married, Mr. Sarum has been a silk weaver, a skill he learned from his mother, and his wife is a silk weaver as well. The couple sells their finished products to the middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh.

He is requesting a loan of US$ 1000 to purchase silk materials for his weaving business.

loan.use: To purchase silk material for weaving

loan.name: Rani's Group

texts.en:
Rani baji is married to M. and lives in the city of Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan. She has five children, three of whom are married. Another makes a living driving a donkey cart. Her husband sells utensils, a job he has had for the last five years. Rani has successfully paid back a loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan), and is applying for a new loan to buy more utensils for her husband to sell.

She is making this application with four other people. Abida baji wants a loan to buy a sewing machine. Maqsoodan baji wants a loan to buy more material for her carpet-making business. Rashidan baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo so she can sell its milk. Nazmin baji wants a loan to buy additional inventory for her grocery shop. Shamim baji wants a loan for her small milk-selling business.

This is a group loan. Funds will be distributed among the members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loan.use: To expand their businesses

loan.name: Najma's Group

texts.en:
Najma baji is the wife of M. A. and lives in the city of Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan. She is the mother of eight children, and owns a two-room brick house. For the past five years, her husband has made a living selling fruit. Najma has successfully completed her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan). Now she is applying for a new loan to buy more fruits for her husband to sell.

She is making this application with three other people. Jamila baji wants a loan to buy more fruit to sell from her stand. Bilquis baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo so she can sell its milk. Razia baji wants a loan to buy more material for her embroidery business.

This is a group loan. Funds will be distributed among the members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loan.use: To expand their businesses

payment.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 22, 2008)

loan.name: Samina's Group

texts.en:
Samina baji is the wife of M. U. and lives in the city of Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan. She owns a two-room brick house where she has lived for the last six years. She has three sons. Her husband has a food business and also runs a drink stand. Samina has successfully repaid three loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan), and has applied for a fourth loan to buy more material for her husbandâ€™s food business.

She is applying for this loan with three other people. Shahida baji wants a loan to buy more items to sell from her fruit stand. Nusrat baji wants a loan to buy more inventory for her grocery shop. Sakina baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo so she can sell its milk..

This is a group loan. Funds will be distributed among the members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loan.use: To expand their businesses

loan.name: Zakia's Group

texts.en:
Zakia baji is the wife of R. A. and has lived in a two-room brick house in Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan for the last 10 years. She has three daughters and one son, all of whom are enrolled in a local school. Zakia baji sews clothes and does domestic chores for a living. Her husband runs a grocery store. She has successfully paid back three loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan) and is now applying for a fourth loan to buy more inventory for her husbandâ€™s shop.

She is applying for her loan with several other people. Salma baji wants a loan to buy more materials for her wood business. Bushra baji wants a loan to buy more tents for her tent-service business. Rubina baji and Tahira baji want a loan to buy more fruit for their fruit-selling businesses.

This is a group loan. The funds will be distributed among the members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loan.use: To expand their businesses

loan.name: Naseem's Group

texts.en:
Naseem baji is the wife of M. and lives in the city of Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan. She has lived in a two-room brick house for the last 22 years, and is the mother of four sons. Her oldest son works in a factory. The next oldest son raises buffalos. Her younger children are enrolled in a local neighborhood school. Her husband is a land owner who farms for a living.

Naseem baji contributes to the family income by running a milk business. She has successfully repaid three loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan) and is applying for a new loan to buy a buffalo to expand her small company. She is making this application with two other people. Sharifan baji also wants a loan to buy a buffalo for her milk business. Parveen baji wants a loan to buy wood to resell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loan.use: To expand their businesses

loan.name: Rani's Group

texts.en:
Rani baji is married to A. M. and lives in Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan. She owns a two-room brick house and has no children. Her husband runs a livestock business, and has been in this profession for the last 10 years. Rani has successfully repaid three loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan). Now she is applying for a new loan to buy a buffalo to raise and resell.

She is making this application with several other people. Bashiran baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo for her milk business. Shafqat baji wants a loan to buy wheat to resell. Amna baji wants a loan to buy more inventory for her grocery store. Iram baji wants a loan to buy more supplies for her fruit business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loan.use: To expand their businesses

loan.name: Habijan's Group

texts.en:
Habijan baji is the wife of B. A. and lives in the city of Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan. She has lived in a two-room brick house for the last 35 years, and is the mother of four children: two sons and two daughters. Her husband is a land contractor (he rents land and farms it). He has worked in this area for the last 25 years. Habijan has successfully repaid three loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan) and is now applying for a loan to rent land for her husband.

She is applying for this loan with several other people. Sugran baji wants a loan to rent land. Bashiran baji wants a loan to buy wood for her furniture business. Sugran baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo to resell. Parveen baji wants a loan to buy inventory for her grocery store.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loan.use: To expand their businesses

Established for five years in the AgoÃ¨ district, she sells charcoal near the marketplace of this district. She wishes to include commerce in corn and yams and is requesting this initial loan to do so. The loan would be used to buy 40 yam tubers and 5 sacks of corn in order to satisfy her customers better.

loan.name: Dorothy

texts.en: Dorothy is a forty-year-old mother of six children. She lives in Kisumu, Kenya with her family. She is the proprietor of a food kiosk established in 1999. She specializes in making chapattis, the local favorites, which she serves with boiled beans and green lentils to her clients. She also makes mandazis, normally served with tea. Her business has flourished over the last nine years and this she attributes to four microfinance loans received from KMET/KIVA. She now requires an additional US $800 for expansion.

loan.use: Expand her business

He opened a sales center for school supplies in the AgoÃ¨ district. The objective for which he created this center is to be near the people in his district, because there is no bookstore in the area. During this time of vacations, the price of school supplies has diminished a little, and he wishes to take advantage of this chance to stock up on books and notebooks before school starts. To do so, he is requesting this loan to buy 5 boxes of notebooks and 80 books for primary school. He will thus be able to earn a good income.

loan.name: Anna

texts.en: Anna is a 60-year-old widow who supports six children in her household. She runs a business on a small scale. Anna owns ten housing units which she rents out at US $12 a month. She is able to generate US $804 in rent a month. She has received and fully paid US $1587 loans from KMET/ KIVA. She has currently applied for US $800 to enable her to improve the condition of her houses.

loan.use: House renovation

loan.name: Christine

texts.en: Christine is a 34-year-old hard-working entrepreneur. She is married and lives with her husband and 4 children in Kisumu, Kenya. She has been in the second-hand clothing business for many years. She specializes in selling both men's and women's clothes. She also runs a tailoring and dressmaking shop. Christine, who has received three loans from KMET/Kiva, now requires US $800 to boost her tailoring business and also add more stock of second-hand clothes.

loan.use: Invest in her tailoring shop

Ms. Yawa Dzidedi K. was born in 1958 in KÃ©vÃ©, a town located 40 km from LomÃ©. She is married to Mr. Kossi DOUHO and has two children. Mrs. Massan E. was born in 1971. Her main business is processing manioc flour. Married and the mother of five children, she has mastered her trade. A good manager, she has been successful in combining other small businesses. With the revenues from her business, she has been able to help manage the family expenses. An honest woman, she has successfully managed and paid back her first loan without defaulting. loan.name: Nelly

texts.es:
Nelly is a good client, very hard-working. She has three children to support; her husband is a driver. She works from very early in the morning until very late at night, in different parts of the city of El Alto. She's an unassuming woman and very commited to working because she wants her children to know that with a little sacrifice one can get ahead in life in an honest way. loan.name: Akoua

texts.fr:
Born in 1951, Mrs. Akoua A. is married to a tailor. She works in agriculture, which ultimately does not allow her, along with her husband, to manage the household expenses for their five children. With the help of her husband, she has opened a small general food store. She has already paid back one loan successfully. Currently, she is asking for a new loan that will allow her to stock her store with soap, dough, tin cans, and other goods demanded by her clients.

Translated from French by Lucia Franzese, Kiva volunteer.

loan.name: Mario

texts.es:
Mario is a milk producer for the PIL company; he also works in bovine artificial insemination. His wife sells potato and potato flour products that they themselves produce on their land and they sell them to different markets in nearby communities. With these jobs they are able to support their four children, all of whom are dependent on their parents.

Mario lives in a community called Huayrocondo-Battallas (located two and a half hours from La Paz city).

The loan will be used to buy a medium-sized cow to increase milk production, and the milk will be then sold to the PIL company. This will increase his income by about 15%.

This is Marioâ€™s second loan with Impro, and the good payment history enables him to qualify for another loan. Mario has been a client of IMPRO since April, 2007.

loan.name: Olga Maria

texts.es:
Olga is a humble client of scarse resources who supports her three school-age children. Her husband helps her with his income. She works in a cellular phone store, which is her only job, since she was unable to have other opportunities to improve her quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer.

loan.use: Purchase a calling center, as well as phone cards to sell.

loan.name: Alma Rosa

texts.es:
Alma began her business to provide a better future for her 2 children. She wasnâ€™t able to find work and wanted to have her children nearby in order to take care of them, so she began a business in 2006 selling food. She sold food to her neighbors and thanks to her great cooking she gained clients and is making good income.

She needs a loan for US$250, which will be repaid in 3 months, to buy ingredients to make food and be able to sell more in order to earn a greater income. With your help Alma will be successful.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loan.name: Abravi

texts.fr:
Born in 1978, Mrs. Abravi E. is a seller of foodstuffs (rice, beans). Married and the mother of three children, she helps manage the family expenses thanks to the revenues from her sales. She is asking for a loan that will allow her to purchase sacks of rice, beans and other items to prepare in order to enlarge her business, better serve her clients, and ultimately strengthen her business.

Translated from French by Lucia Franzese, Kiva volunteer.

loan.name: Juan German

texts.es:
Juan began his business in order to support his children and give them an education as he wishes a better quality of life for them. He began his grocery store in 2006 with little merchandise, and little by little he bought more items that people requested, until he was able to fully establish his store.

He needs a loan for US$250, which will be repaid in 3 months, to stock merchandise and be able to sell more, thereby improving his income. With your help Juan will be able to grow his business.

loan.name: Amuda Layi Group

texts.en: Sahadatu is the leader of a six-member group. She is a 70-year-old wife and the mother of three children. The group consists of five women and one man. They are very hard-working and resourceful family providers. They trade in various commodities like kola nuts, palm kernel oil, food stuffs, clothing, etc. to earn a living. Their major challenge has to do with funds to grow these businesses to the expected levels to redeem their families from poverty. They believe the loan will impact their businesses to bring a transformation in their family well-being. Their common hope is to be able to increase savings to provide their children with quality education. They want to use the loan to procure an increased stock of kola nuts, clothing, food stuffs, palm kernel oil, etc. They belong to the group called â€˜Amuda Layi Trust Groupâ€™. Members in this group agree to guarantee for one another as a social collateral and assist one another to repay the loan.

loan.use: To procure an increased stock of kola nuts, food stuffs, palm kernel oil, etc.

loan.name: Fuente De Esperanza (Source Of Hope) Group 4

texts.en:
Delfina is the president of the Â¨Fuente de EsperanzaÂ¨ Bank of Hope and definitely holds sway in her community. She lives in a very poor community surrounded by sugar cane in a rural area outside of El Seibo. Delfina is 77 years old and lives with her husband. She has six children and six grandchildren who now live in the neighboring towns of Higuey and La Romana.

Delfina sells clothing, mainly shirts, to the people in her community. She has successfully repaid two loans to Esperanza International and is now requesting a third. With the loan money, she hopes to open a small Â¨colmadoÂ¨ (mini grocery-store) at the side of her house.

Note: This is a group loan for 5 people.

loan.use: To open a mini grocery-store at the side of her house.

loan.name: Liliana

texts.es:
Liliana has worked for years in a well-known popular market in the city. She is the mother of 5 school-aged children. She earns her income from selling breakfasts in the morning and teas in the afternoons. Her home is located in El Alto city. Every morning she gets up very early to go in to the city, accompanying her two small daughters as they are too young to be left alone. With her loan she will buy consumables to sell and thereby be able to give a better education to her children.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

La Sra. Liliana, trabaja hace aÃ±os en un conocido mercado popular de la ciudad, es madre de 5 hijos en edad escolar, ingreso es de la venta de desayunos en las maÃ±anas y te por la tarde Su domicilio se encuentra en la ciudad de El Alto, cada maÃ±ana se levanta muy temprano para bajar a la ciudad en compaÃ±Ã­a de sus dos pequeÃ±as hijas ya que son muy pequeÃ±as para dejar las solas. Con el crÃ©dito comprara insumos para sus ventas y asi poder dar una mejor educaciÃ³n a sus hijos.

loan.use: Purchase consumables

loan.name: Afi

texts.fr:
Born in Ghana in 1968, Mrs. Afi K. is married and the mother of one child. Her main business is to sell cakes made with a manioc base. As she is very driven, she manages her business well. She is asking for a loan that will allow her to purchase a large quantity of manioc and oil, as well as start other businesses in order to increase her revenues and better provide for the needs of her family.

Translated from French by Lucia Franzese, Kiva volunteer.

NÃ©e au Ghana en 1968, Madame K. Afi est mariÃ©e et mÃ¨re dâ€™un (1) enfant. Son activitÃ© principale est la vente de gÃ¢teau fabriquÃ© Ã  base du manioc. TrÃ¨s dynamique, elle gÃ¨re bien ses activitÃ©s. Elle sollicite un financement qui va lui permettre dâ€™acheter en grande quantitÃ© du manioc et de lâ€™huile et aussi initier dâ€™autres activitÃ©s afin dâ€™augmenter ses revenus et mieux subvenir aux besoins de sa famille.

loan.use: Buy manioc to produce cake

loan.name: Maria Luisa

texts.es:
MarÃ­a Luisa began her business helping her husband and improving their quality of life. As he didnâ€™t have a job, she helped him by beginning to sell tamales. She began her business in 2005 with the money she had saved and decided to invest in the ingredients to make tamales, and she began to sell them.

She needs a loan for US$250, which will be repaid in 3 months, to buy ingredients and be able to improve her sales and make her business successful. With your help she will be able to accomplish her goals.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

Ella necesita un prestamo por US $250 que pagara en 3 meses para comprar materia prima y poder mejorar sus ventas y salir adelante. Con tu ayuda ella podra lograrlo.

loan.use: Purchase ingredients to make tamales

loan.name: Abra

texts.fr:
Mrs. Abra F. was born in Lonyo in the prefecture of Zio in 1949. She is married and the mother of six children. Thanks to her revenues from her agriculture business, she is able to help manage the household expenses. She has a lot of experience in agricultural work and has mastered the production of corn and other crops. For this reason, she is asking for a loan to finance the expansion of her cultivable land. She will therefore increase her revenues to improve the living conditions for her family.

Translated from French by Lucia Franzese, Kiva volunteer.

Madame F. Abra est nÃ©e Ã  Lonyo (P/Zio) en 1949. MariÃ©e et mÃ¨re de six (6) enfants, elle arrive Ã  contribuer aux charges du foyer grÃ¢ce aux revenus tirÃ©s de son activitÃ© : lâ€™agriculture. Elle a beaucoup dâ€™expÃ©rience dans les travaux agricoles et maÃ®trise bien la production du maÃ¯s et autres cultures. Ainsi, sollicite t-elle un financement qui va lui permettre dâ€™Ã©tendre sa superficie cultivable. Elle pourra donc augmenter ses revenus pour amÃ©liorer les conditions de vie de sa famille.

loan.use: Expand cultivable land

loan.name: Natalya

texts.en:
Natalya is an entrepreneur from Nikopol where she owns a small grocery sales business. She is married with two sons. Natalya has a vending facility in a favorable location. Competition in this sphere of trade is relatively low. Natalya has been in business for a year. Her monthly income is about $500.

Natalya's business has a very good reputation in the market. She is very determined and strongly believes best results are gained by focused and sustained efforts, which is why she always presses on to achieve even bigger success in her business. Natalya is hoping to grow her business and make all her dreams come true. She is requesting a loan of 3500 Grivnas to increase her turnover capital.

loan.use: To increase turnover capital

loan.name: Tatyana

texts.en:
Tatyana is married and has two children. She successfully manages a little shop where she sells a variety of non-perishable grocery items such as drinks, household chemicals, clothing and footwear items. Tatyana has been involved in this type of business for more than 3 years. Through her perseverance and hard work she has been able to reinvest profits into her business and see it develop. Today her total net income amounts to $500 a month and she has about $3000 invested in inventory.

Tatyana's enthusiasm and the relationships she has built with her customers show that she is doing what she does best --cheerfully serving others. She has created a loyal base of customers who always try to stop by and purchase from her shop. She is a warm and communicative woman, who looks forward to what the future holds. Her desire is to be a help to her husband as they both strive to support and raise their children. Tatyana is requesting a loan of 4560 Grivnas to purchase variety of grocery items in bulk. She believes that this will eliminate the need for her to buy products as often and therefore save her some money on transportation and unloading.

loan.use: To increase turnover capital

loan.name: Valentina

texts.en:
Valentina lives in Nikopol and runs her business located in the Central Market. She became an entrepreneur only six months ago. She was in need of money and bravely started her small venture selling cosmetics and body care items. Valentina presently makes about $200 in profit each month.
Valentina is planning to use the loan of 3000 Grivnas ($US675) to increase her seasonal stock. She is always ready to work inventively to realize her personal and financial goals. We believe the client has the determination to make her business expand following the route of success and providing a supplemental income to her household.

loan.use: To increase her inventory.

loan.name: Ami

texts.fr:
Born in 1977, Mrs. Ami K. is a farm worker who loves growing corn. The mother of two children, she is able to contribute toward the household expenses thanks to her earnings. She is very attached to growing corn, which is of major importance to their everyday diet and is a source of income for them. A real go-getter, she manages her business activities very well, and is requesting financing to enable her to increase the area she cultivates and therefore her income. In this way she will have sufficient means to make a greater contribution toward improving the family's living conditions.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer.

NÃ©e en 1977, Madame K. Ami est une cultivatrice qui aime la culture du maÃ¯s. MÃ¨re de deux (2) enfants, elle arrive Ã  contribuer aux charges du mÃ©nage grÃ¢ce Ã  ses revenus. Elle est trÃ¨s attachÃ©e Ã  la culture du maÃ¯s qui a une importance capitale dans leur habitude alimentaire et est source de revenu dans le milieu. TrÃ¨s battante, elle gÃ¨re bien ses activitÃ©s et sollicite un financement qui va lui permettre dâ€™augmenter sa superficie cultivÃ©e et de facto augmenter ses revenus. Ainsi, elle pourra avoir les moyens suffisants pour plus contribuer Ã  lâ€™amÃ©lioration des conditions de vie de la famille.

loan.use: To increase the size of her cultivable land

loan.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria is married with two teenage kids. She runs a small business selling children's clothing in the local market of Vasilyevka. She is a skillful manager who knows how to survive in a competitive market economy environment. Victoria has been in this business for over 10 years. Currently, she has about $3000 in inventory.
Victoria's consistency, perseverance and commitment to her business have ensured the growth and success of her small venture. She always treats people with respect, which is one of the most effective methods of providing her business with a solid foundation. She also has a unique ability to reach and maintain the right customers. Moreover, Victoria is always willing to help her clients with tips, which oftentimes are much needed.
At the moment she is requesting a loan of 1000 Grivnas ($US350) to increase the inventory for sale in her kiosk.
Note: This is a short term "express" loan that will be repaid in a month.

loan.use: To grow her trade

loan.name: Ramon

texts.es:
RamÃ³n began his business to improve and offer a better quality of life for his family. He wasnâ€™t able to find good work that would give him the opportunity to improve and be able to have better income for his family, so he decided to begin his own business in 2002, selling tools and scrap metal. He began with little merchandise, and upon seeing that he could earn an income he continued working hard to make his business successful.

He needs a loan for US$250, which will be repaid in 3 months, to buy merchandise and be able to continue with his business. With your support RamÃ³n will be successful.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

Ramon inicio el negocio para tratar de mejorar y poder darle mejor calidad de vida a su familia. En ese momento no encontraba un buen trabajo que le diera la oportunidad de mejorar y poder tener mejores ingresos para su familia, por lo que decidio emprender su propio negocio, comenzo en el aÃ±o 2002 con la venta de herramienta y chatarra, con muy poca mercancia, al ver que si le podia redituar siguio esforzandose para sacar adelante su negocio.

El necesita un prestamo por US $250 que pagara en 3 meses para comprar mercancia y poder seguir con su negocio. Con tu apoyo Ramon saldra adelante.

loan.use: Purchase merchandise

loan.name: Alexander

texts.en:
Alexander is married and has grown children who live in a different country. He lives in Vasilyevka, Ukraine. Alexander runs a small business selling general goods in the local market. His kiosk is located on the main market aisle where there are many customers every day. Alexander has been in business for over seven years. His wife actively helps him with operations. Currently, his monthly gross income is about $2,000.
Alexander is a high achiever and a consistent entrepreneur who is very knowledgeable about the market environment. His professional skills and perseverance have helped to ensure rapid growth and success of his business.
Alexander is requesting a loan for 3000 Grivnas ($US675) to increase the assortment of inventory in his kiosk. He is hoping that this loan will help his venture grow and generate extra profits. We believe that Alexander's ability to identify tasks critical to business success and set up a system for accomplishing them will allow him to continue growing in the sphere of private entrepreneurship.
Note: this is a short term "seasonal" loan that will be repaid in two months.

loan.use: To purchase additional inventory

loan.name: Confort

texts.fr:
Mrs. Confort G. was born in 1977. Having abandoned school at a very young age, she has devoted herself to farming. Specializing in growing cassava, she has mastered this art very well, and it provides her with the minimum amount of income required to meet the needs of her five children. She is requesting financing in order to increase the size of her cassava field so that she can boost her income and make a greater contribution towards improving the living conditions of her family.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer.

Madame G. Confort est nÃ©e en1977. Abandonna trÃ¨s tÃ´t ses Ã©tudes, elle sâ€™est donnÃ©e Ã  lâ€™agriculture. La culture du manioc Ã©tant sa spÃ©cialitÃ©, elle maÃ®trise trÃ¨s bien ce domaine qui lui procure le revenu minimum pour subvenir aux besoins de ses cinq (5) enfants. Elle sollicite un financement qui lui servira Ã  agrandir son champ de manioc afin dâ€™augmenter ses revenus pour mieux contribuer Ã  lâ€™amÃ©lioration des conditions de vie de sa famille.

loan.use: To increase the size of her cassava field

loan.name: Mariya

texts.en:
Mariya is married with two grown children. She owns a small kiosk selling socks and underwear in downtown Nyzhniv, Ivano-Frankivsk region. Close proximity to a busy central market makes it a very favorable location for business growth. Mariya offers low prices and good quality of inventory. Currently, she earns about $700 monthly income from her business.
Mariya has been working in this business for two years. She used to work as a secretary in Nyzhniv town administration office but she faced some problems with her health and had to quit her job. This is how she took a risk and launched her own venture selling clothing.
Hard-work and tenacity have helped her enterprise reach sustainability and success. Mariya would like to get a loan for 3000 Grivnas ($US675) to purchase 50 sets of underwear and socks. The extra supply of inventory will help her generate additional income. Mariya is hoping that increased sales activity will generate the necessary funds to sustain her business as well as to meet her family's needs.
Note: This is a short term "seasonal" loan that will be repaid in two months.

loan.use: To purchase 50 sets of underwear and socks.

loan.name: Irina

texts.en:
Irina is married with two daughters. She owns a small business and works in the central city market of Pavlograd, in the so-called Trade Gallery. Irina sells women's teenage clothing items. All her merchandise is very high quality and can meet varying customers' demands. Irina started her business 11 years ago. Currently, she has about $9000 invested in inventory. Her monthly income is about $1000.
Irina has proved to be a very reliable client. Her venture has been growing consistently into a stable and sustainable business. Irina likes to move on and not just be satisfied with present successes. She is hoping additional funding will help her re-stock her inventory and construct a new vending kiosk in the same market. She is requesting a 3000 Grivna ($US675) loan to implement these goals.
Note: This is a short term "seasonal" loan that will be repaid in two months.

loan.use: To purchase more stock for clothing sales.

loan.name: Socorro Patricia

texts.es:
Patricia began her business to earn a living and provide a better quality of life for her children. She decided to begin the business as her husbandâ€™s income didnâ€™t cover their household expenses. Over a year ago she began selling telephone equipment to her neighbors and acquaintances, little by little growing her customer base and they recommended her to others and now she earns a good income.

She needs a loan of US $500, which will be repaid in 6 months, to buy more equipment. With your help Patricia will be successful.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

Patricia inicio el negocio para prosperar y darle mejor calidad de vida a sus hijos. Ella decidio iniciar su negocio ya que con el sueldo de su esposo no les alcanzaba para cubrir los gastos familiares. Comenzo hace mas de uÃ±o vendiendo equipos telefonicos con sus vecinas y familiares, poco a poco logro hacer cartera de clientes y ellos la recomendaron con mas gente hasta lograr mejorar sus ingresos.

Ella necesita un prestamo por US $500 que pagara en 6 meses para poder comprar mas equipos, con tu apoyo Patricia saldra adelante.

loan.use: Purchase telephone systems to resell

payment.comment: Correction due to underpayment for business #57382

loan.name: Samuel Trust Group

texts.en: Esther S. is a divorced wife with five children. She is a 54-year-old trader of used bed spreads. She is the leader of a seven-member group with six females and a single male. These are the breadwinners of their families. They all have children who are currently in school. They are engaged in the trading of food stuffs, clothing, cosmetics, groceries, etc. as the source of livelihood for their homes. However, they barely make enough income to meet the demands of their households due to inadequate working capital. Their common dream is to see their businesses grow one day to enable them to improve the living conditions of their families. They believe this loan will help them to inject more capital into their businesses to materialize this dream. They belong to the group called Samuel Trust Group. Members in this group agree to guarantee for one another as a social collateral and assist one another to repay the loan.

loan.use: To purchase increased stock of food stuffs, groceries, clothes, cosmetics, etc.

loan.name: Rodolfo

texts.es:
Mr. M. is asking for a second loan from Kiva. His first loan was used to buy merchandise for his grocery store. He has repaid his first loan.

His business doesnâ€™t have a permanent roof, the current roof is plastic. He wants to buy materials to put a wood roof on his store and be able to protect his merchandise.

He is asking for a loan of $500 dollars.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

El Sr. M. esta pidiendo su segundo crÃ©dito con Kiva. Su primero crÃ©dito se utilizÃ³ para comprar mercancÃ­a para su tienda de abarrotes. El ya termino de pagar su primer crÃ©dito.

El negocio no cuenta con un techo fijo el que tiene es de plÃ¡stico. En este nuevo crÃ©dito el quiere comprar el material para poner el techo de madera en el negocio y tener mÃ¡s protegida la mercancÃ­a.

El solicita un prÃ©stamo de $500.00 dolares.

loan.use: Buy materials for a wood roof.

loan.name: Adjo

texts.fr:
Born in 1980 in GavikopÃ© (in Zio Prefecture), Mrs. Adjo K. had to abandon her studies at primary level due to lack of means. A widow and the mother of four children, she has devoted herself to growing corn, which enables her to provide for her children's needs since her husband left no inheritance. She is requesting financing so that she can increase the area of land she cultivates and, consequently, her income. This will allow her to provide adequately for the needs of her family.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer.

Elle sollicite un financement qui lui permettra dâ€™augmenter sa surface cultivÃ©e et de facto ses besoins. Ce qui lui permettra alors de subvenir convenablement aux besoins de sa famille.

loan.name: Godwin

texts.en: Godwin is 33 years old. He is married with two kids who are currently in school. Godwin is a dealer in electrical and electronic parts like speakers, transistors, transformers, screw drivers, wires, television cords, antennas, etc. He also provides repairs and servicing works for his customers. He buys his supplies from importers at wholesale prices and sells to his customers at retail prices. He requests the loan to enable him procure increased stock of electrical and electronic parts. He hopes to increase his savings to expand his shop to include refrigerators and parts. He belongs to the community group called Evergreen Trust Group. In this group, members agree to guarantee for each other as a social collateral to repay the loan.

loan.use: To procure increased stock of electrical and electronic parts.

loan.name: Akou

texts.fr:
Born in 1979, Mrs. Akou G. is married and the mother of four children. She has launched herself into farming and, in particular, growing corn, which earns her just enough to support her family. She is very attached to working on the land and has great faith in it. She is requesting financing in order to increase her cultivable land. This will help her satisfy her customers and provide for her familyâ€™s needs.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer.

Ce qui lui assure le minimum vital de la famille. TrÃ¨s liÃ©e Ã  ce mÃ©tier de la terre, elle ne se dÃ©courage pas. Elle sollicite un financement pour augmenter sa surface cultivable. loan.name: Kodjo

texts.fr:
Born in 1977 and the father of two children, Mr. Kodjo A. left school early to devote himself to farming, which earns him just enough to support his family. He is still very attached to this profession. Honest and full of energy, he is requesting financing so that he can increase the area he cultivates and, consequently, his income. This will enable him to provide for his familyâ€™s needs.

loan.name: Abra

texts.fr:
Born in 1986, Mrs. Abra T. had to leave school at primary level due to lack of means. She devoted herself to working in the fields, in particular to growing corn, which enabled her to make ends meet. She is married and has two children to look after. She is a hard worker and is requesting financing to enable her to increase the area of land she cultivates, and consequently her income, in order to improve the living conditions of her family.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer.

loan.name: Yeredon (Knowing Yourself) Group

texts.fr:
The members of the Yeredon group are married women with an average of 25 years of age and 4 children. They live in traditional families with their husbands, in-laws and children in the village of Sikouna 1 in the Fana area (Koulikoro region in Mali). They buy and sell food condiments, charcoal and various other items. The women of the Yeredon group are related or have built strong friendships. This is their first group loan with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution. The sources of their supplies vary according to the items they sell; for charcoal, it is primarily sold on the spot in the surrounding villages through farmers officially appointed to trade it in the area. The main point of their cash sales is in Sikouna 1 and at the market on market days. Their customers are made up of wholesalers from the cities, women and some men. With this loan, they would like to grow their monthly income with which they will pay the interest on the loan and invest the remainder in their respective activities. Their long-term goal is to become wholesalers. Please note that due to health reasons one group member is missing from the photograph.

Translated from French by Ivana Kostic, Kiva Volunteer.

Les membres du groupe Yeredon sont mariÃ©s avec une moyenne dâ€™age de 25 ans et 4enfants .Elles vivent dans des familles traditionnelles avec leurs maris, les beaux parents et les enfants dans le village de Sikouna 1 sous prÃ©fecture de Fana (RÃ©gion de Koulikoro RÃ©publique du Mali). Elles font gÃ©nÃ©ralement le commerce de condiments alimentaires de charbon de bois et dâ€™articles divers. Les femmes du groupe Yeredon ont une relation de voisinage dâ€™alliances et dâ€™amitiÃ©. Câ€™est pour des raisons de santÃ© quâ€™une cliente manque Ã  la photo de groupe.

loan.name: Tomas

texts.es:
Tomas has been working in this field for more than 20 years, and has owned his own business for 3 years. His electronic repair shop is located in his home. His business is the only source of income to support his family, which lives in another state.

He is asking for his first loan from Kiva to buy diagnostic equipment (for example, a voltage test meter) and electronic parts needed to make repairs on televisions, dvd players, speakers, and other electronic devices.

He is asking for a $700 dollar loan.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

texts.fr:
Born in 1960, Mr. Kossi SomÃ© K. is married and the father of seven (7) children. His main occupation is agriculture. He cultivates grains and okra. A very dedicated man, he is requesting a loan to increase his cultivable area by purchasing fertilizer and insecticides. This will increase his yield and thus increase his income.

Translated from French by Allana Carlyle, Kiva Volunteer.

NÃ© en 1960, Monsieur K. Kossi SomÃ© a laissÃ© est mariÃ© et pÃ¨re de sept (7) enfants. Son activitÃ© principale est lâ€™agriculture. Il fait la culture cÃ©rÃ©aliÃ¨re et du gombo. TrÃ¨s dÃ©vouÃ©, il sollicite un financement pour augmenter sa superficie cultivable en achetant de lâ€™engrais et des insecticides. Ceci augmentera son rendement ainsi que ses revenus.

loan.use: The purchase of fertilizer and insecticides to increase his cultivable area.

loan.name: Babacar

texts.fr:
Babacar opened a tailor's workshop that he manages with his apprentices. To grow his income, he wants to buy some cloth, thread, and trim in large amounts. To finance his business, he was a recipient of a loan of 250,000 francs CFA from IMCEC. With this purchase of goods, thanks to the loan, he will benefit from economies of scale and thus grow his income for fortifying or refurbishing his machines.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva volunteer

Babacar a ouvert un atelier de tailleur qu'il gÃ©re avec ses apprentits.Pour accroitre ses revenus ,il veut acheter des tissus ,du fils et de la garniture en quantitÃ© . Pour financer son activitÃ©,il a bÃ©nÃ©ficiÃ© d'un pret de 250000f cfa de l'IMCEC.Avec l'achat de ces produits grace au pret, il bÃ©nÃ©ficiera des Ã©conomies d'Ã©chelles et ainsi accroitre ses revenus pour renforcer ou renouveler ses machines.

loan.use: Working capital

loan.name: Yiriwa (Progress). Group

texts.fr:
Members of the Yiriwa group are married women with an average of 20 years of age and 4 children. They live with their husbands and children in polygamous families in Sikouna 2, a village in the Fana area of Koulikoro in Mali. The Yiriwa group is involved in the breeding and the sale of livestock products (sale of live animals, butter, fresh milk, yogurt, curdled milk, etc). This group of Peulh women (a semi-nomadic people of West Africa specialized in the breeding of cattle), bound through ethnic and linguistic but also family ties, decided to borrow together from the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution. This is their first group loan. With this loan, they would like to build their supplies of cattle food and medication at the veterinary pharmacies in Fana, Marka coungo and Santiguila. They usually sell the livestock and products for cash on market days in these cities, and their business runs year round. In addition to the breeding, some of them sell various articles such as flour. Each member of the group hopes to have a monthly profit of 7.500FCFA which will be used to build their capital.

Translated from French by Ivana Kostic, Kiva Volunteer.

Cette activÃ© est menÃ©e durant toute lâ€™annÃ©e. En plus de lâ€™Ã©levage certaines dâ€™entre elles font le petit commerce de divers articles : arachide farine de niÃ©bÃ© produits de cueillette. loan.name: Trabajando Unidos Group

texts.es:
Hi! We're the Trabajando Unidos ("Working Together") group. We're all merchants, each with our own small business. We have various years of experience operating our businesses. We know each other well, having long worked together. Thanks to the incomes from our different businesses, we can support our families. We should mention, too, how grateful we are to all of you for the support that you extend to us so that we can push our businesses forward.
These are the businesses that we've created:
Rosa Idalia Del Carmen E.. I'm a merchant. I have a general store in the center of my town. I'm a single mother and I have a high school-aged son who helps me with the business in his spare time. I'm asking for your help so that I can stock my business and meet the demand of my customers.
Carlos Alberto C.. My main work is reselling merchandise but I'm also the pastor of a church in my town. I work as a street vendor, selling milk products. I have 5 elementary school-aged children.
Jose Daniel C.. My main work is selling and repairing bicycles. I've made a living this way for some years and, thanks to God, it generates enough income to cover the needs of my family. I'm married and have 4 children, all of whom are school-aged. They help me with the business and together we're pushing it forward. Es importante mencionar que gracias al apoyo que ustedes nos brinden, podemos salir adelante con nuestros negocios.

loan.use: Buy merchandise for resale.

loan.name: Adjo

texts.fr:
Born in 1966, Mrs. Adjo K. left her studies very early. Not having been encouraged ahead in her studies, she turned to working the earth and like her husband she is particularly involved with the cultivation of cassava. A mother of eight (8) children, she manages to provide for the needs of her family. She is requesting a loan to increase her cultivable land. This will allow her to increase her income. She will therefore be able to secure a suitable life for her family.

Translated from French by Allana Carlyle, Kiva Volunteer.

loan.use: Increase her cultivable land

loan.name: Kadiatou

texts.fr:
Mrs. Kadiatou S. is a 49 year-old mother of 6 children. She lives in a close-knit family with her husband and her children in Fana Coura, one of the districts of the Fana region (Koulikoro area in Mali). For social reasons, she had to give up her studies to help her mother with housework and in the kitchen. After more than 15 years of working with and learning from her mother, she decided to open a restaurant. Her restaurant is located at the large Fana market on a very busy crossroad. Her clientele are mainly travellers, drivers and people going to the market. The variety of meals in her restaurant is very appreciated by the regulars. In order to obtain additional resources to support her restaurand amidst increasing competition, she decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance instutution. After 3 group loans through a local association, this is her fourth individual loan. All of her previous loans were refunded in time. With this loan, she would like to buy 600 kg of rice and a large quantity of condiments to build her supplies. Currently she earns approximately 35.000 FCFA, but with this new loan, hopes to increase it to 45.000 CFA, which she will use to help her husband with the family expenses and to invest the remainder in her business and in buying equipment for the restaurant.

Translated from French by Ivana Kostic, Kiva Volunteer.

loan.name: Los Robles Group

texts.es:
Hi. We're the Los Robles ("The Oaks") group. We're merchants, each with his or her own small business which we operate personally. Thanks to these businesses, we can help our families get ahead and provide higher standards of living for our children. Given the economic situation of our country, which is becoming more difficult by the day, we have to make our own work and that's why we're looking for help to fund our businesses. We now need small supplies of goods for our businesses so that we can offer our customers a range of products and, in turn, increase our incomes. After all, more inventory means more sales.
MIGUEL AGEL D.. My main business is buying and selling produce. I work as a street vendor, selling my products in the various neighborhoods of our city. I have several years' experience at this. I am married and I have 3 children who help me in their spare time.
HUMBERTO R.. I operate a small general store in the center of my neighborhood. I have several years' experience at this and I've built a good customer base. I'm a senior citizen. I'm asking you to help me fund stocks of goods for my business.
VENTURA DE JESUS M.. I operate a small general store at my house. The business allows me to take care of my husband and children and earn an income to help with family expenses at the same time. I have two high school-aged children. Tomando en cuenta que la situacion economica del pais cada dia es mas dificil por lo que decidimos trabajar y por tal razon buscamos financiamiento para nuestros negocios. Actualmente necesitamos surtir un poco mas y asi poder ofrecer a nuestros clientes variedad de productos logrando asi mejorar nuestros ingresos ya que a mayor surtido mayor venta.

loan.use: Buy merchandise for resale.

loan.name: Alfa Y Omega Group

texts.es:
Hi. We are the Alfa y Omega ("Alpha & Omega") group. We earn our living buying and selling merchandise, each one of us operating small businesses, selling different kinds of products. We've known each other for some years and we've always worked together. Thanks to the income from our businesses, we've been able to improve the lives of our children and have higher standards of living.
Antonia V.. My main business is making and selling tortillas. I'm a senior citizen now. Thanks to the income from this business, I can help my husband with family expenses. We support each other and that's how we managed to build our house.
Norma Suypa G.. My main business is making and selling clothes and "chicharras" (not sure, literally cicadias, so possibly something that makes a sound or looks like a cicadia?). I have a daughter who is in the first grade. I should mention that thanks to this business, I can contribute to paying my family's expenses. We've managed to buy a solar panel to use at the house that we'll build later.
Luis Edgardo L. M.. I work as a street vendor, selling new clothing in different neighborhood around the city of Danli. My wife and I are trying to improve our standard of living. We have a boy at a local preschool. We now need to stock our business but we don't have enough capital to do it so we're applying to you for help. loan.name: Abra

texts.fr:
Born in 1959, Mrs. Abra A. is a married mother of three (3) children. Very early she became involved in the preparation and sale of palm oil and thanks to this income she is able to contribute to the needs of her household. To better satisfy her clientele and to grow her production, she is requesting a loan to purchase large quantities of palm nuts. This will help her to better support her needs.

texts.fr:
Born in 1978, Mrs. Akossiwa E. abandoned her studies very early and gave herself over to field work with her husband. Married and the mother of three (3) children, she became attached to this work which provides income to help her support the very basic needs of her family. A very energetic and honest woman, she is requesting a loan to expand her farmable land and thus increase her income. By doing so, she will be able to provide for her family in a more satisfactory manner.

Mr. Moise H. was born April 24, 1964, in Grand Popo in the department of Mono. He is married and a father of two: Casimir, 10, and Justine, 8, who both go to school. loan.name: Kossigan

texts.fr:
Born in 1952, Mr. Kossigan S. abandoned his studies very early due to lack of financial support and returned to apprenticeship. A tailor by profession, this career became secondary due to the income he earns from the cultivation of peanuts and cassava. By doing this he manages to support his nine (9) children. According to his neighbors, he has proven to be a good manager. He is thus requesting a loan to expand his peanut and cassava field. With this loan he hopes to increase his business profit and therefore effectively contribute to the improvement of his familyâ€™s living conditions.

Translated from French by Allana Carlyle, Kiva Volunteer.

loan.name: Augustina

texts.en: Augustina is 35 years old. She is a wife and the mother of three children who are in school. She is very enterprising and she has been trading to support her childrenâ€™s education. She sells and supplies refrigerators and cookers to the staff of institutions. She makes it flexible for her loyal customers to take stock on credit and make regular payments, especially monthly workers. Augustina says this strategy is good because it enables her to make increased sales over a short period. She hopes the loan will inject more capital into her business to enable her to take cash delivery from her suppliers to reduce the cost of operations. She also hopes to increase her savings to support her childrenâ€™s education. She is a member of the group called â€˜Kae Awuradeâ€™ (meaning, remember the Lord) Trust Group.

loan.use: To purchase increased stock of refrigerators, electric and gas cookers.

loan.name: Lydia

texts.en: Lydia, 38 years old, is married with two kids who are in school. She has been selling grocery products for five years in the town to support her family. She says business is doing well, and she therefore wants to use the loan to buy more products to increase her inventory. Lydia believes this loan would help her increase her savings towards the welfare of her two children, who are in school now. She is a member of the group called â€˜Nyame mmere' (meaning, Godâ€™s time). Members agree in principle to guarantee for each other to repay the loan.

loan.use: To buy more grocery products like canned fish and tomatoes, cocoa products, skim milk, body pomade, etc.

loan.name: Mamou

texts.fr:
Mrs. Mamou C. is 31 years old and mother of three (3) children (2 boys and 1 girl). She lives with her husband and their children in MÃ©dine, one of the districts of the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Mrs. Mamou C. has been buying and selling wood for heating for the past 15 years, a trade she learned from her mother. Her business is well known and receives numerous orders, especially in the winter. To strengthen her financial means for this business, she decided join the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution. She has been a member of Soro Yiriwaso for the past three (3) years and has benefited from 3 group loans through an association of women from her district. This is now her first individual loan. All the preceding loans were refunded in time. With the current loan, she would like to buy a truck load of firewood for heating in order to satisfy the needs of her growing clientele. She supplies the town of Sikasso and its surrounding areas. Mrs. Mamou CissÃ© hopes to raise her monthly profits to 75.000 FCFA with which she intends to fund her expenses, to contribute to the family needs, to pay the interest on her loan and to invest the remainder in her business.

loan.name: Ama

texts.fr:
Born in 1969 in Ghana, Ama G. was never able to attend school because her family was too poor to send her. She now lives in Lonvo with her husband and she practices a profession she truly enjoys: the preparation of palm oil. She cares for two of her sisters' children. Very much an entrepreneur, and having mastered her enterprise, she is asking for a loan that will allow her to purchase more palm nuts so that she may increase her palm oil production. With this loan, she is hoping to increase her profits and to better her family's living conditions from now on.

Rachel is a very skilled and talented hairdresser who adds beauty and style to the hair of her customers. She believes in the efficiency and effectiveness of service, therefore she wants to use the loan to buy larger quantities of hair products like weavons, pomade, shampoo, activators, etc. to provide quality service to her customers. She hopes to increase her savings and include the sale of cosmetics. She is a member of the community group called â€œNyame ye odoâ€ (God is love) Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as a social collateral to access loans and help each other to repay the loan.

Born in 1984 in Nyigbe, Mrs. Massan E. was forced to abandon her studies in elementary school because her family lacked the money necessary to send her. She then began to work in the fields, in particular in the cultivation of corn,which helps her to earn a minimal profit. She has three children to care for and so she needs an industry that will earn her enough money to support them. She is asking for a loan that will be used to enlarge her fields and thereby increase her revenues. With this, she will be better able to improve her family's living conditions.

And so, he turned to farming, in particular corn. The father of two children, he is able to support his family because of this enterprise. Currently, he is asking for a loan that will help him to enlarge his field thereby helping to contribute to the improvement of his family's living conditions.

texts.fr:
Fatoumata S. is 43 years old and the mother of five children (two boys and three girls). She has been making voluntary savings deposits at Soro Yiriwaso for two months, and she is on her first PIC (individual commercial loan).

With this loan, she intends to buy 5 boxes of hair cream of different grades, 5 women's handbags, 10 coolers, 5 dozen coffee mugs, 5 boxes of bath soap, and 5 pairs of shoes. loan.name: Hermanas Unidas Group

texts.en:
Estama M. has found a unique niche in her local community juS.outside of Puerto Plata, Dominican Republic. When someone has an old or broken piece of furniture, they take it to her. She has begun a small business repairing chairs, sofas, beds, and other furniture. Left by her husband several years ago, Estama has found herself in the same position as many women here in the Dominican and in her home country, Haiti. She is left to provide for her two boys (ages 14, 16) with whatever means she can. The money from this loan will go towards purchasing paint, sand paper, various tools, as well as several old beds that may be refurbished and sold. She aspires to continue growing her business, so that someday she might be able to own her own shop that she can work out of.

Estama is one of the leaders of the 10 person micro bank Hermanas Unidas, which means "United Sisters". All ten women in the bank are Haitian immigrants who have come to earn a living in the Dominican informal sector. These unique entrepreneurs unite in solidarity, promising to cover one another if someone fails on a payment, thus allowing them to access funding that they would otherwise never be able to receive on their own. The concept of this group bank paying their loan together is to reduce the risk of one person defaulting due to the strong peer pressure from their fellow bank members. As these 10 women embark upon their firS.ever loan from Esperanza, we are confident that they will all succeed in bettering their lives and the lives of their families with this loan. Their businesses are simple, but offer a stream of income that could never have been accomplished without such a loan for initial capital. Several of the women sell clothes and shoes in the street, and a couple of them will offer housecleaning services and beauty supplies.

On behalf of Estama M., the Hermanas Unidas group, and the entire team here at Esperanza International, we thank you for your support and awareness of the global issue of poverty, in which your efforts are helping to make a difference

loan.use: To purchase, paint, sandpaper, tools, and several old beds to be refurbished and sold.

A hairdresser by profession, she has also been selling various common consumables for eight years. The location of her house is a real asset for her. Of good character, she is devoted to this business, which enables her to cover a large portion of family expenses. She is requesting this loan to respond to the ever-growing demands of her customers.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva volunteer

loan.name: LÃ©ontine

texts.fr:
Born around 1956, Ms. LÃ©ontine B. is originally from Zangnanado, in the AGONLIN region in the middle of BÃ©nin, in ZOU County. She is a widow and the mother of five children: Honorat, Jean, Josiane, Odette, and Angenor. Five years ago, she used to sell ready-to-eat meals in front of her house. This business was not entirely satisfactory to her. So, she decided to turn towards other work. This is how she got started selling roasted acajou nuts (from the mahogany tree), condiments of all sorts, boiled corn mash, and other items. To bolster her business level, in order to meet the needs of her customers, she is here to request this loan of 100,000 francs.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva volunteer

Cette activitÃ© ne lui donnait pas entiÃ¨re satisfaction. Elle donc dÃ©cidÃ© de s'orienter vers d'autres activitÃ©s. loan.name: Yvonne

texts.fr:
Born on April 7, 1963 in Dassa-ZounmÃ¨, in Collines County, Ms. Yvonne N. is single with one child: PrÃ©cieux, age 10, in the 5th grade at school. Trained in freight logistics, she got started in the domain of selling ready-to-eat meals all the while working in transit. She has already been in this sector for twenty years, and she applies herself in making various kinds of dishes that she delivers to several services of the public administration, as she does to the private sector. The demand has been stronger and stronger in recent months, and her current working capital does not allow her to meet customer demand. With this in consideration, she is requesting as her second loan an amount of 350,000 francs in order to respond properly to the growing demand.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva volunteer

loan.name: GÃ©ronime

texts.fr:
Born on May 27, 1971 in Avrankou, in OuÃ©mÃ© County, Ms. GÃ©ronime K. was initiated into commerce at the earliest age by her mother, now deceased. Currently, she is a retailer of fruit of all kinds: bananas, papayas, oranges, etc..... Married, she is the mother of four children, including the eldest, Olivier, age 20, a refrigeration apprentice; Mariane, age 17, in 7th grade; and twins FÃ©licienne et FÃ©licitÃ©, age 10, in 3rd and 4th grades respectively. In order to bolster her capital and to energize her business, she is requesting as her third loan the amount of 100,000 francs.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva volunteer

NÃ©e le 27 Mai 1971 Ã  Avrankou dans le dÃ©partement de l'ouÃ©mÃ©. Dame K. GÃ©ronime est initiÃ©e au commerce dÃ¨s son plus jeune Ã¢ge par sa dÃ©funte mÃ¨re.
